ARTICLE I. - DEVELOPMENT IMPACT FEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Sec. 3 of Ord. No. 2017-37, adopted Sept. 19, 2017, changed the title of art. I from In General to "Development Impact Fees"; and repealed and reenacted §§ 30-1-30-9 in their entirety to read as herein set out. Said §§ 30-1-30-9 pertained to various provisions relating to building and building regulations, and derived from Ord. No. 620, adopted Mar. 5, 1974; Ord. No. 839, adopted June 5, 1979; Ord. No. 884, adopted Aug. 19, 1980; Ord. No. 885, adopted Aug. 18, 1980; Ord. No. 913, adopted May 19, 1981; Ord. No. 916, adopted July 21, 1981; Ord. No. 957, adopted Oct. 5, 1982; Ord. No. 994, adopted Sept. 20, 1983; Ord. No. 1984-30, adopted Sept. 18, 1984; Ord. No. 1986-35, adopted Oct. 7, 1986; Ord. No. 1989-50, adopted Oct. 3, 1989; Ord. No. 1990-17, adopted Aug. 21, 1990; Ord. No. 1994-21, adopted Aug. 2, 1994; Ord. No. 2005-10, adopted Mar. 1, 2005; and Ord. No. 2007-38, adopted Sept. 4, 2007. 

Sec. 30-1. - Intent. 
(a)  The intent of this article is to ensure that new development bears the proportionate share of the costs of the city's municipal capital facilities, and parks and recreation capital facilities. 
(b)  It is the intent of this article that the impact fees imposed upon new development are no greater than necessary to defray the impacts directly related to new development (i.e., the costs of city municipal capital facilities and parks and recreation capital facilities), as are necessary to accommodate new development. 
(c)  It is not the intent of this article that the impact fees be used to remedy any existing deficiency in municipal capital facilities or parks and recreation capital facilities. 
(d)  It is not the intent of this chapter that any monies collected from any impact fee deposited in an impact fee trust fund account ever be comingled with monies from a different trust account, or ever be used for capital facilities that are different from that, for which, the fee was paid, or ever be used to replace or rehabilitate existing city municipal capital facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Building means any structure without reference to use or occupancy for which a building permit is required for ordinances of the city. 
    Building official means the officer charged with the administration and enforcement of the uniform building code adopted by the city or his regularly authorized deputy. 
    Capital facility means any improvement or facility that: 
(1)  Is directly related to any service that the city is authorized to provide and has an estimated useful life of five (5) years or longer. 
(2)  Firefighting apparatus and ambulances shall qualify as "capital facility" for the purposes of this chapter. 
    City means the City of Lafayette, Colorado. 
    City road system means all collector and arterial roads within the city that are included within the "city street system" as defined by Colorado statute. 
    Contractor means any person, firm, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other entity required to obtain a building permit pursuant to the ordinances of the city. 
    Development means any construction or expansion of a building or structure, or use, any change in use of a building or structure, or any change in the use of land, which creates an additional demand for municipal capital facilities. 
    Development permit means any final approval of an application for rezoning, a final PUD plan, special review use permit, subdivision, site and architectural plan, building permit or similar application for new development. 
    Floor area means the area included within the surrounding exterior walls of a building, or portion thereof, excluding parking garages. 
    Impact fee(s) means the service expansion impact fee and parks and recreation facilities impact fee established by this article. 
    Impact fee trust fund means the trust fund established pursuant to this article that includes a municipal capital facilities account and parks and recreation capital facilities account. The trust fund is also called "the trust fund." 
    Municipal capital facilities means the building improvements for office space at the Lafayette City Hall and other capital facility improvements used to provide general administrative services to the city government, the building improvements to the city's public works yard and facilities, the building improvements for the city's public library, building improvements associated with police and fire facilities, including communications equipment, and transportation capital facilities as defined herein. Municipal capital facilities does not include the cost of vehicles and equipment other than firefighting apparatus and ambulances. 
    Parks and recreation capital facilities means the real property, building improvements and capital facility used to provide parks and recreation services to the citizens of Lafayette, including the recreation center, municipal aquatics park and senior services center, but excluding the golf course. 
    Site-related improvement(s) means those transportation improvements that provide direct access to a development, other than arterial roads and interchanges on the city road system. Direct access improvements include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Driveways and streets leading to and from the development; 
(2)  Right or left turn lanes leading to those driveways and streets; 
(3)  Traffic lights and other traffic control measures for those driveways; and 
(4)  Internal street, traffic lights, and other traffic control measures. 
    The foregoing street improvements include all improvements within the right-of-way, including, but not limited to, all road preparation and surfacing, curb and gutter, medians, entryways, underground utilities, sidewalks, bicycle paths, bridges, street lighting, landscaping and drainage improvements. Credit is not provided for site-related improvements under the terms of this chapter. 
    Transportation capital facilities means the preliminary engineering, engineering design studies, land surveys, alignment studies, engineering, permitting and construction of all necessary features for any road in the city road system, undertaken to accommodate additional traffic (through the provision of additional capacity) resulting from new impact generating development in the city. Transportation capital facilities include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Construction of new through lanes; 
(2)  Construction of new bridges; 
(3)  Construction of new drainage facilities in conjunction with new road construction; 
(4)  Purchase and installation of traffic signals, including new and upgraded signalization; 
(5)  Construction of curbs, gutters, sidewalks, medians, and shoulders, in conjunction with new road construction; 
(6)  Relocating utilities to accommodate new road construction; 
(7)  Construction and reconstruction of intersections; 
(8)  Widening of existing roads; 
(9)  Bus turnouts; 
(10)  Acceleration and deceleration lanes; 
(11)  Interchanges; 
(12)  Traffic control devices; and 
(13)  Bicycle and pedestrian improvements that the city determines are not site related improvements. 
    Transportation capital facilities include all necessary rights of way for the expansion or construction of a road in the city road system. For the purposes of this article, site-related improvements shall not constitute transportation capital facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-3. - Impact fees established. 
(a)  Service expansion impact fee. There is hereby established a "service expansion impact fee," which fee is established as an impact fee pertaining to municipal capital facilities. 
(b)  Parks and recreation facilities impact fee. There is hereby established an impact fee pertaining to parks and recreation capital facilities. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall restrict the city from requiring a contractor to construct reasonable capital facilities improvements designed and intended to serve the needs of the contractor's project, whether or not such capital facility improvements are of a type for which credits are available under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-4. - Development impact fees to be imposed. 
(a)  Fee obligation, payment and deposit. 
(1)  Obligation to pay and time of payment. Any contractor applying for a building permit, except those exempted pursuant to this article, shall be obligated to pay impact fees pursuant to the terms of this article. The obligation to pay the impact fees shall run with the land. The amount of the impact fees shall be determined by city council by the adoption of a resolution, and shall be calculated as provided below. 
(2)  Fees promptly deposited into account trust fund. All monies paid by a fee payer pursuant to this article shall be identified as impact fees and shall be promptly deposited into the appropriate impact fee trust account established and described in this article. 
(3)  Extension of previously issued development permit. If the contractor is applying for a development permit issued previously, the impact fee(s) required to be paid shall be the net increase between the impact fees applicable at the time of the current permit extension application, and any impact fees previously paid pursuant to this article, and shall include any impact fees established subsequent to such prior payment. 
(4)  Permit for change in use, expansion, redevelopment, modification. If the contractor is applying for a building permit to allow for the change of use, or for the expansion, redevelopment or modification of an existing development, the impact fees required to be paid shall be based on the net increase in the impact fees for the new use as compared to the previous use and shall include any impact fees established subsequent to such prior payment. 
(b)  Exemption. The following types of development shall be exempted from payment of the impact fee(s). Any claim for exemption shall be made no later than the time when the applicant applies for the first building permit. Any claim for exemption not made at or before that time shall be waived. The city planner director or designee shall be determine the validity for any claim for exemption pursuant to the standards set forth below: 
(1)  Replacing existing residential unit with new unit. Reconstruction, expansion, alteration, or replacement of a previously existing residential unit that does not create any additional residential unit. 
(2)  New impact generating development that creates no greater demand than previous development. New impact generating development that an applicant can demonstrate will create no greater demand over and above that produced by the existing use or development. 
(3)  Building after fire or catastrophe. Rebuilding the same amount of floor space of a structure that was destroyed by a fire or other catastrophe. 
(4)  Accessory structure. Construction of unoccupied accessory structure related to a residential unit. 
(5)  Previous payment of same amount of impact fee. Impact-generating development for which an impact fee was previously paid in an amount that equals or exceeds the impact fee would be required by this chapter. 
(6)  Government. Development by federal government, state of Colorado, or the city. 
(c)  Calculation of amount of impact fee(s). Impact fees shall be established by city council by the adoption of a resolution. Such fees shall be calculated and predicated upon the estimated costs as are necessary to defray the projected impacts caused by the proposed new development on the municipal capital facilities and/or parks and recreation capital facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-5. - Credits. 
(a)  Any contractor applying for a building permit may apply for a credit against impact fees otherwise due, up to but not exceeding the full obligation of the impact fees proposed to be paid pursuant to the provisions of this article, for any contributions, construction, or dedication of land (where appropriate) accepted by the city, for city municipal capital facilities or parks and recreation capital facilities. Credit against service expansion impact fees shall be allowed only for municipal capital facilities that are related to a service expansion fee. A credit against the parks and recreation impact fee shall be allowed only for the provision of parks and recreation capital facilities. 
(b)  Valuation of credits. 
(1)  Land dedication. Credit for land dedication shall be valued at the fair market value of the land established by either by agreement with the city, or by a private appraiser acceptable to the city in an appraisal paid for by the contractor. 
(2)  Construction. Credit for construction of capital facilities shall be valued by the city based upon the completed engineering drawings, specifications, and construction cost estimates submitted by the contractor to the city. The city shall determine the amount of the credit due based upon the information submitted, or, if determined that the information is inaccurate or unreliable, then on alternative or construction costs acceptable to the city planning director or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-6. - Impact fee trust fund. 
(a)  Establishment of trust fund and accounts. 
(1)  There is hereby established the impact fee trust fund (hereinafter "trust fund") for the purpose of ensuring the impact fees collected pursuant to this article are designated for the accommodation of capital facilities impacts reasonably attributable to new impact generating development for which the fees are paid. 
(2)  The trust fund shall be divided into two (2) accounts: A service expansion capital improvement account, and a parks and recreation capital improvement account. 
(b)  Deposit and management of accounts and trust fund. 
(1)  The impact fee trust fund and the two (2) accounts shall be maintained as an interest-bearing account and shall be managed in conformance with C.R.S. § 29-1-801, et seq. 
(2)  All impact fees collected by the city pursuant to this article shall be promptly deposited into the appropriate account in the trust fund. 
(3)  Any proceeds in the trust fund accounts not immediately necessary for expenditure shall be invested in an interest-bearing account. Interest earned on the monies in the accounts shall be considered a part of such an account and shall be subject to the same restrictions on use applicable to the impact fees in such account. 
(4)  Monies in each trust account shall be considered to be spent in the order collected on a first in/first out basis. 
(5)  A record of the trust fund accounts shall be available for public inspection in the city administrator or designee's office during normal business hours. 
(c)  Annual reporting. At least once annually, the finance director shall publish on the city's website, in a clear, concise and user friendly format, information detailing the allocation by dollar amount of each impact fee account collected, the average annual interest rate earned for each account and the total amount of disbursements from each account during the city's most recent fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-7. - Expenditure of impact fees. 
(a)  Service expansion impact fee. The monies collected from the service expansion impact fee shall be used only to acquire and construct municipal capital facilities. 
(b)  Parks and recreation facility impact fee. The monies collected from the parks and recreation facility impact fee shall be used only to acquire and construct parks and recreation capital improvements. 
(c)  No monies shall be spent for periodic or routine maintenance, rehabilitation, or replacement of any capital facilities. 
(d)  No monies shall be spent to remedy existing deficiencies in capital facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-8. - Refund of impact fees paid. 
(a)  Any impact fees collected shall be returned to the contractor paying such fee, or the contractor's successor-in-interest, if the impact fees have not been spent or encumbered within six (6) years from the date of the building permit for which the development was issued, along with interest actually earned on the fees. Fees shall be deemed spent on the basis of the first fee collected shall be the first fee spent. 
(b)  The refund shall be administered by the city's planning director or designee. 
(1)  A refund application shall be submitted within one (1) year following the end of the sixth year from the date on which the building permit was issued. The refund application shall include the following application: 
a.  A copy of the dated receipt issued for payment of the fee. 
b.  A copy of the building permit. 
c.  Evidence that the applicant is the successor-in-interest or the contractor who paid the fee. 
(2)  Within fifteen (15) days of the receipt of the refund application, the city's planning director or designee shall determine if it is complete. If it is determined that the application is not complete a written statement specifying the deficiencies shall be forwarded by mail to the person submitting the application. The city's planning director or designee shall take no further action on the refund application until it is deemed complete. 
(c)  When it is determined that the refund application is complete, it shall be reviewed within thirty (30) days and shall be approved if it is determined a fee has been paid which has not been spent within the period of time permitted under this section. The refund shall include the fee paid, plus interest actually earned on the fee. 
(Ord. No. 2017-37, § 3, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 30-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. No. 2007-38, adopted Sept. 4, 2007, repealed § 30-10 in its entirety. Former § 30-10 pertained to the collection and expenditure of the parks and recreation fee and derived from Ord. No. 620, adopted Mar. 5, 1974; Ord. No. 836, adopted June 5, 1979; Ord. No. 913, adopted May 19, 1981, Ord. No. 944, adopted Sept. 20, 1983; Ord. No. 1984-30, adopted Sept. 18, 1984; and Ord. No. 2005-10, adopted Mar. 1, 2005. 
Sec. 30-11. - Engineering inspection fees. 
    Any contractor as defined in section 30-8 applying for a building permit in accordance with the applicable ordinances and codes of the city, for the purpose of a building to be used for residential purposes, shall, as a condition to obtaining such building permit, pay to the city a per unit fee in an amount set by resolution of city council for new residential construction to be used by the city for the inspection by an engineer of capital improvements constructed in conjunction with said building. The payment of said fee may be deferred pursuant to article XIV of this chapter. Where any dwelling unit is razed and subsequently rebuilt, the amount owing for the engineering inspection fee may be discounted in an amount set by resolution of city council for each dwelling unit razed. 
(Ord. No. 1010, § 1, 1-3-84; Ord. No. 1984-31, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 1986-41, § 1, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 1990-17, § 17, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 1994-21, § 3, 8-2-94; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 19, 3-1-05) 
Secs. 30-12-30-14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 2017-37, adopted Sept. 19, 2017, recodified §§ 30-12-30-14 to be included in § 28-34. Former §§ 30-12-30-14 pertained to public art fees, and derived from Ord. No. 2005-18, adopted June 7, 2005; and Ord. No. 2011-33, adopted Sept. 20, 2011. 
Secs. 30-15-30-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONTRACTORS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations generally, Ch. 55. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-21. - Compliance with article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any contractor licensed under the provisions of this article to violate any provisions of this article or to violate or refuse to obey any order issued under the authority or neglect to pay any fee assessed under the authority of this article. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-22. - Issuance of permits to license holders. 
    On any work requiring a licensed contractor, permits under this chapter shall be issued only to the contractor or to his authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-23. - Fraudulent use of license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fraudulently use a contractor's license issued to a contractor under this article to obtain permits for another person. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
State Law reference- See generally, offenses involving fraud, C. R. S. Title 18, Article 5; criminal impersonation, C. R. S. § 18-5-113. 
Sec. 30-24. - Safety standards generally. 
(a)  All state laws, provisions of this Code or other city ordinances dealing with measures for the safety of workmen and the public shall be observed by contractors within the city, in addition to any requirements contained within this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a contractor to be careless or negligent in obtaining minimum safety measures, including appliances, apparatus and equipment to protect workmen and the public. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
State Law reference- Industrial and commercial safety, Title 9, C.R.S. 
Sec. 30-25. - Failure to obtain permit or inspection. 
    It shall be unlawful for a contractor to fail to obtain inspection services when the same are required or fail to obtain a permit when the same is required. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-26. - Responsibility for contracted work. 
    A contractor shall be responsible for all work included in his contract, whether or not such work is done by him directly or by a subcontractor. He shall be responsible for all funds or property received by him for prosecution or completion of a specific contract or for a specific purpose. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-27. - Violation of article. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, convert or demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure in the city or cause the same to be done contrary to or in violation of any of the provisions of this article. Any person violating any of the provisions of his article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  The suspension or revocation of any license, permit or other privilege conferred by the city shall not be deemed a penalty for the purposes of this section. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Secs. 30-28-30-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-36. - Required generally; classification. 
    Licenses or registrations shall be required for all types of work specified in this division unless otherwise stated and such licenses or registrations shall be classified in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-10, 11B-16, 26-10; Ord. No. 663, § 2, 1-20-76) 
State Law reference- Power of city council to license, regulate and tax occupations and business places, C. R. S. § 31-15-501 
Sec. 30-37. - Approval of certain issuances. 
    No person may be issued a license or registration to engage in the following listed trades, jobs or contractual service as enumerated in this section unless approved by the city administrator or his designated agent: 
(1)  Builder's license, Class A 
(2)  Builder's license, Class B 
(3)  Builder's license, Class C 
(4)  Plumber's license, Class A-master 
(5)  Heating contractor's license 
(6)  Electrical registration 
(7)  Appliance license 
(8)  Gas fitter's license 
(9)  Masonry license 
(10)  Concrete and form license 
(11)  Warm air heating and ventilating license 
(12)  House and building mover's license 
(13)  Wrecker's license 
(14)  Excavating license 
(15)  Special contractor's license 
(16)  Mobil home installer's license 
(17)  Sign contractor's license 
(18)  Satellite dish antenna installer's license. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 3, 1-20-76; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 1, 2-3-87) 
State Law reference- Electricians, C. R. S. § 12-23-100.2 et seq.; plumbers, C. R. S. § 12-58-101 et seq. 
Sec. 30-38. - When examination not required. 
    All persons who have been previously licensed under the provisions of this division by the city to engage in the trades, jobs or contractual services mentioned in section 30-37, shall not be required to be examined, provided however, that all persons must hold a license issued by the state, if required by the state, before engaging in any trade, job or contractual service within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 3, 1-20-76) 
State Law reference- Electricians, C. R. S. § 12-23-100.2 et seq.; plumbers, C. R. S. § 12-58-101 et seq. 
Sec. 30-39. - Supervisors-General policy with respect to licenses. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, all licenses enumerated in this article shall be issued under authority of and in accordance with the terms and provisions of sections 30-39-30-43 and shall be subject to the supervisory clauses contained in those sections. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-40. - Same-Retained by licensees. 
    The respective licensees under this article, whether individuals, firms or corporations, shall not be required to possess those skills and qualifying experience records required for the work they are permitted to do under the terms and provisions of their respective licenses, provided that they retain in their business a supervisor whose skills and qualifying experience record are such that the would be qualified to do all work in his principal's license category. The respective licensees' rights to do business shall be dependent upon the continued retention of the designated supervisors in active, full-time capacity. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-16, 26-16; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-41. - Same-When inactive. 
    Whenever a designated supervisor terminates his connection with a licensee or otherwise becomes inactive, the licensee shall immediately notify the building official. In such event the license shall be deemed to be suspended and there shall be a thirty (30) day grace period in order to acquire a proper supervisor before complete termination of the license. Should the supervisor be replaced or should his retention in the business of the licensee be renewed, such fact shall be made known to the building official. If the proposed replacement has been found by the city administrator to meet the qualifications imposed by section 30-40 the license shall again be deemed in full force and effect without imposition of an additional fee for the same calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-42. - Same-Review; designation in application for license. 
    Each individual who is to act as a supervisor under this division shall be reviewed in accordance with the provisions of this division for the work proposed to be done. Each individual who is to act as a supervisor shall be designated as such in each application for a license. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-43. - Same-Working hours. 
    Licensed supervisors under this division must be on the job at all times during working hours. If something is needed for the job, the apprentice should be sent. At no time will an apprentice be on any job without a licensed supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-44. - Application-Contents; receipt and forwarding by building official. 
    Applications for contractor's licenses shall be on such forms and shall furnish such information as the building official may prescribe. The building official shall receive and sign all applications for licenses set out in this section. Upon receiving an application for licensing, the building official shall forward the application to the city administrator for approval. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-45. - Same-Review; standards required for issuance of license. 
    The building official shall review applicants for licenses issued under this division, and the standards to be applied in the conduct of such review shall be the protection of the public health, welfare and public safety of the people of the city, so that those who are recommended to be licensed under this article are financially and morally responsible and qualified in terms of their skills, practical experience and knowledge to contract for or to do the work for which they seek to be licensed. Applicants who are so qualified shall be licensed as provided in this division. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-16, 26-16; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-46. - Insurance-Required; amounts. 
    Every contractor granted a license under the terms of this division shall be required to maintain at all times, to cover employee's liability, public liability insurance with minimum limits of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any one accident, and property damage insurance with a minimum limit of not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one accident. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-3, § 2, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-47. - Same-Certificate of agent. 
    At the time application is made and before a license can be issued, the contractor shall file with the Building official a certificate signed by a qualified agent of an insurance company stating that the policy required in this division has been issued to the licensee for employee's liability insurance or workmen's compensation insurance, public liability insurance and public property damage insurance; the minimum limits of each and the policy number; the name of the company, the effective date of such policies and the expiration date of such policies, together with a statement and a copy of an endorsement placed on such policy requiring ten (10) days written notice by registered mail to the building official if it becomes necessary to cancel the policy for any reason. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-48. - Same-Cancellation. 
    In the event of a cancellation of a policy of insurance under this division, the licensee shall be required to furnish a new certificate in full compliance with the terms of sections 30-46-30-48 within the ten (10) day period; otherwise, the license shall automatically be revoked. The license shall be reinstated when the licensee has furnished a certificate of insurance in compliance with such sections, unless such license is suspended for reasons other than the failure to file a proper certificate of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-49. - Other requirements prerequisite to issuance. 
    Any licenses or lawful requirements imposed by other provisions of this Code, other ordinances of the city or laws of the state upon an applicant for a contractor's license under this division shall be deemed prerequisites to the issuance of such license. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-50. - Issuance. 
    If, in the opinion of the building official, the applicant for a license required by this division is qualified by training or experience and is financially and morally responsible to fulfill the obligation of a contractor, he shall issue the applicant a license upon payment of the annual fee prescribed in this division. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-51. - Use by other person. 
    No license issued pursuant to this article shall be used for work performed by any person other than the person to whom said license has been issued. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-15, 26-15) 
Sec. 30-52. - Term; renewal. 
    A contractor's license issued under the provisions of this division shall have a term of one (1) year commencing on the date of issue and shall expire the last day of the month of issuance of the succeeding year. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-13, 26-13; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 3, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-53. - Annual Fees; amount generally. 
    The annual license fee or registration fee applicable to the license or registration required and set forth in this section shall be set by resolution of city council is section shall be as follows: 
Type of License 
Builder's license-Class A 
Builder's license-Class B 
Builder's license-Class C 
Heating contractor's license 
Plumber's license 
Appliance license 
Gas fitter's license 
Masonry license 
Concrete and form license 
Warm air heating and ventilating license 
Mover's license 
Wrecker's license 
Excavating license 
Special contractor's license 
Mobile home installer's license 
Sign contractor's license 
Satellite dish antenna installer's license 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-12, 26-12; Ord. No. 712, § 1, 2-1-77; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 4, 2-3-87; Ord. No. 1988-13, § 1, 7-19-88; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 20, 3-1-05) 
Secs. 30-54, 30-55. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1987-03, §§ 5, 6, adopted Feb. 3, 1987, repealed §§ 30-54 and 30-55. Prior to repeal, § 30-54 had set a license fee for licenses purchased after July first of any year, and § 30-55 had set license renewal deadline of Feb. 15, as well as a penalty for late renewal. Such sections were derived from Ord. No. 712, § 1, adopted Feb. 1, 1977. 
Sec. 30-56. - Revocation; suspension. 
(a)  The building official may, upon his own motion, and shall, upon the verified complaint in writing of any person, require any person licensed under this division to appear before the city council for a hearing upon five (5) days written notice, mailed to his last known post office address, or by notice served personally. 
(b)  The city council shall have the power to temporarily suspend or permanently revoke a license if the holder thereof, after a proper hearing, is found guilty of, or commits, one or more of the acts prohibited in this chapter. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-18, 26-18; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-57. - Permits-License in good standing required. 
    No permit shall be issued to any contractor who has not first obtained a license as required by this division or who is delinquent in the payment of his annual fee, or whose license has been suspended or revoked by action of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-58. - Same-Work determined by license held. 
    Licensed contractors may apply for and be issued permits to do only work as they are entitled to do under their respective licenses. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-59. - Same-Fraudulent applications. 
    Any application for a permit or license filed in derogation of sections 30-57-30-61 shall be deemed to have been filed with fraudulent intent and shall be a nullity. Any permit or license issued on the basis of such fraudulent application shall be null and void. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-60. - Same-When license not required. 
    Any individual who owns and resides in a single-family residence shall not be required to be licensed for any work to that residence performed by the owner/occupant. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-11, 26-11; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 7, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-61. - Same-Processing of excepted applications. 
    Applications under the exception clause in section 30-60 shall be processed as are all other applications for permits, and permits shall be issued only in accordance with those portions of the building, electrical, plumbing, gas fitting, warm air heating, boilers and pressure vessels regulations which relate to structural, technical and safety requirements. 
(Code 1963, § 26-11; Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-62. - Licenses nontransferable. 
    Licenses issued pursuant to this article shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1963, §§ 11B-14, 26-14) 
Secs. 30-63-30-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 30-71. - Class "A." 
    A builder's license class "A" shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of building or contracting for, or altering or adding to the structural portions of any building or structure or portion thereof of types I, II, III, IV or V construction in any and all occupancy group classifications where such work requires the issuance of a permit under this Code or other city ordinances. All such work shall be done in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter and all other city and state laws governing same. A builder's license class "A" shall entitle the licensee to contract for and do necessary demolition and wrecking work in connection with the work specified in this section. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
State Law reference- Building construction requirements, C. R. S. § 9-1-101 et seq. 
Sec. 30-72. - Class "B". 
(a)  A Class "B" builder's license shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of building or contracting for, or altering or adding to structural portions of buildings or structures or portions thereof of any residential building, and to any commercial building where the gross square footage of the building does not exceed two thousand (2,000) square feet. 
(b)  A Class "B" builder's license shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the necessary demolition and wrecking work in connection with the work specified herein. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 8, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-73. - Class "C". 
(a)  A Class "C" builder's license shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of building or contracting for, or altering or adding to structural portions of buildings or structures or portions thereof of any residential building not larger than three thousand five hundred (3,500) square feet gross living area. 
(b)  A Class "C" builder's license shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the necessary demolition and wrecking work in connection with the work specified herein. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 9, 2-3-87) 
Secs. 30-74-30-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLUMBER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 30-81. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following words and phrases used herein are defined to have the following meaning. 
    Master plumber. A "master plumber" is any person skilled in the planning, superintending and practical installation of plumbing and is familiar with the laws, rules and regulations governing the same, who is engaged in this business as owner or supervisor. 
    Plumbing. "Plumbing" is the installing, alteration and repairing of all pipes, faucets, tanks, valves and other fixtures by and through which supply or waste water or sewage is used or carried, plumbing fixtures and fixture traps and the soil, waste and vent pipes with their devices, appurtenances and connections, through which waste sewage and air are carried within or adjacent to a building or structure. 
(Code 1963, § 26-19) 
Sec. 30-82. - Class "A" master. 
    A plumber's license class "A" master shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to install all sanitary plumbing and potable water supply piping for which a permit is required under the provisions of this Code, other city ordinances and state laws governing the same. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
State Law reference- Master plumber's license, C. R. S. § 12-58-105. 
Secs. 30-83-30-85. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1987-03, §§ 10-12, adopted Feb. 3, 1987, repealed §§ 30-83-30-85. Such sections had pertained to master plumber's license, Class B; journeyman plumber's license, Class C; and bond requirements for plumbing contractors. Former §§ 30-83 and 30-84 were derived from Ord. No. 555, § 1, adopted Feb. 20, 1973, and § 30-85 was derived from Ord. No. 385, § 3, adopted June 2, 1964. 
Sec. 30-86. - Employment of plumber's helpers. 
    No more than two (2) unlicensed plumber's helpers may be employed for each licensed master or journeyman license holder, without the prior consent of the building official. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Secs. 30-87-30-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - STEAM HEATING LICENSE 

Sec. 30-96. - Class "A." 
    A steam heating license class "A" shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to install high and low pressure steam and hot water heating systems, processing pipes and similar commercial hot water and water vapor systems, and heating or steam power systems, where the installation of such requires a permit under the provisions of this Code or other city ordinances governing the same. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-97. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Formerly, § 30-97 had pertained to a Class B steam heating license as derived from Ord. No. 555, § 1, adopted Feb. 20, 1973. Such section was repealed by Ord. No. 1987-03, § 13, adopted Feb. 3, 1987. 
Sec. 30-98. - Employment of unlicensed helpers. 
(a)  No persons who engage in the installation of heating work shall employ unlicensed helpers unless under the direct supervisions of a licensed class "A" license holder. 
(b)  No more than two (2) unlicensed plumber's helpers may be employed for each licensed master or journeyman license holder without the prior consent of the building official. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 14, 2-3-87) 
Secs. 30-99-30-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - ELECTRICIAN'S LICENSE 

Sec. 30-111. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases used herein are defined to have the following meaning. 
    Electrical contractor. An "electrical contractor" means any person, firm, copartnership, corporation, association or combination thereof that undertakes or offers to undertake for another the planning, laying out, supervising and installing or the making of additions, alterations and repairs in the installation of wiring apparatus and equipment for electric light, heat and power. 
    License, licensed. The term "license" and "licensed" shall be synonymous with the terms "registration" and "registered" throughout this article, and any amendments thereto relative to electricians and/or electrical contractors shall not apply to electrical registrants. 
    Master electrician. A "master electrician" means a person having the necessary qualifications, training, experience and technical knowledge to properly plan, lay out and supervise the installation and repair of wiring apparatus and equipment for electric light, heat and power, and other purposes in accordance with standard rules and regulations, such as the National Electrical Code adopted by this chapter. 
(Code 1963, § 11B-19; Ord. No. 663, § 4, 1-20-76) 
Sec. 30-112. - Class "A" master. 
    An electrical registration class "A" master shall entitle the registrant to contract for or do the work of installing electrical wiring or any electrical apparatus where such installation requires the issuance of a permit under the provisions of this Code or other city ordinances governing the same in any and all group classifications listed in the Uniform Building Code adopted in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 4, 1-20-76) 
State Law reference- Master electrician's license, C. R. S. § 12-23-105. 
Secs. 30-113, 30-114. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1987-03, §§ 15, 16, adopted Feb. 3, 1987, repealed §§ 30-113 and 30-114 which pertained to Class B, master and Class C, journeyman electrical registrations. Prior to repeal, such sections had been derived from Ord. No. 663, § 4, adopted Jan. 20, 1976. 
Sec. 30-115. - Unregistered helpers-Employment generally. 
    No persons who engage in the installation of electrical wiring or apparatus shall employ unregistered helpers unless under the direct supervision of a Class "A" registered electrician. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 4, 1-20-76; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 17, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-116. - Same-Number employed. 
    Not more than two (2) unregistered electrician's helpers may be employed per each master or journeyman electrician registration holder without the prior consent of the building official. 
(Ord. No. 663, § 4, 1-20-76) 
Editor's note- It should be noted that Ord. No. 1987-03, § 16 adopted Feb. 3, 1987, repealed the Class C journeyman electrical registrant provisions (§ 30-114), and § 17 of such ordinance provides as set forth in § 30-115 with regard to employment and supervision of unregistered helpers. 
Secs. 30-117-30-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - MISCELLANEOUS LICENSES AND BONDS 

Sec. 30-126. - Appliance license. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "appliance" shall refer to any appliance whose installation would be subject to the regulations set out in the Uniform Building Code, this chapter and the Uniform Plumbing Code. 
(b)  An appliance license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to install appliances as defined herein where the installation of such requires a permit under this Code or other city ordinances governing the same. 
(c)  Holders of plumbing, electrical, warm air heating, steam heating and gas fitting licenses are not required to hold licenses to install domestic appliances. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-127. - Gas fitter's license. 
(a)  A gas fitter's license shall entitle the individual holder thereof to install all gas piping, fittings, controls, burners and venting on all gas fired, oil fired and liquefied petroleum fired appliances in accordance with the plumbing code and the Uniform Building Code. 
(b)  Holders of Class "A" plumber's licenses, Class "A" steam-heating licenses, or warm-air heating and ventilating licenses, may do the work of a gas fitting license. 
(c)  No person may install gas piping, fitting, controls, burners or venting on gas fired, oil fired and liquefied petroleum fired appliances unless he is specifically licensed as mentioned under this section. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 18, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-128. - Masonry license. 
(a)  A masonry license shall entitle the individual license holder thereof to erect, construct, alter or demolish chimneys, fireplaces, walls, pilasters and other work on a building composed of masonry units in accordance with chapters 24, 28 and 37 of the Uniform Building Code adopted by this chapter. 
(b)  Holders of builder's licenses class "A," "B" or "C" need not have a masonry license to do the work referred to under this section. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-129. - Concrete and form license. 
(a)  A concrete and form license shall entitle the individual holder thereof to contract for and install forms for concrete products and to pour and finish concrete products and to mix concrete products subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  All concrete work shall be done in accordance with the Uniform Building Code adopted by this chapter. 
(2)  All concrete and form work on types I, II, III, IV and V structures of over one thousand (1,000) square feet shall be under the supervision of a holder of a builder's license class "A," "B" or "C." 
(b)  Holders of a class "A," "B" or "C" builder's license need not have a concrete and form license to do the work referred to under this section. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 19, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-130. - Warm air heating and ventilation license. 
    A warm air heating and ventilating license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and install warm air heating and ventilation and their appurtenances. All work shall be performed only in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code. All electrical work shall be performed by a holder of a Class "A" electrical license. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 20, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-131. - House and building mover's license. 
    The holder of a house and building mover's license shall be permitted to contract for and engage in moving of structures within, into and out of the city limits subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  New structural alterations, additions and foundation work are to be done by the holder of a builder's license class "A," "B" or "C." 
(2)  Plumbing work necessary in the moving and relocating of the structure is to be done by the holder of a Class "A" plumbing license. 
(3)  Electrical work necessary in the moving and relocating of the structure is to be done by the holder of a class "A" electrical license. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 21, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-132. - Wrecker's license. 
    A wrecker's license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract and engage in the demolition of existing structures. All work connected with wrecking and demolishing structures shall be done in accordance with the Uniform Building Code adopted by this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 22, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-133. - Excavating license. 
(a)  An excavating license shall entitle the holder thereof to contract for and to do the work of cutting into public rights-of-way and excavating into the public rights-of-way and on private property within the city. The holder of an excavating license shall be subject to the provisions of the section controlling excavations of the Uniform Building Code. 
(b)  The holders of a license under any other section of this chapter shall not be required to hold a license under this section, but shall be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73; Ord. No. 1987-03, § 23, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-134. - Special contractor's license. 
    A special contractor's license shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of a particular trade or job connected with the building industry excluding the enumerated licenses in this division. Such special contractor's license shall be limited to the trade or particular kind of work specified in such license and such other work as may be incidental thereto. 
(Ord. No. 555, § 1, 2-20-73) 
Sec. 30-135. - Sign contractor's license. 
    A sign contractor's license shall entitle the licensee to contract for and to do the work of installing signs. The holder of a sign contractor's license shall be subject to the provisions of the sign code of the City of Lafayette, Colorado, and any and all other applicable codes. 
(Ord. No. 1987-03, § 24, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-136. - Satellite dish antenna installer's license. 
    A satellite dish antenna installer's license entitles the licensee to contract for and to do the work of installing satellite dish antennas. 
(Ord. No. 1987-03, § 25, 2-3-87) 
Sec. 30-137. - Construction in public rights-of-way easements; bonding. 
(a)  Before any permit required by this article shall be issued to an applicant, the applicant shall file with the public works director a bond or letter of credit in favor of the city in an amount equal to the total cost of construction, including labor and materials, or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), whichever is greater. The bond or letter of credit shall be executed by the applicant as principal and by at least one (1) surety upon whom service of process may be had in the state. The bond or letter of credit shall be conditioned upon the applicant fully complying with all provisions of the Code, and its rules and regulations, and upon payment of all judgments and costs rendered against the applicant for any material violation of the Code or state statutes that may be recovered against the applicant by any person for damages arising out of any negligent or wrongful acts of the applicant in the performance of work done pursuant to the permit. The city may bring an action on the bond or letter of credit on its own behalf or on behalf of any person so aggrieved as beneficiary. The bond or letter of credit must be approved by the public works director as to form and as to the responsibility of the surety thereon prior to the issuance of the permit. However, the public works director may waive the requirements of any such bond or letter of credit or may permit the applicant to post a bond without surety thereon upon finding that the applicant has financial stability and assets located in the state to satisfy any claims intended to be protected against the security required by this section. 
(b)  A letter of responsibility will be accepted in lieu of a performance bond or letter of credit from all public utilities and all franchised entities operating within the city. 
(c)  The performance bond, letter of credit or letter of responsibility shall remain in force and effect for a minimum of two (2) years after completion and acceptance of the street cut, excavation or lane closure. The performance bond, letter of credit or letter of responsibility may be required to remain in full force and effect for up to three (3) years upon the public works director's determination that such is necessary given factors which include, but are not limited to, the work's scope, duration and or delays in performance. 
(Ord. No. 1988-03, § 1, 4-5-88; Ord. No. 2018-01, § 1, 1-16-18) 
Secs. 30-138-30-145. - Reserved.

Sec. 30-164. - Inspection fees-Definitions. 
    For the purposes of sections 30-164-30-168, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Building: Any structure without reference to use or occupancy for which a building permit is required by the ordinances and codes of the City of Lafayette, Colorado. 
    Contractor: Any person, firm, partnership, joint venture or corporation, required to obtain a building permit pursuant to the ordinances and codes of the City of Lafayette, Colorado. 
    Electrical inspector: The official charged with the administration and enforcement of the National Electric Code as adopted by the City of Lafayette, Colorado, or his duly authorized representative. 
    Floor area: The area included within the surrounding exterior walls of a building or portion thereof, measured from the inside of all exterior walls, excluding parking garages, public hallways and public stairwells. 
(Ord. No. 880, § 1, 7-1-80)

    The permit fees for mechanical work shall be set forth pursuant to resolution of the City Council. 
(b)  The International Fuel Gas Code, 2015 edition, Section 106.5.2, is hereby amended to read as follows: 
    The permit fees for mechanical work shall be set forth pursuant to resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 1999-4, § 1, 2-2-99; Ord. No. 2002-17, § 15, 7-16-02; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 24, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 2005-24, § 15, 8-16-05; Ord. No. 2008-08, § 15, 8-19-08; Ord. No. 2011-19, § 9, 6-7-11; Ord. No. 2013-32, § 9, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 2016-37, § 9, 12-6-16)

ARTICLE XI. - RESIDENTIAL GROWTH MANAGEMENT[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2013-11, adopted May 21, 2013, amended art. XI in its entirety to read as herein set out. See Code Comparative Table for amendatory history. 

Sec. 30-269. - Findings. 
    The city council of the City of Lafayette, Colorado, finds that there is substantial evidence from comprehensive plan and long range planning studies that excessively rapid community growth coupled with substantial demand for construction of new dwelling units within the city has the potential to strain the capacities of public facilities and services. Specifically, the city council finds that demand for construction of new dwelling units may, in the short term, exceed: 
(1)  The ability of the city to deliver and treat additional water; 
(2)  The ability of the city to treat sewage safely within acceptable federal and state standards; 
(3)  The ability of the city to acquire and store sufficient additional raw water resources to meet all seasonal water needs of the existing community when added to increased demands from additional dwelling units. 
    The city council further finds from a review of the comprehensive plan and long range planning studies and budget documents of the city, and from a review of the city's capital programs and its plans to expand the city's existing water treatment and wastewater treatment plants, that sound management of the city's fiscal condition and management of the city's future growth mandate a plan for growth management. 
    The city council further finds that it has enacted certain review criteria pertaining to all residential planned unit developments codified in section 26-18-5 of this Code, and that proper application of said criteria may require management of the city's future growth. 
    The city council further finds that the adoption of Article X, Section 20 of the Colorado Constitution mandates a steady and substantially uniform growth from year to year, in order to protect the city's ability to provide municipal services to its existing and future citizens. 
    On November 7, 1995, the city's electors adopted an amendment to the city's Charter, finding that it is the will of the people of Lafayette to maintain the economic, social and environmental advantages of having a small town character; that it is the will of the people of Lafayette to prevent actions that will increase city operating and capital construction expenses that would necessitate a tax increase or increases for these purposes; and determining that a cap of two hundred (200) dwelling units per year, allowing for approximately three (3) percent annual growth in the existing population of Lafayette, is an appropriate level of growth to preserve and maintain the economic, social and environmental advantages of having a small town character and preserving the quality of services provided by the city to its citizens and the quality of life enjoyed by those citizens. The city council of the City of Lafayette hereby adopts these findings by the city's electors. 
    The city council further finds that on November 7, 2000, the city's electors adopted an amendment to the Charter stating that (i) the approximately twelve-acre parcel located in the SE quarter of Section 35, Township 1 North, Range 69 West, north of the intersection of Brooks Avenue and Dounce Street, shall be exempt from the limitations of section 6.10 of the Charter so long as it is developed for residential purposes by the Boulder County Housing authority or its agent, and (ii) that dwelling units located within mixed use building complexes within the Urban Renewal Area - Lafayette Old Town, as that area existed as of January 1, 2000, shall also be exempt from the limitations of section 6.10 of the Charter. 
    The city council further finds that on November 6, 2001, the city's electors adopted an amendment to the Charter stating that (i) in addition to the other dwelling units authorized by section 6.10 of the Charter, the city council may authorize the construction of up to fifty (50) permanently affordable dwelling units per year, and (ii) "permanently affordable dwelling unit" shall mean a dwelling unit that is deed restricted for perpetuity to permit persons whose household income is less than or equal to eighty (80) percent of the then-current Boulder County area median income, as may be adjusted from time to time, to qualify to purchase or rent the dwelling unit, and (iii) unissued building permits for permanently affordable dwelling units may not be carried forward from year to year, but the council may approve the issuance of building permits for more than fifty (50) permanently affordable dwelling units in a single calendar year if the number of building permits for permanently affordable dwelling units approved in the following year is reduced by an equal amount. 
    The city council further finds that on November 6, 2012, the city's electors adopted an amendment to the Charter stating that the total number of new dwelling units between January 1, 2013, and January 1, 2019, shall not exceed one thousand two hundred (1,200), and that city council shall adopt an ordinance setting out criteria it will utilize in determining the annual number of new dwelling units that are allowed to be built in any such year, which will address allocation of permits for new dwelling units over the entire six-year period. In addition, this Charter amendment stated that those developments within the city for which city council, prior to November 6, 2012, had determined and assigned by resolution a priority classification and building permit allocation pursuant to the city's residential growth management program that was in place prior to November 6, 2012, shall be exempt from the above limitation and may receive such building permits without regard to the calendar year for which their permits were allocated, but only to the extent that such properties are developed substantially in compliance with the approved preliminary plan upon which their allocations are based, and that those properties within the city that, prior to November 6, 2012, were eligible to be in the category of "otherwise entitled to priority," pursuant to the city's residential growth management program, by reason of commitments made by the city that existed prior to May 23, 1995, with respect to annexation, shall be exempt from the above limitation. 
    The city council further finds that section 6.10 of the Charter is not self-executing, and it is therefore necessary to adopt, by ordinance, certain policies and procedures as set forth in this article, to implement the Charter requirements and to administer the issuance of residential building permits in accordance with the Charter's requirements. 
    Based on its review and its knowledge of future growth plans of the city, the city budget and capital programs, various comprehensive plan and long range planning studies, reports from its water engineers and attorneys, and in consideration of the review criteria applicable to residential P.U.D.s, and in order to comply with the requirements of section 6.10 of the Charter, the city council of the City of Lafayette finds that it is essential to the public health, safety and welfare of all the residents and property owners within the city, both present and future, and it is further essential in order to maintain and promote orderly and planned growth, that a reasonable balance be maintained between the construction of additional buildings creating new demands on city services and facilities and the ability of the city to expand its services and facilities. In order to achieve such a balance, the city council finds that the issuance of building permits, which controls all new construction, should be managed in accordance with the provisions set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1993-25, § 1, 8-3-93; Ord. No. 1995-26, § 1, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 2002-11, § 1, 5-21-02; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 5-21-13) 
Sec. 30-270. - Definitions. 
    City means the City of Lafayette, Colorado. 
    Development (when used as a noun and when the context requires) means any proposed or approved residential project, including residential subdivisions and planned unit developments, that are intended to increase the number of dwelling units within the city. 
    Development's annual allocation means the maximum number of building permits for new nonexempt dwelling units, as established or modified by city council on an annual basis as provided herein, that may be issued to or on behalf of any nonexempt development in any particular calendar year. 
    Development's annual allocation schedule means the multi-year (if necessary) projection, as established or modified by city council as provided herein, of a particular development's annual allocations that will accommodate full build-out of the development. 
    Dwelling unit means a structure or portion of a structure designed for occupancy as a residence by a single-family or a single housekeeping unit. 
    Exempt dwelling unit means any dwelling unit: 
(i)  In a single-family residence, a duplex, a triplex or a four-plex constructed on a lot that existed pursuant to a recorded plat, prior to May 23, 1995, or on a lot that results from the subdivision of any lot that existed pursuant to a recorded plat, prior to May 23, 1995; or 
(ii)  Constructed on the approximately twelve-acre parcel located in the SE quarter of Section 35, Township 1 North, Range 69 West, north of the intersection of Brooks Avenue and Dounce Street, so long as said parcel is developed for residential purposes by the Boulder County Housing authority or its agent; or 
(iii)  Constructed within mixed use building complexes within the Urban Renewal Area - Lafayette Old Town, as that area existed as of January 1, 2000; or 
(iv)  Constructed within any developments within the city for which city council, prior to November 6, 2012, had determined and assigned by resolution a priority classification and building permit allocation pursuant to the city's residential growth management program that was in place prior to November 6, 2012, but only to the extent that such properties are developed substantially in compliance with the approved preliminary plan upon which their allocations are based; or 
(v)  Constructed on those properties within the city that, prior to November 6, 2012, were eligible to be in the category of "otherwise entitled to priority," pursuant to the city's residential growth management program, by reason of commitments made by the city that existed prior to May 23, 1995, with respect to annexation. 
    Nonexempt dwelling unit means any new dwelling unit that is not an exempt dwelling unit or a permanently affordable dwelling unit. 
    Nonexempt dwelling unit maximum means the number of nonexempt dwelling units authorized by the city council for construction during the current year, in accordance with subsection 30-271(b). 
    Permanently affordable dwelling unit means a dwelling unit that is deed restricted for perpetuity to permit persons whose household income is less than or equal to eighty (80) percent of the then-current Boulder County area median income, as may be adjusted from time to time, to qualify to purchase or rent the dwelling unit. 
    Permanently affordable dwelling unit maximum means the number of permanently affordable dwelling units, if any, authorized by the city council for construction during the current year, in accordance with subsection 30-271(c). 
(Ord. No. 1993-25, § 1, 8-3-93; Ord. No. 1995-26, § 2, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 1996-4, § 1, 2-20-96; Ord. No. 2002-11, § 2, 5-21-02; Ord. No. 2011-33, § 14, 9-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 5-21-13) 
Sec. 30-271. - Establishment of dwelling unit maximum. 
(a)  By January 31 of the first year of each six-year growth management cycle, as referenced in section 6.10 of the Charter, city council shall adopt a resolution designating the number of building permits for nonexempt dwelling units that will be made available to allocate to nonexempt developments during the first half of the six-year cycle, with the balance of the total number of building permits allowed by section 6.10 of the Charter for that six-year cycle being reserved for allocation to nonexempt developments during the second half of the cycle (the "cycle distribution resolution"). For the purposes of the cycle distribution resolution, an allocation to a nonexempt development shall be deemed to occur upon approval of the development's annual allocation schedule and shall consist of the total number of building permits assigned to the developer for the entire period of the schedule. 
(b)  By January 31 of each year city council shall adopt a resolution that will establish the nonexempt dwelling unit maximum for the current year and the anticipated nonexempt dwelling unit maximum for the following year (the "annual resolution"). In adopting each annual resolution, the city council shall take into consideration each of the following: 
(1)  The water and sewer service capability of the city available for commercial and industrial development. 
(2)  The water and sanitary sewer service capability of the city available for special and unanticipated needs of the city. 
(3)  The anticipated pace of dwelling construction of all nonexempt units, as well as prior commitments that the city has made to issue building permits, such as development agreements, vesting agreements or permanently affordable housing project authorized by this section. 
(4)  The number of dwelling units which can be served with utilities during the applicable calendar years. 
(5)  The provisions of section 6.10 of the Charter, all of the factors listed in section 30-269 of the Lafayette Code of Ordinances, the findings stated in this article, the review criteria applicable to residential P.U.D.s set out in section 26-18-5 of the Lafayette Code of Ordinances, the needs of the community, and the city's ability to service additional growth. 
(c)  The city council may, by resolution at any time, authorize the issuance of building permits for the construction of up to fifty (50) permanently affordable dwelling units per year, which authorization shall be the permanently affordable dwelling unit maximum for the current year. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the council may approve the issuance of building permits for more than fifty (50) permanently affordable dwelling units in a single calendar year if the number of any building permits for permanently affordable dwelling units authorized for issuance in the following year is reduced by an equal amount. 
(d)  At any time when the city council shall find that the actual pace of development within the city requires, in the best interests of the city, an adjustment to the annual resolution's nonexempt dwelling unit maximum, the city council may, by resolution, adjust any or all of said nonexempt dwelling unit maximums for the current year, so long as the total number does not exceed the number authorized by the cycle distribution resolution. In making such an adjustment, the city council shall consider all of the criteria set forth in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(e)  At any time when the city council shall find that an adjustment to the cycle distribution resolution is in the best interest of the city, the city council may amend the cycle distribution resolution to adjust the number of building permits available for allocation during the first half or the second half of the six-year growth management cycle, provided that the total number of dwelling unit allocations may not exceed the number authorized by the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1993-25, § 1, 8-3-93; Ord. No. 1995-26, § 3, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 2002-11, §§ 3, 4, 5-21-02; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 5-21-13) 
Sec. 30-272. - Conditions for residential building permit issuance. 
(a)  No building permits for structures containing new, nonexempt or permanently affordable dwelling units, which will require new or enhanced city utility services, shall be issued to permit the construction of dwelling units in excess of the nonexempt dwelling unit maximum, or the permanently affordable dwelling unit maximum, respectively, in effect for the current calendar year. 
(b)  At any time after approval of a sketch plan for a development, but before that development receives final plat approval, the city council shall, by resolution, determine whether said development is, or is not, exempt from the growth management limitations of section 6.10 of the Charter. Any development that is not found to be exempt from the limitations of section 6.10 of the Charter ("nonexempt development") will receive building permits for new dwelling units only upon compliance with the process and procedures as provided in this article. 
(c)  Residential building permits for permanently affordable dwelling units will be issued on a first-come, first-served basis, permitting the construction of permanently affordable dwelling units up to the permanently affordable dwelling unit maximum authorized under the provisions of subsection 30-271(c) for any given calendar year. After the permanently affordable dwelling unit maximum has been reached, residential building permit applications for permanently affordable dwelling units will be accepted and placed on a waiting list. When residential building permit issuance for permanently affordable dwelling units is resumed, those applications on the waiting list will be processed in the order in which they were received, and prior to the processing of any new applications. 
(d)  Residential building permits for nonexempt dwelling units will be issued on a first-come, first-served basis, but only up to the amount of a development's annual allocation, as determined below, authorizing the construction of nonexempt dwelling units up to the nonexempt dwelling unit maximum authorized for any given calendar year: 
(1)  Each proposed nonexempt development shall submit its projected annual allocation requirements for the issuance of dwelling unit permits with the preliminary plan submittal. The preliminary plan for such development shall not be approved if the total allocation requirement for build-out of the development cannot be fulfilled under the city's growth management limitation, as established by this article. If such total allocation requirements can be fulfilled, the planning director will assign to the development in conjunction with preliminary plan approval a proposed development's annual allocation and schedule for dwelling unit building permits in sufficient numbers to achieve the proposed build-out of the development. The proposed development annual allocation and schedule shall be subject to approval by city council in conjunction with the development's final plan; 
(2)  Beginning in the calendar year following the approval of a nonexempt development's final plan, and every year thereafter until build-out, each nonexempt development shall submit a "building permit status report", which may request a modification to development's annual allocation for the next calendar year. The building permit status report shall be in written form and shall be submitted to the planning director no sooner than December 1, and no later than December 15. In November, city staff shall send written notice to the affected developments advising the development of the requirement to provide a building permit status report. Such notice shall be by U.S. mail, and shall be addressed to the last address that the developer has on file with the city. The purpose of the building permit status report is to ensure that the pace of construction (by reference to the issuance of building permits for dwelling units) reasonable conforms to the schedule for the development's annual allocation. Each building permit status report shall include the following information: 
a.  The most current development's annual allocation schedule and the original development's annual allocation schedule as approved in conjunction with development's final plan; 
b.  The actual number of dwelling units for which building permits were issued within the nonexempt development, on a month-by-month basis for the current calendar year; 
c.  The number of dwelling unit allocations that are being requested, and are reasonably anticipated to be utilized in the next calendar year; 
d.  Any additional information necessary to justify the annual allocation number requested. 
(3)  The planning director shall take into account the information included in the building permit status report and shall recommend a development's annual allocation for each nonexempt development to city council as part of the next annual resolution. If a nonexempt development's actual permitted dwelling units are less than seventy (70) percent of its annual allocation for the preceding year, then the planning director may recommend that city council reduce the development's annual allocation to the actual number of dwelling units permitted in the development during the preceding year, plus twenty (20) percent of the actual number of dwelling units permitted during the preceding year. If a nonexempt development maximized, or came within ten (10) percent of maximizing, its annual allocation during the preceding year, then the planning director may recommend city council increase the development's annual allocation, if an increase has been requested by the developer. 
(4)  In the event that a nonexempt development's annual allocation is modified to a lesser number, the development will not lose its right to the total number of dwelling units necessary to build-out the development. However, the developer's annual allocation schedule shall be modified to reflect a reduction in future years of the same number, and the number of years for build-out to occur will be extended in order to accommodate the slower construction pace. If a nonexempt development's annual allocation is modified to a greater number, the annual allocation schedule shall be modified to reflect an increase in future years of the same number, and the number of years allowed for build-out will be shortened. 
(5)  In the event that a nonexempt development fails to timely submit a building permit status report, the development's annual allocation for the following year only shall be reduced to ten (10) percent of its annual allocation of the preceding year, and the developer's annual allocation schedule shall be modified accordingly. Once the development has built equaling the reduced allocation, the development may petition council to amend the annual resolution and reinstate the developments annual allocation, in full or in part, upon providing the building permit status report. City council may grant the petition, in full or in part, if city council, in its discretion, is satisfied that good cause has been established, and that sufficient allocations remain to fulfill other requests for allocations. 
    During any period after the nonexempt dwelling unit maximum has been reached, residential building permit applications for nonexempt dwelling units will be accepted and placed on a waiting list. When residential building permit issuance for nonexempt dwelling units has resumed those applications on the waiting list will be processed in the order in which they were received. 
(e)  If construction authorized by any building permit has not commenced within one hundred eighty (180) days after it is issued, the permit shall become void and may be reissued, by the city, but only on a first come, first served basis, up to the applicable dwelling unit maximum. 
(f)  In the event that applications for nonexempt dwelling unit building permits do not exceed the nonexempt dwelling unit maximum in a given calendar year, the authorized, but unissued permits for nonexempt dwelling units may be carried forward to the following year, subject to the one thousand two hundred (1,200) per six-year limitation. Any such unissued permits for nonexempt dwelling units cannot be carried forward beyond the six-year growth management cycle. 
(g)  Building permits issued in violation of this article shall be void. Nothing in this article shall alter or affect other requirements for compliance with all applicable zoning, subdivision and building regulations, codes, and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1993-25, § 1, 8-3-93; Ord. No. 1995-26, § 4, 11-27-95; Ord. No. 1996-4, § 2, 2-20-96; Ord. No. 2002-11, § 5, 5-21-02; Ord. No. 2011-33, § 14, 9-20-11; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 5-21-13; Ord. No. 2019-06, § 3, 2-19-2019) 
Secs. 30-273-30-289. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XIII. - WOOD-BURNING PROHIBITIONS[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1988-24, § 1, adopted Nov. 15, 1988, added provisions concerning wood-burning prohibitions designated as Art. XII, §§ 30-300-30-304. Such article has been redesignated as Art. XIII in order to avoid duplicative numeric article designations, see Art. XII, available service units. 

Sec. 30-300. - Definitions.
