ARTICLE III. - SENIOR SERVICES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 2011-33, adopted Sept. 20, 2011, recodified Ch. 50, Art. II, as Ch. 81, Art. III, and renumbered § 50-10 as § 81-50. Section 6 of said ordinance further provided for the addition of reserved §§ 81-37-81-49. 

Sec. 81-50. - Senior advisory board established. 
(a)  Established. There shall be and is hereby established a senior advisory board which shall have the primary responsibility of serving as an advisory group to city council with regard to the quality of life in the city for older adults, and to the provision of services for this age group. 
(b)  Membership. The board shall consist of seven (7) citizens of Lafayette, who shall be appointed by the city council. A city employee appointed by the city administrator shall serve as a nonvoting staff liaison to the board. 
(c)  Term. All appointments to the board shall be for a period of three (3) years. The board may recruit and recommend nominees to city council for appointment. Vacancies on the board shall be filled for the unexpired term by city council appointment as soon as possible. A member of the board shall not receive a salary or other compensation for services as a board member, but necessary traveling and subsistence expenses actually incurred may be paid from the general fund. City council may, upon recommendation of the board, appoint up to two (2) alternate members, which member(s) shall be called upon to serve and vote in the absence of a regular member(s), and the board may recommend any alternate member for appointment by council to a vacant position. Board members serve at the pleasure of city council. 
(d)  Powers and duties. The board shall: 
(1)  Adopt bylaws, rules and regulations for its guidance and government. 
(2)  Prepare and submit to city council a plan for the enhancement of the quality of life of older adults living in the city, and as necessary amend the plan. 
(3)  Review the annual senior services budget request. 
(4)  Monitor gifts of money which shall be segregated in the accounting records of the city or property or endowments as may be granted to and accepted for senior services purposes and to encourage grants, or gifts, in support of senior services. 
(5)  Adopt policies that provide for the provision of senior services. Such policies shall be effective upon adoption or at the time specified in the policy, unless and until city council disapproves of the policy. The senior advisory board shall promptly submit any adopted policy to city council for its review. 
(6)  Review the qualifications of all final candidates for the staff position directly administering senior services. 
(7)  Recommend to city council local legislation and policies that will encourage the inclusion of older adults in the community and support their needs. 
(Ord. No. 2006-40, § 1, 9-19-06; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 6, 2-1-11; Ord. No. 2011-33, § 5, 9-20-11)

ARTICLE II. - EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to establish an alternative pension plan or retirement system, C. R. S. § 24-54-101 et seq. 

Sec. 85-21. - Creation of retirement association. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. § 24-54-101 et seq., as amended, there is hereby established the "Lafayette Employees Retirement Association," for the purpose of establishing a retirement plan or system for the city's elected or appointed officers and its employees, excluding sworn ambulance and fire and commissioned police personnel. The Lafayette Employees Retirement Association may be referred to in this article as the "association." 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 1, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 85-22. - Purpose of association. 
    The association is being created for the purpose of establishing an alternative pension plan or retirement system as permitted by C.R.S. § 24-54-101 et seq., as an alternative to Lafayette's affiliation with the Public Employees' Retirement Association, established by C.R.S. § 24-51-101 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 2, 5-19-92) 
Sec. 85-23. - Membership. 
    The membership of the association may include all elected or appointed officers of the city, and the city's employees, as established by the retirement plan or plans (hereafter "retirement plan") adopted by the board of retirement created hereby. The retirement plan shall not apply to or include sworn ambulance and fire and commissioned police personnel. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 3, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 85-24. - Funds not subject to process. 
    Except for assignments for child support purposes as provided by Colorado statute, and except for writs of garnishment which are the result of a judgment taken for arrearages for child support or for child support debt, none of the monies, funds, annuities, individual accounts, or other benefits adopted by the association shall be assignable either in law or in equity or be subject to execution, levy, attachment, garnishment or other legal process. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 4, 5-19-92) 
Sec. 85-25. - Creation of board of retirement. 
    There is hereby created a board of retirement in whom is vested the general administration, management and responsibility for the proper operation of the association, and for making effective and construing the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 5, 5-19-92) 
Sec. 85-26. - Composition of board; compensation; term. 
    The board shall serve without pay and shall consist of five (5) members, as follows: 
(1)  City administrator, mayor, and city treasurer; 
(2)  Two (2) regular full-time employees, elected by said employees to serve overlapping four-year terms, with the initial employee receiving the lesser number of votes to serve a two-year term. An employee may be reelected to unlimited consecutive four-year terms. 
    The board of retirement may select ex officio (nonvoting) individuals for membership on the board. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 6, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 85-27. - Officers of the board. 
(a)  Chairman. The city treasurer shall act as chairman of the board. 
(b)  Treasurer. The city treasurer shall be ex officio treasurer of the board and the administrative officer of the association. The treasurer shall be bonded in an amount to be determined by the board. The cost of the bond shall be paid from the retirement plan; provided, however, if the bond of the treasurer required by the city is sufficient to meet the board's requirements, no additional bond shall be required of the treasurer. 
(c)  Secretary. The city clerk, or designee, shall act as secretary to the board. 
(d)  Legal advisor. The city attorney shall act as legal advisor to the board. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 7, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 85-28. - Meetings of the board. 
    The board shall hold meetings regularly, at least annually, and shall designate the time and place thereof. All meetings of the board shall be public, and notice thereof shall be given in accordance with applicable state or ordinance requirements. Unless the board shall otherwise determine at its first meeting in any calendar year, notice of board meetings shall be posted on the main door to the city council chambers, located in the Lafayette City Hall at 1290 S. Public Road, Lafayette, Colorado. Each member of the board, other than ex officio, shall be entitled to one (1) vote in the meetings of the board. 
    Three (3) members shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board, and a majority vote of the board shall be determinative of any issue before the board. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 8, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 85-29. - Powers of the board. 
    The board shall be vested with the following powers: 
(1)  The board shall have full and complete control and management of any retirement plan established by the board; 
(2)  The board shall determine what type of retirement plan in which to participate and shall select, on the basis of the most sound proposal, a plan based either on the purchase of an insured group plan of retirement annuities funded through a group carrier, or a noninsured trust retirement plan, or participation in the public employees' retirement association; 
(3)  The board shall hear and decide all applications for relief, pensions, annuities, retirement, or other benefits pursuant to the plan or system adopted. A record of such action and all other matters properly coming before said board shall be kept and preserved; 
(4)  The board may appoint such consultants, advisors, or other persons as it deems necessary to assist it in performing its duties of control and management of the retirement plan. The retirement plan shall be responsible for payment of any costs incurred thereby; 
(5)  The board shall have any other powers necessary for it to carry out its functions as established by this article, not inconsistent with or limited by state or federal statute. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 9, 5-19-92) 
Sec. 85-29.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2007-22, adopted July 3, 2007, deleted § 85-29.1, which pertained to equity investments by individual plan members, and derived from Ord. No. 1994-2, adopted April 4, 1994. 
Sec. 85-30. - Records and reports. 
    The secretary of the board shall keep, or cause to be kept, such data as shall be necessary to document actions of the board. The board shall render a report to the city council at least annually. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 10, 5-19-92; Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 85-31. - Interest of board members. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, no board member or any officer or employee of the association shall have any interest, direct or indirect, in the gains or profits of any investments made by the board. No board member, nor any entity with which the board member may have an interest, as owner, shareholder, employee, or otherwise, may engage in any contractual relationship with the association. No board member or other person connected with the board, directly or indirectly, for himself or as an agent or partner of others, shall borrow any of the funds or deposits of the association, or in any manner use the same, except to make such current and necessary payments as are authorized by the board; nor shall any board member, or other person connected with the board, become an endorser, surety or become, in any manner, an obligor for monies loaned or borrowed of the retirement plan. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 11, 5-19-92) 
Sec. 85-32. - Vacancies on the board. 
    In the event that any board member ceases to be qualified to serve on the board, the board shall declare that member's office vacated. If any vacancy so occurs, the vacancy shall be filled within ninety (90) days after the date of the vacancy for the unexpired term, in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 12, 5-19-92) 
Sec. 85-33. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board shall make all necessary rules and regulations for managing and discharging its duties (not inconsistent with statute or with the provisions of this article), for its own government and procedure in so doing, and for the preservation and protection of any fund or annuity contract. 
(Ord. No. 1992-10, § 13, 5-19-92) 
Chapter 86 - COLLECTIVE BARGAINING FOR FIREFIGHTERS 

Sec. 86-1. - Statement of policy. 
    The protection of the public health, safety and welfare demands that the city's firefighters or any employee organization not be allowed to strike or engage in any work stoppage, slowdown or mass absenteeism. This necessary prohibition imposed by the city does not, however, require the denial to firefighters the right to organize, the right to be represented by an employee organization of their choice, and the right to bargain collectively. It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to have a system of collective bargaining to establish a productive relationship between the city and its firefighters and to use such system to establish compensation, hours, and certain terms and conditions of the firefighter's employment as specified in this chapter. The city hereby adopts a system of independent fact finding with submission of certain unresolved issues to the registered electors of the city to resolve such issues. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-2. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires a different interpretation, the following terms shall have the following meaning: 
    American Arbitration Association means the American Arbitration Association or its successor organization. 
    City administrator shall mean the city administrator or the administrator's designated representatives. 
    Collective bargaining shall mean the performance of the mutual obligation of the city, through its designated representatives, and the firefighters' bargaining agent, to meet at reasonable times and places and negotiate in good faith with respect to compensation, hours, and certain terms and conditions of employment, as defined in this section. 
    Compensation shall mean wages, salaries, and any other monetary compensation paid to firefighters. 
    Employee organization shall mean an organization that admits firefighters employed by the city to membership and represents firefighters in collective bargaining and includes any person acting as an officer, representative or agent of such organization. 
    Final offer shall mean the written offer on unresolved issues that are subject to negotiation as set forth in this chapter, made latest in time by a party to the other party at least seven (7) days prior to the start of the independent fact finding impasse hearing. 
    Firefighter shall mean a paid employee of the city whose primary duties are directly involved with the provision of fire protection or firefighting services up to and including the rank of lieutenant, except that, for the purposes of this chapter, "Firefighter" does not include clerical personnel or reserve firefighters. 
    Firefighters' bargaining agent shall mean an employee organization chosen by the firefighters as set forth in this chapter to be the sole and exclusive representative of the firefighters for the purpose of collective bargaining. 
    Fringe benefits shall mean vacation leave; holidays; sick leave; bereavement leave; jury duty leave; leave for union activity; other paid or unpaid leave; the method for applying for and voting for leave; insurance (levels of contributions and levels of benefit); allowance for uniforms and equipment and the maintenance of uniforms and equipment; tuition allowance reimbursement; and any other financial or economic benefits granted to individual fire department employees. 
    Good faith shall mean an honest and sincere attempt to reach a mutually acceptable resolution of all issues in dispute through the bargaining process. However, the obligation to negotiate in good faith does not compel a party to agree to a proposal or require the making of a concession. 
    Hours shall mean the amount of working time in the work period and the notice and the time intervals regarding changes of shifts. 
    Impasse shall mean failure of the parties to reach agreement only with regard to compensation, hours, or terms and conditions of employment within the period of collective bargaining specified by this chapter. 
    Independent fact finding shall mean the investigation and hearing of issue(s) of impasse arising out collective bargaining, selection of an independent fact finder, submitting a report defining the issue(s) of impasse, analyzing and reporting the facts relating thereto, and making non-binding recommendation(s) on the final offers of the city or the firefighters' bargaining agent for the purpose of resolving the issue(s) of impasse in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-3. - Right to organize and bargain collectively. 
    Firefighters shall have the right to engage in collective bargaining with the city and to be represented by an employee organization in such negotiations in accordance with this chapter as to the following matters, which are set forth as follows: 
(1)  Compensation as defined in this chapter; 
(2)  Fringe benefits as defined in his chapter; 
(3)  Hours as defined in this chapter; 
(4)  Personal safety and health equipment; 
(5)  Procedures relating to labor/management cooperation and communications; 
(6)  Procedures and notice relating to the layoff and recall of firefighters, but not the decision of whether to layoff or recall firefighters; 
(7)  Procedures for promotions, rotations and transfer of firefighters, but not the decision of whether to promote, rotate or transfer firefighters; and 
(8)  Grievance procedures for allegations of violations of the collective bargaining agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-4. - Management rights retained by the city. 
(a)  The city reserves and retains solely and exclusively all of its constitutional, statutory, home rule charter, ordinance and common law rights, duties and responsibilities to manage the fire department, supervise all fire department employees, and to take all necessary actions to carry out the mission of the city and of the state during federal, state or local emergencies. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to alter the employment status of firefighters or limit the authority of the fire chief and/or the city administrator to exercise powers to discipline firefighters as authorized by the city's home rule charter and implemented through the Code and the employee handbook. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-5. - Selection and recognition of bargaining agent. 
(a)  The city hereby recognizes International Association of Fire Fighters, Local 4620 ("Local 4620"), as the firefighters' bargaining agent since it represents a majority of firefighters, and such recognition shall continue unless and until Local 4620 is removed as the firefighters' bargaining agent as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Questions concerning the selection or removal of a bargaining agent may be raised by petition of any firefighter, group of firefighters or employee organization representing or wishing to represent the firefighters, but only if such petition is signed by at least fifty (50) percent of the firefighters. Such a petition may be submitted at any time to the American Arbitration Association provided that in the event there is a bargaining agent then certified or recognized by the city, no petition may be filed within twelve (12) months of the bargaining agent's certification or recognition; and further that no petition may be filed during the term of an existing agreement, except during the period from January 1 to January 31 of the final year of such agreement. 
(c)  When a petition is filed concerning the selection or removal of a bargaining agent, the American Arbitration Association shall promptly send the petition to the fire department for determination of whether it contains the requisite number of signatures. The fire chief shall promptly make that determination and notify the American Arbitration Association of its conclusion. If the petition has the requisite number of signatures, the American Arbitration Association shall determine the question of selection or removal of any bargaining agent by taking a secret ballot of firefighters and certifying in writing the results thereof to the city and the person, persons and employee organizations involved. The secret ballot election shall be conducted not less than fifteen (15) days, and not more than thirty (30) days, from the date of filing the petition. The American Arbitration Association shall certify the results of the above-described election within three (3) days of the close of the polls. The cost of running the election shall be borne equally by each organization on the ballot. Under no circumstances shall the city be responsible for any of the costs of such an election. 
(d)  The employee organization selected by the majority of the firefighters voting in an election conducted pursuant to subsection (c) of this section shall be recognized by the city as the sole and exclusive bargaining agent for all firefighters unless and until the American Arbitration Association certifies a different organization, in accordance with the rules and procedures set forth in this section. 
(e)  The election procedure shall follow the rules established by the American Arbitration Association. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-6. - Obligation to engage in collective bargaining. 
(a)  The city administrator and the firefighters' bargaining agent shall have the duty to engage in collective bargaining, and the obligation to bargain in good faith. 
(b)  In order to begin the collective bargaining process under subsections (c) and (d) of this section, it is the obligation of the bargaining agent to serve written notice of request for collective bargaining on the city no later than sixty (60) days prior to the commencement of collective bargaining. 
(c)  The initial collective bargaining negotiations must commence upon the effective date of this chapter. Initial negotiations shall conclude thirty (30) days after the commencement of such negotiations. 
(d)  With the exception of the initial collective bargaining negotiations, collective bargaining shall commence in the final year of a collective bargaining agreement no later than April 1 and conclude thirty (30) days after the commencement of such negotiations. 
(e)  All time limits for action contained in this chapter, other than the times for requesting and commencing bargaining set forth in this section, may be waived by mutual consent of the parties. 
(f)  The city shall not negotiate as to matters controlled by any federal or state constitutional provision, law, rule, regulation, or the city's Home Rule Charter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-7. - Unresolved issues submitted to independent fact finding. 
    In the event that the firefighters' bargaining agent and the city are unable, within thirty (30) days from and including the date of their first meeting, to reach mutually acceptable terms as to matters subject to negotiation, final offers on any or all such unresolved issues may be submitted by either or both parties to an independent fact finder. The obligation of the parties to bargain in good faith shall continue after submission of unresolved issues to an independent fact finder. Any or all issues, which are unresolved between the firefighters' bargaining agent and the city, may be resolved by the parties at any time. In the event the firefighters' bargaining agent and the city are able to reach agreement upon any or all issues prior to the receipt of the decision of the independent fact finder, then the independent fact finder shall make no decision on such issue or issues. 
(Ord. No. 2106-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-8. - Independent fact finder selection. 
(a)  Within seven (7) days after the expiration of the thirty-day negotiation time period set forth in this chapter, either the firefighters' bargaining agent or the city shall notify the American Arbitration Association that an independent fact finder is required. The parties shall request that the American Arbitration Association submit simultaneously to each side an identical list of seven (7) persons qualified to serve as an independent fact finder within seven (7) days after the notification. 
(b)  In order to be qualified as an independent fact finder, a person must be a member of the National Academy of Arbitrators or the American Arbitration Association panel of labor arbitrators. Any person whose only experience is as a hearing officer in any civil or career service system shall not be qualified. 
(c)  Within seven (7) days from the service of the list on the parties, the parties shall alternately strike one (1) name from the list until one (1) individual is selected, who shall be appointed as the independent fact finder. 
(d)  Upon appointment, the independent fact finder shall sign an oath to uphold the terms of this chapter. 
(e)  Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the parties from agreeing to an independent fact finder. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-9. - Hearings. 
(a)  The independent fact finder shall call a hearing to begin within twenty-five (25) days of notification of selection, and shall give at least ten (10) days' notice in writing to the firefighters' bargaining agent and the city of the time and place of such hearing. The hearing shall be informal, and the rules of evidence prevailing in judicial proceedings shall not be binding. 
(b)  All oral or documentary evidence and other data deemed competent and relevant by the independent fact finder shall be received in evidence. The independent fact finder shall have the power to administer oaths and to require by subpoena the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of books, records and other evidence relating to or pertinent to the issues presented for determination. 
(c)  The hearing conducted by the independent fact finder shall be concluded within seven (7) days of the time of commencement. Within seven (7) days following the conclusion of the hearing, the parties may, if they deem necessary, submit written briefs to the independent fact finder. 
(d)  Within ten (10) days of receipt of such briefs, or within seventeen (17) days after the conclusion of the hearing if no post-hearing briefs are filed, the independent fact finder shall make written findings and conclusions setting forth the basis of the independent fact finder's decision on the issues presented, a copy of which shall be delivered on the same date and in the same manner to the firefighters' bargaining agent and the city. 
(e)  In the event the firefighters' bargaining agent and/or the city reject any or all of the independent fact finders decision(s) they may submit the unresolved issue(s) of impasse to an election as set forth in this chapter. 
(f)  Issue(s) of impasse not submitted to an election shall be deemed resolved by the decision of the independent fact finder, and the parties shall both be obligated to abide by, and give effect to that decision. 
(g)  By mutual agreement of the parties and the independent fact finder, the time frames in this section may be extended. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-10. - Required factors that shall be considered by the independent fact finder. 
    The independent fact finder shall conduct the hearing and render his or her decision(s) with due consideration of the need for a prompt, peaceful and just settlement of all unresolved issues between the involved firefighters' bargaining agent and the city. The independent fact finder's written findings and conclusions shall be reached only after consideration of the parties' final offers as to the issues of impasse and all of the following factors: 
(a)  The interests and welfare of the residents of the city; 
(b)  The city's finances; 
(c)  The lawful authority of the city; 
(d)  Stipulations of the parties; 
(e)  Comparison of what other fire service employees performing comparable services, for comparable public employers in comparable communities receive regarding the negotiable matters set forth in this chapter; 
(f)  Any claims of failure of a party to bargain in good faith as required in this chapter; and 
(g)  Other usual and customary standards recognized in the resolution of interest disputes. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-11. - Final offer procedure. 
    The city and the firefighters' bargaining agent shall submit final offers, as set forth in the definitions section of this chapter to the independent fact finder on each issue of impasse that is to be decided by the independent fact finder. The decision of the independent fact finder on each issue of impasse shall be the final offer of the city or the final offer of the firefighters' bargaining agent. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-12. - The independent fact finder's decision. 
    The decision(s) of the independent fact finder is/are not binding on the firefighters' bargaining agent or the city. Nothing herein shall prohibit the parties from agreeing to terms different from the decision of the independent fact finder, as long as such agreements are made within fourteen (14) days after receipt of the independent fact finder's decision. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-13. - Fees and expenses of independent fact finding. 
    The parties shall equally bear all necessary fees and expenses incurred in the course of the independent fact finding process (excluding all fees and expenses incurred by either party in the preparation or presentation of its case). 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-14. - Unresolved issues submitted at election. 
(a)  Upon the request of the firefighters' bargaining agent, or the city, made within thirty (30) days after receipt of the independent fact finder's decision, and after expiration of the parties additional fourteen-day negotiation period, the final offers of the firefighters' bargaining agent, or the city, on the issue(s) of impasse remaining unresolved may each be submitted as alternative single measure to a vote of the city's registered electors at a regular municipal election, or at a special municipal election held in conjunction with the state's November general election, whichever is earliest in time. 
(b)  The format and wording of the ballot question (ballot title) shall be framed to accurately reflect the final offers of the firefighters' bargaining agent and the city as presented to the independent fact finder. 
(c)  The registered electors shall by the majority of those voting select either the final offer of the firefighters' bargaining agent or final offer of the city as presented to the independent fact finder. 
(d)  Issues agreed to during the fourteen-day period described in subsection (a) of this section shall not be included in the final offer of the firefighters' bargaining agent or final offer of the city. 
(e)  The cost of the election shall be borne by the firefighters bargaining agent or the city, whichever refuses to accept the recommendations of the independent fact finder. 
(f)  If both the firefighter's bargaining agent and the city refuse, the election costs shall be borne equally by the firefighter's bargaining agent and the city. In such event, the firefighter's bargaining agent shall pay only its proportionate share of the election expenses that are related to resolving the impasse. 
(g)  In the event that issue(s) unrelated to the unresolved issue(s) of impasse are also to be decided upon in any election then the firefighter's bargaining agent shall pay only its proportionate share of the election expenses that are related to resolving the issue(s) of impasse. 
(h)  Any prorating of cost under this section shall be on the basis of the number of issues, questions, or offices included on the ballot, with the unresolved issue(s) of impasse collectively considered as one (1) matter. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-15. - Obligation to abide by the results of collective bargaining. 
    The city and the firefighters and their bargaining agent are obligated to abide by, give effect to, and execute a written collective bargaining agreement incorporating any understandings reached by the city and the firefighters' bargaining agent, regarding those matters which are: 
(a)  Agreed to by both parties after collective bargaining; or 
(b)  Agreed to by both parties after the decision of the independent fact finder, or 
(c)  Approved by the majority of the registered electors of the city voting at an election. 
    The term of a collective bargaining agreement shall commence on January 1 and be for a duration of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 86-16. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  Neither the firefighters' bargaining agent nor any firefighter, nor any person acting in concert with them, will cause, sanction or take part in any withholding of any services or performance due to the city or its citizens by means of a strike, walkout, sit down, slowdown, stoppage of work, abnormal absenteeism, or other method. All such actions are expressly prohibited. 
(b)  Violation of any provision of subsection (a) of this section by any firefighter may result in discipline, up to and including termination, of the firefighter, in addition to whatever other remedies may be available to the city at law or in equity. 
(c)  No firefighter or person seeking to become a firefighter shall be appointed, promoted, reduced, removed or in any way discriminated against because of affiliations or non-affiliations with an employee organization. 
(Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Chapters 87-89 - RESERVED 
[1] 
Footnotes: 

Chapter 90 - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Improvement districts, Ch. XI. 
Cross reference- Public improvement information furnished to planning commission, § 5-43; parks, recreation and cemeteries, Ch. 80; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 105. 
State Law reference- Public improvements generally, C. R. S. § 31-15-707 et seq.; special improvement districts, C. R. S. § 31-25-501 et seq.; improvement districts (1949 Act), C. R. S. § 31-25-601 et seq. 
Annotation- Where electors presented to the city council a referendum petition demanding the repeal of Ordinance No. 355, an emergency ordinance providing for a street-paving improvement district, the petition was valid and could be applied to an emergency ordinance. Burks v. Lafayette, 142 Colo. 61, 349 P.2d 692 (1960) 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
    Alley improvements. The term "alley improvements" shall include surfacing and necessary improvements incidental thereto. 
    City administrator. All references to the "city administrator shall include his authorized representative, when such authority has been given by a written order of the city administrator. 
    City engineer. All references to the "city engineer" shall include any engineer, or firm of engineers or corporation engaged in the practice of engineering which may be under contract with the city with respect to local public improvements contracted for or installed pursuant to this Chapter. 
    Lots, etc. Lots, plots, block and other subdivisions may be designated in accordance with any recorded plat thereof, and unplatted lands by any definite description. 
    Real estate. The term "real estate" shall be held to mean all lands, whether platted or unplatted, regardless of the lot or land lines. 
    Street. The term "street" shall include avenues, boulevards and other highways. 
    Street improvements. The term "street improvements" shall include any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Surfacing of roadways. 
(2)  Construction of curbs, gutters and sidewalks. 
(3)  The necessary grading therefor. 
(4)  Landscaping of adjoining parkways by the planting of trees and shrubs. 
(5)  Storm drainage incidental thereto. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 23, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to improvement districts, C. R. S. §§ 31-25-501 and 31-25-602. 
Sec. 90-2. - Power of city generally. 
    The city shall have the power to contract for, construct or install special or local public improvements; to assess the cost thereof wholly or in part against the property specially benefited; to jointly make and jointly contract for a local public improvement and a general public improvement and to pay from any lawful fund that portion of the cost which is general public benefit; and to accept contributions or grants-in-aid to supply the whole or any part of the cost apportioned to the city, or to accept and apply such contribution or grants-in-aid wholly or in part credit to the appropriate public improvement district. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 2, 2-2-72) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 11.1 
State Law reference- Power of city to make local improvements, C. R. S. § 31-25-502. 
Sec. 90-3. - Improvements. 
(a)  The improvements authorized by this chapter may consist of any special or local improvement of any character, which improvement confers special benefits on real estate abutting on or in the vicinity of such improvement. 
(b)  Without limiting the generality of subsection (a) of this section, such improvements may consist of grading, paving, curbing, guttering, providing parking for, or otherwise improving the whole or any part of any street or alley, or streets or alleys in the city, or any one or more of said improvements, including the reconstruction, replacement, renewal, or extension of the same. In case of grading only, or grading and curbing only, the improvements may include the necessary cross walks. 
(c)  Such improvements may also consist of the construction of district sewers, or storm sewers in districts to be known as storm sewer districts, the same to be provided by ordinance in accordance with the provisions herein contained. Said sewers may consist of the necessary manholes, inlets and appurtenances, and shall be so constructed as to connect with some existing public sewer or natural drainage. Said districts may be divided into subdistricts to be specially named or numbered in said ordinance. The costs of district storm sewers may be assessed on all of the land in said storm sewer district respectively in proportion as the area of each piece of land in the district or in the part improved is to the area of all the land in the district, exclusive of public streets and highways, or by any other method that will result in the assessments being equitable in proportion to the benefits received. Such storm drains may be made, contracted for, or constructed larger than required by a local public improvement district, and the city may pay from any lawful fund that portion of the cost that may be in excess of the cost required by the district, and upon the extension at a later time of the mains or submains to an area not included within the district for which mains or submains were made and contracted for, the city may assess the amount paid by the city as a lien upon real property benefited by the over-sized construction and extension of the mains and submains. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 24, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 1, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- What improvements may be made, C. R. S. § 31-25-503. 
Sec. 90-4. - Petitions for improvement-Contents. 
    Every petition for a proposed improvement under this chapter shall describe the real property owned by each signer as being benefited by the proposed improvement, shall state the nature and location of the proposed improvement and the proposed maximum unit cost thereof, which unit cost shall be exclusive of the cost of collection of the assessments, other incidentals and all interests on any bonds issued in payment of construction and other costs from the time of issuance of said bonds to the time that interest commences on assessments; shall authorize advertising of the proposed improvement for remonstrances, if a preliminary, informal estimate of the city engineer indicates that the cost of the proposed improvement will not exceed by more than ten (10) percent the maximum unit cost set forth in the petition; and shall authorize an increase of the proposed maximum unit cost by not more than ten (10) percent thereof, and the assessment of such increase, if the estimate of the city engineer determines that such increase is necessary. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 5, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Petition for improvement, C. R. S. § 31-25-503. 
Sec. 90-5. - Same-Signatures. 
    All signatures on petitions shall be subscribed and acknowledged in the manner provided by law for the acknowledgement of deeds of conveyance of real estate; provided, however, that the signature of any owner or owners of real property may be attached to a petition by their agents duly authorized by power of attorney accompanying the petition. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 5, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-6. - Same-Withdrawal. 
    No petitioner, his heirs or assigns shall be permitted to withdraw from a petition after such petition has been filed with the city administrator unless the proposed improvement is not advertised for remonstrances within nine (9) months from the filing of the petition with the city administrator, and any petitioner who fails to withdraw prior to advertising shall be deemed to have waived his right to withdraw. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 5, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-7. - Assessment of property generally. 
(a)  In all cases when the cost of a local public improvement is to be assessed wholly or in part upon the property benefited, the cost shall be assessed in proportion to benefits received. Such assessments may be in proportion as the frontage of each lot or tract of land is to the frontage of all the lots and lands so improved, or may be in proportion as the area of each piece of real estate in the district is to the area of all the real estate in the district, or may be by any other method that will result in assessments being most equitably in proportion to benefits received. 
(b)  If, at the time of the passage of the ordinance authorizing any improvement, any piece of real estate has the whole or any part of the proposed improvement conforming to the general plan and acceptable to the city engineer, the existing improvement may be adopted in whole or in part, or necessary changes thereof may be made to make the same conform to the general plan, and the owner of such real estate shall, when the assessment is made, be credited with the amount which is saved by reason of adopting or adapting such existing improvement. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 4, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Cost assessed in accordance with benefits, C. R. S. § 31-25-513. 
Sec. 90-8. - Public notice-Required. 
    In all cases where the cost of local public improvements is assessed wholly or in part upon property benefited, public notice of the proposed improvements, either individually or in groups, shall be given. If the petition for an improvement is signed by one hundred (100) percent of the owners of the real property to be assessed and contains a request for waiver, or if each of such property owners otherwise executes and delivers to the city council a waiver agreement satisfactory to the city council, the city council may, in its discretion, waive any or all of the requirements for notice, publication, and hearing set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 6, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1986-14, § 1, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 90-9. - Same-Assessed real estate not adjacent to improvement. 
    When it is proposed to assess real estate which is not abutting, adjoining, contiguous or adjacent to any proposed improvement, the notice shall state the exterior boundaries of the real estate proposed to be so assessed, or of the proposed district. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 6, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-10. - Same-How advertised. 
    The city administrator shall, by advertisement at least once, in a newspaper of general circulation within the city, give notice to the owners of the real estate benefited and to all persons interested generally, without naming such owners or persons, of the proposed improvements and of the real property which would be assessed therefor, a proposed method of assessment and the manner of payment therefor, and the date, place and time for hearing written remonstrances to the proposed improvement, which date shall be not less than ten (10) days after the publication of the notice of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 6, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 2, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-11. - Same-How mailed. 
    The city administrator shall mail by first class mail, not less than seven (7) days prior to the hearing, a copy of the notice of proposed improvements to the owners of record of all real estate in the proposed district as such owners of record are determined by reference to the current records in the office of the county assessor, as such records are kept by that official for the purpose of performing his function of county assessor. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 6, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 3, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-12. - Objections to improvement. 
    In all cases where the cost of a local public improvement is to be assessed wholly or in part upon property benefited, the improvement shall be initiated by the city administrator without receiving a petition therefor, except that when the owners of the real estate which would bear thirty-five (35) percent or more of the estimated cost of the proposed improvements have filed a regularly executed petition therefor, the city administrator shall advertise such improvement for remonstrances unless, in his judgment, the proposed improvement is not good and sufficient for the particular locality; provided, however, that no improvement proposed by petition shall be advertised for remonstrances if the preliminary informal estimate of the city engineer exceeds by more than ten (10) percent the maximum unit cost stated in the petition. The estimate of the city engineer shall be conclusive for this determination. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 5, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-13. - Hearing-Conduct; filing of remonstrances. 
    On the day and at the time and place specified in the notice set forth in this chapter, the city administrator shall conduct a hearing for the purpose of considering the desirability of and the need for such advertised proposed improvements. If for any reason the hearing is postponed and not held until a later hour or date, and the city administrator is hereby authorized to postpone any hearing to a fixed later hour and date, written remonstrances to a proposed improvement shall be accepted up to the opening of the postponed session of the hearing; otherwise, such written remonstrances must be filed prior to the date and hour of the original hearing. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 8, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-14. - Same-Signing remonstrances. 
    All written remonstrances to a proposed improvement shall be subscribed and acknowledged in the same manner required for petitions for proposed improvements. No person who has signed his name for an improvement shall be permitted to sign a remonstrance to the same improvement unless such person has regularly withdrawn from such petition as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 8, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-15. - Same-Remonstrances. 
    If a duly executed written remonstrance is timely filed by the owners of a majority of the property to be assessed, except in case the city shall pay one-half or more of the total cost of the improvements made, the proposed improvements shall not be ordered. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 8, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 4, 5-1-84) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 11.1. 
Sec. 90-16. - Approval of improvements. 
    After the hearing and subject to the foregoing limitations, the city administrator shall enter an order approving those proposed improvements which he considers proper. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 8, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 5, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-17. - Objections to proceedings, etc. 
    Any objection to the regularity, validity and correctness of the proceedings and instruments taken, adopted or made prior to the date of a hearing under this chapter shall be deemed waived unless presented by remonstrance at the time and in the manner specified in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 8, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-18. - Modification of proceedings. 
    All proceedings by the city administrator may be modified or rescinded wholly or in part at any time prior to the final passage of the ordinance authorizing the improvements; provided that no substantial change in the district, details, preliminary plans or specifications shall be made after the publication of notice to property owners, except the deletion of improvements and property from the proposed program and district; and provided, further, that the city administrator shall have the right to make minor changes in the time, plans and materials entering into the work at any time before its completion. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 8, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 6, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-19. - Formation of districts-Procedure. 
    After the hearing set forth in this chapter, the city engineer shall combine into suitable construction units those proposed local improvements which have been approved by the city administrator. Each such construction unit, whether composed of noncontiguous parts or sections or not, shall constitute a local public improvement district and shall be so referred to in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 9, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-20. - Same-Conditions. 
    In the formation of local public improvement district or districts under this chapter, the city engineer shall make such condition as, in his judgment, will make for efficiency in construction and will result in the lowest possible construction cost. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 9, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-21. - Report by city engineer. 
    For each such local public improvement district, the city engineer shall submit to the city administrator a detailed estimate of the total cost of the improvements and a detailed estimate of cost for each improvement included within the district, exclusive of all incidental costs; full details and specifications for the proposed construction, which said details and specifications shall permit and encourage competition among bidders; a map showing the real property to be assessed for the cost of construction; and an estimate of that portion, if any, of the cost of such construction which is not to be assessed for a local public improvement. The estimates provided for in this section shall not be binding upon the city for any purpose. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 9, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 7, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-22. - Submission of ordinance to council. 
    The city administrator shall cause to be prepared and submitted to the city council an ordinance authorizing creation of the district and the construction of the improvements proposed, which ordinance shall be in the form recommended by the city administrator by his endorsement thereon. Such ordinance may be passed on first reading by the city council prior to the hearing on the proposed improvements, but shall not be finally passed until after such hearing. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 10, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 8, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-23. - Finding of city council conclusive. 
    The findings of the city council by ordinance that any local public improvements were duly ordered after notice duly given, or that a petition or remonstrance was or was not filed, or was or was not duly subscribed and acknowledged as required in this chapter, shall be conclusive in every court or other tribunal. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 10, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-24. - Construction contracts-General requirements. 
    In all cases where the cost of local public improvements is to be assessed wholly or in part upon the property benefited, the improvements shall be constructed by independent contract or contracts. All such contracts shall be let by the city administrator with the approval of the city council. All such contracts shall be let to the lowest reliable and responsible bidder after publication of notice to bidders at least once, at least ten (10) days prior to the opening of bids, in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. The right to reject any and all bids is reserved. No such contract shall be made without bond for its faithful performance with sufficient surety or sureties thereon. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 3, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 9, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- Contracts for construction, C. R. S. § 31-25-516. 
Sec. 90-25. - Same-Conditions; guarantees. 
    In the letting of contracts under this chapter the city administrator may impose such conditions upon bidders with regard to bonds and securities and such guarantees of good faith and responsibility on the part of the bidders for the faithful completion of the work and providing for any other material matter or thing in connection therewith as may be considered advantageous to the city. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 3, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Surety bond with construction contracts, C. R. S. § 31-25-516. 
Sec. 90-26. - Same-Restrictions; supervision or termination. 
    Upon notice and for substantial cause, the work under such contracts may be suspended or terminated forthwith by the city council or the city administrator. Every such contract shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter and the provisions of any ordinance authorizing the improvements or contracts. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 3, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 10, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-27. - Same-Default. 
    Upon default in the performance of any contract under this chapter the city administrator may advertise and let a contract for the uncompleted work in a like manner and without further ordinances, and charge the cost thereof to the original contractor upon his contract; and when a deficiency shall in such case occur, the city administrator with the approval of the city council may advance the amount thereof out of any available funds in the city and recover the same by suit on the original contract and bond. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 3, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Default in performance of contract, C. R. S. § 31-25-516. 
Sec. 90-28. - Improvement district bonds; tax authorized. 
    In consideration of general benefits conferred on the city at large from the construction or installation of improvements in special or local improvement districts, the city council may levy annual taxes on all taxable property within the city at a rate not exceeding two (2) mills in any one year, to be disbursed as determined by the city council for the purpose of paying for such benefits, for the payment of any assessment levied against the city itself in connection with bonds issued for special or local improvement districts or for the purpose of advancing money to maintain current payments of interest and equal annual payments of the principal amount of bonds issued for any special or local improvement district hereafter created. The proceeds of such taxes shall be placed in a special fund and shall be disbursed only for the purposes specified herein, provided, however, that in lieu of such tax levies, the city council may annually transfer to such special fund any available money of the city, but in no event shall the amount transferred in any one year exceed the amount which would result from a tax levied in such year as herein limited. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 22, 2-2-72) 
Cross reference- Taxation, Ch. 110. 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 11.3. 
Sec. 90-29. - Special assessment bonds generally. 
(a)  For the purpose of paying all or such portion of the cost of any improvement constructed under the provisions of this chapter as may be assessed against the property specially benefited and not paid by the city, special assessment bonds of the city may be issued in such form as may be prescribed by the city council, payable in a period of years at least sufficient to cover the period of assessment installment payments provided. All such bonds may be issued on estimates approved by the city council and sold as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Such bonds shall be payable out of the monies collected on account of the assessments made for such improvements and from such other sources as may be provided for in the ordinance authorizing such bonds and as may be permitted by Article XI of the city charter. All monies collected from such assessments for any improvement shall be applied for the payment of the bonds issued therefor and interest thereon, until payment in full is made of all the bonds, both principal and interest. The bonds may be used in payment of the cost of the improvements, or the city council may sell said bonds to pay such cost by public or private sale to the best advantage of the city. All such bonds shall bear interest as may be fixed by the city council, and shall be payable and redeemable and shall otherwise be issued with such terms as may be provided by the city council in the ordinance authorizing the issuance of such bonds. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 20, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 875, § 3, 4-15-80; Ord. No. 877, § 1, 5-6-80; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 11, 5-1-84) 
Charter reference- Improvement district bonds, general benefit, § 11.3. 
State Law reference- Power of city to issue special assessment bonds, C. R. S. § 31-25-534. 
Sec. 90-30. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1984-10, § 23, adopted May 10, 1984, repealed former § 90-30, payment of bonds, as derived from Ord. No. 493, § 21, adopted Feb. 2, 1972. 
Sec. 90-31. - Surplus and deficiency. 
    When all outstanding bonds of any series issued under this chapter have been paid and any moneys remain to the credit of the district, they shall be transferred to a special surplus and deficiency fund, and whenever there is a deficiency in any special or local improvement district fund to meet the payments of outstanding bonds and interest due thereon, the deficiency shall be paid out of said surplus and deficiency fund. Whenever a special or local improvement district has paid and cancelled three-fourths of its bonds issued, and for any reason the remaining assessments are not paid in time to take up the remaining bonds of the district and the interest due thereon and there is not sufficient money in said special surplus fund and deficiency fund; then the city shall pay said bonds when due and the interest due thereon, and reimburse itself by collecting the unpaid assessments due said district. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 22, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 12, 5-1-84) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 11.2. 
Sec. 90-32. - Connection to utilities. 
    Before beginning any authorized construction, the city administrator may order the owners of the abutting real estate to connect their several premises with the gas, water and sewer mains or with any other conduits in the street or alley adjacent to their several premises. In case of a failure or refusal by the owners of the abutting real estate to make the ordered connections, such connections shall be made incidental to the authorized construction cost and the cost thereof assessed upon the appropriate abutting real estate. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 11, 2-2-72) 
Cross reference- Sewers, Ch. 95; water, Ch. 120. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-515. 
Sec. 90-33. - Determination of cost. 
    In determining the whole cost of the local public improvement there shall be included therein, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the cost of constructing or otherwise acquiring such improvement or improvements (which may be based on bid price), contingencies, engineering and clerical services and supplies, cost of inspection, cost of collecting assessments, advertising, printing, interest on bonds until interest on assessments commences to defray such, fiscal services, legal services for preparing proceedings and advising in regard thereto and other incidental costs, which incidental costs may be based on estimates approved by the council. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 12, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 13, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-34. - Notice of costs-Publication; contents. 
    Upon completion of any local improvement under this chapter, and upon acceptance thereof by the city administrator, or upon determination of the best bid therefor, with estimated incidental expenses, or whenever the whole cost of any improvement, or a complete unit thereof can otherwise be reasonably ascertained, the city administrator shall publish, at least once, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, a notice to the owners of the real estate to be assessed and all persons interested generally, without naming such owners or persons. Such notice shall specify the whole cost of the improvements, the portion, if any to be paid by the city, and the proposed apportionment on the real property benefited, and the date, place and time for hearing written remonstrances to the proposed apportionment, which date shall be not less than ten (10) days after the publication of the notice of the hearing. At such hearing, or at an adjournment thereof, any such written remonstrances will be heard and determined by the council, sitting as a board of equalization. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 12, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 14, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- Notice of hearing on assessments, C. R. S. § 31-25-520. 
Sec. 90-35. - Same-Objections waived unless set out. 
    Any objection to the regularity, validity or correctness of the proceedings under this chapter, or of the proposed apportionment, or of any assessment based thereon, and of the amount levied on each tract and parcel of land, shall be deemed waived unless presented in writing at the time and in the manner herein specified. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 12, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-36. - Complaints-Hearing. 
    At such hearing, or an adjournment thereof, the city council, sitting as a board of equalization, shall hear and determine all written remonstrances filed with the city administrator and may confirm the apportionment proposed or make any modifications which may seem equitable and just. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 13, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 15, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- Hearing on objections, C. R. S. § 31-25-521. 
Sec. 90-37. - Same-New apportionment. 
    After the consideration of all objections to the apportionment, if any change in the apportionment shall be made by the council it shall certify such change to the city administrator, who shall prepare a new apportionment in accordance therewith and transmit the same to the council. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 13, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 16, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-38. - Assessing ordinance. 
    The assessing ordinance shall assess the cost of the improvements against the real estate to be assessed in the district in the proportion finally determined. The assessing ordinance may be passed on first reading by the city council prior to the hearing on the proposed assessments, but shall not be finally passed until after such hearing. The final passage of the assessing ordinance shall be prima facie evidence of the fact that the property assessed is benefited in the amount of the assessment, and that such assessments have been lawfully made. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 13, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 17, 5-1-84) 
Sec. 90-39. - Assessment roll. 
    The city clerk shall from the assessing ordinance prepare a local assessment roll in book form, showing in suitable columns each piece of real estate assessed, the amount of the assessment, the amount of each installment of principal and interest if, in pursuance of this chapter, the same is payable in installments, and the date when such installments will become due, with suitable columns for use in case of payment of the whole amount, or of any installment or penalty, and deliver the same duly certified, under the corporate seal of the city, to the city treasurer for collection. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 14, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Assessment roll, C. R. S. § 31-25-523. 
Sec. 90-40. - Lien. 
    From the date of the final publication of the assessing ordinance, all assessments made pursuant thereto shall be a lien in the several amounts assessed against each lot or tract of land, and such assessments shall have priority over all other liens except general taxes and prior assessment liens. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 15, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 18, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- Assessment a lien, C. R. S. § 31-25-522. 
Sec. 90-41. - Irregularities. 
    No delays, mistakes, errors, defects or irregularities in any act or proceeding authorized in this chapter shall prejudice or invalidate any final assessment, but the same shall be remedied by subsequent or amended acts or proceedings as the case may require, and when so remedied the same shall take effect as of the date of the original act or proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 15, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-522. 
Sec. 90-42. - Assessment set aside by court. 
    If in any court of competent jurisdiction any final assessment is set aside for irregularity in the proceedings or for any other reason, then the council, upon notice as required in the making of an original assessment, may make a new assessment in accordance with the provisions in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 15, 2-2-72) 
Charter reference- Commencement of action to question assessments, etc., § 11.4. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-539. 
Sec. 90-43. - Payment of assessments-When due; installments authorized. 
    All assessments shall be due and payable, without interest and without demand, within thirty (30) days after the publication of the assessing ordinance after its final passage; provided, that the city council may provide that at the election of the owners such assessments may be paid in installments, with interest on the unpaid portion of such assessment at a rate to be determined by the city council. The number of installments, periods of payment and rate of interest shall be determined and fixed by the city council in the assessing ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 16, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 875, § 1, 4-15-80; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 19, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. §§ 31-25-527, 31-25-528. 
Sec. 90-44. - Same-Election to pay in installments. 
    Failure to pay the whole assessment under this chapter within said period of thirty (30) days shall be conclusively considered and held as an election on the part of all persons interested, whether under disability or otherwise, to pay in installments. Such election shall be conclusively considered and held a waiver of any and all right to question the power or jurisdiction of the city to construct the improvements, the quality of the work, the regularity or sufficiency of the proceedings, or the validity or correctness of the assessment. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 16, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 875, § 1, 4-15-80; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 20, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-529. 
Sec. 90-45. - Same-Payment of principal. 
    The owner of any piece of real estate not in default as to any installment or payment may at any time pay the whole unpaid principal of his assessment with the interest to the time the next installment of interest becomes due and payable. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 16, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 875, § 1, 4-15-80; Ord. No. 1984-10, § 21, 5-1-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-530. 
Sec. 90-46. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1984-10, § 23, adopted May 10, 1984, provided that § 90-46 be repealed. Such section had pertained to the owner of an interest paying share of assessment, and was derived from Ord. No. 493, § 16, adopted Feb. 2, 1972, as amended by Ord. No. 875, § 1, adopted Apr. 15, 1980. 
Sec. 90-47. - Failure to pay installments. 
    Failure to pay any installment, whether of principal or interest, when due under this chapter shall cause the whole of the unpaid principal to become due and payable immediately, and the whole amount of the unpaid principal and accrued interest shall thereafter draw interest until the day of sale at a rate to be determined by the city council; but at any time prior to the date of sale the owner may pay the amount of all delinquent installments, with interest at the rate determined by the city council, as aforesaid, plus all penalties accrued, and thereupon shall be restored to the right thereafter to pay in installments in the same manner as if default had not been suffered. No statute of limitations shall apply until the last installment of assessments becomes due and payable. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 18, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 875, § 2, 4-15-80) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-530; limitation of actions, C. R. S. § 13-80-101 et seq. 
Sec. 90-48. - Default of payment. 
    At the expiration of said thirty-day period, provided in the preceding section, the city treasurer shall return the local assessment roll to the clerk, thereon showing all payments made thereon with the date of each payment. Said roll shall be certified by the city clerk under the corporate seal of the city, and by him/her redelivered to the city treasurer with a warrant for the collection of the same. The city treasurer shall receive payment for all assessments appearing on the assessment roll, with interest. In case of default in the payment of any installment of principal or interest when due, the city treasurer shall cause to be advertised and sold any and all property, concerning which such default is suffered, for the payment of the whole of the unpaid assessments, with interest and penalties thereon. Said advertisements and sales shall be made at the same time and in the same manner, under all the same conditions and penalties and with the same effect, as are provided by general law for sales of real estate in default of payment of general taxes. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 17, 2-2-72; Ord. No. 907, § 1, 3-17-81) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-531; tax sales, C. R. S. § 39-11-101 et seq. 
Sec. 90-49. - Sale of unpaid assessments. 
    At any sale by the county treasurer of any real estate in the city for the purpose of paying any special assessments for local improvements, the city treasurer, having the written authority from the city council, may purchase such real estate without paying for the same in cash, and receive a certificate of purchase from the county treasurer in the name of the city. Such certificates shall be received and credited at their face value, with all interest and penalties accrued, on account of the assessments in pursuance of which the sale was made. The certificates may thereafter be sold by the city treasurer for the best price obtainable at public sale, at auction or by sealed bids, in the same manner and under the same conditions as is provided in this chapter in respect to the sale of property owned by the city, and the proceeds, in the event that all bonded indebtedness incurred in payment for said local improvements has not been discharged in full, credited to the fund created by the ordinance for the payment of such assessments; or, in the event that all bonded indebtedness incurred in payment for said local improvements has been discharged in full, the proceeds shall be credited to the special surplus and deficiency fund provided for by section 90-31 of this chapter. Such assignments shall be without recourse, and the sale and assignment shall operate as a lien in favor of the purchaser and assignee as provided by law in the case of sale of real estate in default of payment of the general taxes. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 19, 2-2-72) 
Charter reference- Surplus and deficiency fund, § 11.2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-532; tax sales, C. R. S. § 39-11-101 et seq. 
Sec. 90-50. - Foreclosure by city. 
    In addition to all other remedies, the city, when it is the holder of a certificate of purchase, may bring a civil action for the foreclosure thereof joining as defendants all persons having or claiming any interest in the property or the proceeds of foreclosure sale, and all governmental units having taxes or other claims against said property, and all unknown persons having or claiming interest in said property. Any number of certificates may be foreclosed in the same proceeding. In such proceedings, the city, as plaintiff, shall be entitled to all relief provided by law in actions for adjudication of rights with respect to real property. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 19, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-532. 
Sec. 90-51. - Sale of property by city. 
    Cumulatively, with all other remedies, the city being the owner of property by virtue of a tax deed or being the owner of property otherwise acquired in satisfaction or discharge of the liens represented by certificates of sale, may sell such property for the best price obtainable at public sale, at auction, or by sealed bids. Such sale shall be after public notice by the city treasurer to all persons having or claiming any interest in the property to be sold or the proceeds of such sale, such public notice to be by publication, once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks by three (3) insertions in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. Such notice shall describe the property, state the time, place and manner of receiving bids and the time fixed for sale, which shall be not less than twenty (20) days after the first publication. The city may reject any and all bids. Any interested party at any time within ten (10) days after receipt of bids for the sale of property may file with the city administrator a written protest as to the sufficiency or the amount of any bid made, or the validity of the proceedings for the sale. If such protest shall be denied, such person, within ten (10) days thereafter, shall commence an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enjoin or restrain the city from completing the sale. If no such action shall be commenced, all protests or objections to the sale shall be deemed to have been waived, and the city shall then convey the property to the successful bidder by quitclaim deed. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 19, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-532. 
Sec. 90-52. - Proceeds of sale of property by city. 
    The proceeds of any sale of property by the city under this chapter shall be credited to the appropriate special assessment fund or the surplus and deficiency fund, as provided in this chapter. The city shall deduct therefrom the necessary expenses in securing deeds and taking procedures for the sale or foreclosure. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 19, 2-2-72) 
Charter reference- Surplus and deficiency fund, § 11.2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-532. 
Sec. 90-53. - Manner of setting out descriptions. 
    In all proceedings authorized or required by this chapter figures may be used instead of words, and it shall not be necessary in improvement districts to designate each piece of real estate in the district separately, but general descriptions and quantities may be used except in the assessment rolls, and the cost may be stated as being a probable amount per front foot, or per square foot, or per lot of a given size, and proportionate amounts for other lots or, when a different rule of assessment is provided, then as being subject to such rule. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 23, 2-2-72) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C. R. S. § 31-25-540. 
Sec. 90-54. - Legal proceedings. 
    No action or proceeding, at law or in equity, to review any acts or proceedings, or to question the validity or enjoin the performance of any act, or the issuance or collection of any bonds, or the levy or collection of any assessments, authorized in this chapter, or for any other relief against any acts or proceedings done or had pursuant hereto or under the provisions of the charter of the city, with reference hereto, whether based upon illegalities, irregularities or jurisdictional defects, shall be maintained, unless commenced within ninety (90) days after the performance of the act or the passage of the resolution or ordinance complained of, or else be thereafter perpetually barred. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 25, 2-2-72) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 11.4. 
State Law reference- Maintenance of actions, C. R. S. § 31-25-538. 
Sec. 90-55. - Existing districts. 
    Local public improvement districts created but not completed and assessed on the effective date of this chapter shall not be affected hereby but shall be governed by the laws relating to such improvement districts on the date of their creation. 
(Ord. No. 493, § 25, 2-2-72) 
Sec. 90-56. - District 72-1 created. 
    Public Improvement District 72-1 is created and the proposed improvements constructed and the real property shown on Exhibit "B" of the ordinance from which this section is derived is assessed for the cost of construction of the proposed improvements. 
(Ord. No. 540, § 1, 8-15-72) 
Sec. 90-57. - Statutes superseded. 
    Pursuant to Article XX of the Colorado Constitution and the City's Charter, Part 5 of Article 25, Chapter 31, C.R.S., and all other statutes or portions of statutes relating to the creation of local improvement districts, the issuance of special assessment bonds, or the levying of special assessments for improvements, are hereby superseded. 
(Ord. No. 1984-10, § 22, 5-1-84) 
Chapter 92 - REIMBURSEMENT ASSESSMENT DISTRICTS 

Sec. 92-1. - Type of improvements subject to reimbursement. 
(a)  The owner of any property in Lafayette who installs and dedicates street, sidewalk, water main, sewer main, bicycle trail, bridge, storm drainage facility or other public improvements, may apply for the establishment of a reimbursement assessment district to obtain reimbursement of a portion of the cost from the owners of other property specially benefitted by the improvements. 
(b)  If the city constructs any such improvement which specially benefits the owners of private property, it may establish a reimbursement assessment district for its own benefit, subject, however, to all the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 92-2. - Property eligible for inclusion. 
(a)  Property is eligible for inclusion in a district if it will be or has been specially benefitted by a street, sidewalk, bicycle trail, storm drainage facility, bridge, water main, sewer main or other improvement constructed and dedicated to the city or constructed and owned by the city. 
(b)  Property located outside the city limits may be included in a reimbursement district upon the application of the person installing the improvements. Such inclusion, however, shall be contingent and no assessment may be collected with respect to such property unless it has been annexed to the city prior to the last date to which the assessment may be deferred pursuant to section 92-4(a), or ten (10) years from the effective date of the ordinance establishing or renewing the reimbursement district, whichever date is later. 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 92-3. - Basis for assessment. 
(a)  Properties within a reimbursement district shall be assessed in such a manner as equitably to apportion the cost among all properties specially benefitted by the improvement, but no property shall be assessed an amount greater than the special benefit received by it. In the absence of unusual circumstances requiring a different method, improvements, other than bridges, shall be subject to reimbursement on the basis of front footage for streets, sidewalks and trails and on the basis of acres served in the case of water main, sewer main and storm drainage improvements. 
(b)  The cost to be apportioned within a reimbursement district shall be the reasonable cost of installing the improvement, but not including the cost of any part or portion which solely benefits the developer such as curb cuts or main connections to serve his property. Engineering, surveying, legal and similar costs, not to exceed fifteen (15) percent of construction costs, may be included for determining the cost.
