When possible, reimbursable construction costs shall be based upon the lowest responsible bid of three (3) bids obtained by the developer. If the city constructs any improvement which specially benefits the owner of private property and, in connection therewith, is granted an easement by the owner without consideration, then the owner shall receive a credit against any reimbursement assessment obligation established hereunder in an amount equal to the fair market value of such easement; provided however, that nothing herein shall be construed to give a credit to an owner that would otherwise be required to grant such an easement upon development, as the term is defined in section 26-8-1 of this Code, of the owner's property. 
(c)  Except as hereinafter limited, the term "special benefit" shall mean any benefit conferred upon a property which is greater or different in kind from that conferred upon properties in the city as a whole by an improvement. Among the factors to be considered in determining the existence of a special benefit are: 
(1)  Increased market value. 
(2)  Improvement in safety or convenience of access. 
(3)  Improved drainage. 
(4)  Alleviation of health or sanitation hazards. 
(5)  Adaptability of the property to a superior or more profitable use. 
(6)  Improved availability of public water or sewer service to the property. 
(7)  In the case of undeveloped property, the installation of an improvement which would otherwise be required upon development of the property. 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 92-4. - Reimbursement terms. 
(a)  The assessment shall be due and payable upon the effective date of the ordinance imposing the assessment; provided, however, if any property included within a reimbursement district is unplatted, undeveloped or has not connected to the improvement at the time the assessment is imposed, the owner of such property may defer payment of the assessment until such time as the property is platted, a building permit is issued, or the property connects to the improvement, whichever shall first occur after the assessment is imposed; provided however, that upon good cause shown, the city council may by resolution alter or vary the act or event that triggers the requirement of payment of deferred assessments. 
(b)  If the owner elects to defer payment of the assessment, the payment shall include interest at the rate provided by C.R.S. 5-12-102(4)(b) for judgments, as amended from time to time. Such interest shall commence on the effective date of the ordinance imposing the assessment. Notwithstanding any of the foregoing, the city council may by resolution, upon good cause shown, vary the rate of interest, suspend interest for a certain time period or waive interest entirely for deferred assessments. 
(c)  A reimbursement district shall terminate ten (10) years from the effective date of the ordinance establishing it and any property which is platted or connected to the improvement or for which a building permit is issued thereafter shall not be subject to reimbursement assessment; provided however, that the city council may, prior to such termination and by ordinance, renew for not more than ten (10) years the reimbursement district and reimbursement assessment as to all properties for which the assessment is not then paid in full upon a finding of special benefit as to each such property in accordance with the standards contained in section 92-3 of this chapter. Said renewal ordinance shall be filed as a notice applicable to each such property in the office of the county clerk and recorder 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 92-5. - Establishment of districts. 
(a)  Application. 
(1)  The owner of any property who has previously installed one or more public improvements may file with the city administrator an application for a reimbursement district. The application shall include the nature, location, and cost of the improvements, a description of the proposed district and a legal description of each of the individual properties within it, the names and addresses of the property owners within the district, the proposed manner of assessment and the amount proposed to be assessed against each property for each improvement. Nothing herein shall be construed to allow an original owner to seek reimbursement from a current owner of property once owned by the original owner. 
(2)  The owner of any property who proposes to install one or more public improvements may file with the city administrator an application for a reimbursement district. The application shall include the nature, location and anticipated cost of the improvements, a description of the proposed district and a legal description of each of the individual properties within it, the names and addresses of the property owners within the district, the proposed manner of assessment and the amount proposed to be assessed against each property for each improvement. When possible, the application shall be accompanied by three (3) construction bids. Nothing herein shall be construed to allow an owner to seek reimbursement from a future owner of property, which property is owned at the time of the application by the owner making application. 
(b)  Notice. Within thirty (30) days of the city's receipt of a complete application, a notice shall be mailed, by the applicant, by registered mail to the owners of each property within the proposed district together with a copy of the application. The notice shall state that any owner may file, within fifteen (15) days, a written request for an administrative hearing to contest the proposal. The request for hearing shall state in general terms the grounds of objection. 
(c)  Hearing. Upon written request for an administrative hearing, the city council shall schedule a hearing to be held within sixty (60) days and shall so notify the applicant and all objecting parties. The hearing shall be quasi-judicial in nature. 
(d)  Adoption of ordinance. After the hearing, or if no hearing is requested, the city council shall then consider the adoption of an ordinance establishing a reimbursement district and imposing appropriate assessments which may be, in the discretion of the city council, liens upon the property assessed. If the city council determines that the assessments shall be liens upon the property assessed, it shall so state in the ordinance and cause a notice of the lien to be filed for record in the office of the county clerk and recorder. If the city council determines that the assessments shall not be liens upon the property assessed, then it shall cause a notice of reimbursement assessment obligation to be filed for record in the office of the county clerk and recorder. 
(e)  Judicial review. Any reimbursement assessment ordinance adopted hereunder shall be subject to judicial review pursuant to Colorado Rule of Civil Procedure No. 106. 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 92-6. - Developer's responsibility. 
    After the adoption of a reimbursement ordinance, it shall be the responsibility of the person entitled to reimbursement to keep the city apprised of his current address. In the event of the recipient's death, it shall be his personal representative's responsibility to notify the city of the name and address of the person entitled to receive future reimbursements. In the case of a corporate recipient, a successor shall be designated prior to dissolution. Failure to comply with the developer's responsibilities shall constitute abandonment of all rights of reimbursement and shall be grounds for repeal of the reimbursement ordinance and refund of any assessments received by the city on behalf of the developer after the abandonment. 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 92-7. - Release. 
    Upon payment of assessment or expiration of the reimbursement term, whichever occurs first, the city shall, upon request, issue a written release to the owner of assessed property. 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 92-8. - Contracts. 
(a)  In lieu of the procedure set forth herein, the developer and the owners of any property that would be subject to assessment may contract for reimbursement in such manner and amount as they deem appropriate and the city will, at the request of the parties, collect the reimbursement at the time of connection, platting, or as otherwise agreed. 
(b)  In the event that a developer contracts with the owner of a portion of the property which would be subject to reimbursement assessment, such property shall be excluded from the district, but no property within the district shall be assessed in an amount proportionally greater than that provided by contract. 
(c)  The city council hereby ratifies and affirms all previously approved reimbursement agreements, development requirements or any conditions of approval heretofore entered into by the city and expresses its intent that the adoption of this chapter 92 not affect the validity of such preexisting contracts, requirements or conditions. 
(Ord. No. 1999-39, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Chapter 95 - WATER RECLAMATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2000-44, adopted Nov. 21, 2000, changed the title of Ch. 95 from "Sewers" to "Water Reclamation." 
Charter reference- Municipal utilities, Ch. XIII. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 30; mobile homes, Ch. 60; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 105; water, Ch. 120; subdivisions, App. B; connection to utilities, § 90-32; flood control standards for utilities, App. C, § 5.1-3. 
State Law reference- Municipal sewer systems, C. R. S. §§ 31-15-709, 31-35-401 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 95-1. - Mandatory connection. 
    All water closets and toilets in or belonging to any residence, factory, store, office or other building located within the city limits, together with all drainage from plumbing fixtures located therein, shall be connected to the public water reclamation system of the city. 
(Ord. No. 394, § 1, 6-1-65; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 8, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-2. - Extensions-Subdivisions. 
(a)  The developer of any subdivision desiring water reclamation service from the city shall pay the entire cost of extending the city water reclamation service to such subdivision and shall deed to the city all mains and service connections required to service the subdivision. The city shall pay for any oversized pipe that is required as a result of any master plan adopted by the city for water reclamation service to any area either within or outside of the existing city limits. All extensions shall conform to city specifications. 
(b)  For subdivisions inside the city limits, the city's main extension policy shall be as follows: 
The city will extend or require the subdivider to extend the required water reclamation main through the subdivision to be served. If the subdivider is required to extend the main, then the city will negotiate a repayment agreement with the subdivider which will allow said subdivider to recoup as much of the cost of the extension between the boundary of his subdivision and the nearest properly sized city sewer main as can be agreed upon. 
(c)  In the event no agreement can be made between the city and the subdivider, then the city shall not be responsible to extend the main. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 5, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 2000-44, §§ 2, 9, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-3. - Same-Individuals. 
(a)  Any individual desiring the extension of the city water reclamation system to serve his private property shall pay the entire cost of extending the city water reclamation service to his property and shall deed to the city all water reclamation lines and improvements necessary to extend the service to his property. The city shall pay the cost of any oversize pipes which the city requires to serve any individual property as the result of any master plan which is adopted by the city for water service within or outside the existing city limits. All extensions shall conform to city specifications in the office of the director of public works. 
(b)  For individuals inside the city, the city's main extension policy shall be as follows: 
The city will extend or require the individual to extend the required service mains to the individual being served. If the individual is required to extend the main, then the city will negotiate a repayment agreement with the individual which will allow the individual to recoup as much of the cost of extensions between the boundary of his property and nearest properly sized city water reclamation main as can be agreed upon. 
(c)  In the event no agreement can be made between the city and the individual, then the city shall not be responsible to extend the main. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 5, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-4. - Same-Inside city water reclamation line modifications. 
    The city recognizes its responsibility as it relates to water reclamation service to existing, developed, platted property within the city which is already served by water reclamation main which may be inadequate for conformance with sound engineering and public safety standards. When necessity arises for enlarging or replacing or otherwise upgrading the water reclamation system in an existing platted, developed area already served by city water reclamation, the improvement will be made by the city. If such improvements are made necessary by the development of a new subdivision which is to be served by a water reclamation main passing through an area described above, then the city may require the developer to negotiate a participation agreement with the city for the cost of the improvements. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 5, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-5. - Same-Oversizing; city participation. 
    If the size of water reclamation line required to serve a subdivision or individual is smaller than the size line the city wishes installed for sound future planning, then the city will participate in the oversizing of the pipe from a minimum of six (6) inches to the size the city wishes to be installed. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 5, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-6. - Same-City-developer cooperation on line extension. 
    The city council may, if it appears to be in the best interest of the city so to do, extend the water reclamation line for the purpose of serving a subdivision, group of subdivisions or an individual or individuals by constructing a line with force account labor or by contracting for construction of the line. If the council elects to construct such a line at city expense, then a fair portion of the cost of such line shall be recouped by the city through the addition, over and above the standard tap fee, of a surcharge established by resolution. The city administrator shall recommend the area to which the surcharge shall apply, and the amount of the surcharge to the city council based upon the density and type of development proposed along the projected line extension. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 5, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Secs. 95-7-95-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAPS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to prescribe and collect sewer tap fees, C. R. S. § 31-35-402. 

Sec. 95-21. - Definitions. 
    The water reclamation tap fee prescribed in section 95-25 et seq. of this article shall be charged and paid pursuant to the following definitions: 
    Apartment: A multi-unit dwelling under a common ownership consisting of one (1) or more rental units. 
    Building: "Building" as used in this article for purposes of applying the schedule of charges means an independent structure standing alone, excluding fences. To qualify as one building, all portions, additions or extensions shall be connected by an attachment that is an enclosed part of the building and which is usable by the occupants thereof. 
    Combined uses: Developments with combined residential and other than residential uses in the same structure or building shall be assessed a tap fee based on the individual uses within the structure. The "other than residential" portion shall be assessed in accordance with the other-than-residential fee schedule, and the residential portion shall be assessed in accordance with the residential fee schedule. 
    Condominium: A multi-unit dwelling consisting of separate estates in individual air space units, each of which has an undivided interest in the common elements, if any. 
    Multi-unit dwelling: A building used by two (2) or more families living independently of each other in separate dwelling units. This definition does not include motels or hotels but does include trailer courts with each trailer space considered as one dwelling unit. 
    Other than residential: All utility customers not included under the classifications in this section as single-family or multi-unit dwellings shall be categorized as "other than residential," which includes but is not limited to business, commercial and industrial connections, and recreational facilities appurtenant to residential developments. Business, commercial and industrial developments designed to be sold and occupied in a manner similar to residential condominiums shall be assessed a tap fee pursuant to the "other than residential" schedule of fees. The industrial tap fee shall be based on the total demand of the building or structure. Any increase in total demand resulting from the installation of additional fixtures shall require an additional tap fee. 
    Single-family dwelling: A detached principal building other than a mobile home, designed for or used as a dwelling exclusively by one (1) family. 
    Townhouse: A multi-unit dwelling in which the ownership of each dwelling unit consists of a separate fee simple estate on an individually platted lot, together with an undivided fee simple interest in the common elements, if any. 
(Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2001-17, adopted June 5, 2001, deleted § 95-22 which pertained to violations, and derived from Ord. No. 835, adopted June 6, 1979; and Ord. No. 1994-6, adopted April 19, 1994. 
Sec. 95-23. - Permit. 
    No water reclamation tap shall be made upon any water reclamation main or any other portion of the water reclamation works of the city without first securing a permit therefor. The application for a water reclamation tap permit shall be made in writing upon a form furnished by the director of public works, or his authorized deputy, and shall state clearly the tap size, address and name of the person applying for the tap and any other information which the director of public works may reasonably require. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 1, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-24. - Fee-Required. 
    Any person desiring to connect to the city water reclamation system shall pay to the city a water reclamation tap fee pursuant to the schedule of fees set forth in section 95-25, et seq., of this article and shall pay such other fees as set forth in section 95-24.1. Applicants desiring to connect to and use the city water reclamation system for a proposed building within the city limits shall pay such fee in full at the time of issuance of a building permit or at a time pursuant to Article XIV of Chapter 30 of this Code. Applicants desiring to connect to and use the city's water reclamation system for an existing building in the city limits or any building outside of the city limits, whether existing or proposed, shall pay such fee prior to the time of issuance of a water reclamation connection permit. 
(Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 1990-17, § 3, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-24.1. - Same-Surcharge on application for new water reclamation tap. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby imposed upon every application for a new City of Lafayette water reclamation tap, residential and nonresidential, a surcharge set by resolution of the city council per unit of new construction. The surcharge shall apply to all land (lots, outlots and tracts) platted prior to April 13, 2007, and payment shall be due in full upon application for a building permit for each unit of new construction. 
(b)  Purpose. The aforementioned surcharge shall be used by the City of Lafayette, Colorado, for the sole purpose of developing, constructing and maintaining a storm drain system within and throughout the City of Lafayette, Colorado. 
(Ord. No. 919, §§ 1, 2, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 956, § 1, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 993, § 1, 9-20-83; Ord. No. 1984-32, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 1986-36, § 1, 10-7-86; Ord. No. 1986-42, § 1, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 10, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 40, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 2007-23, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 95-25. - Same-Residential schedule. 
    The residential tap fee schedule shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 2, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 861, § 1, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 896, § 1, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 918, § 1, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 956, § 2, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 1984-32, § 2, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 1985-35, § 1, 12-3-85; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 11, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 41, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 95-26. - Same-Other-than-residential schedule. 
(a)  All water reclamation system customers other than residential, shall pay a tap fee set by resolution of city council. The tap fee shall be based on the size of the water meter used for each property pursuant to section 120-40 of the Code. The actual physical connection size and location shall be solely determined by the public works department. All separate nonresidential irrigation water taps shall not pay water reclamation tap fees. 
(b)  Applicants shall provide all pertinent information necessary for determination of the tap fee as required by the director of public works. Water reclamation tap fees shall be paid at the time the building permit is issued, or at any time prior to the issuance of a building permit, or at a time pursuant to Article XIV of Chapter 30 of this Code. No building permit or water reclamation connection permit shall be released until all public utility requirements have been satisfied, unless deferred as above stated. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 2, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 861, § 2, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 896, § 2, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 1986-36, § 2, 10-7-86; Ord. No. 1990-17, § 5, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 12, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 42, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 95-27. - Same-Out-of-city fees. 
    Tap fees for connections outside the city limits shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 2, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 43, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 95-28. - Same-Payment. 
    The city shall look only to the owner and the owner's successors in interest of each property or building desiring water reclamation service for payment of the water reclamation tap fee. 
(Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-29. - Monthly charges. 
    In the event that a water reclamation tap is issued by the city, but such water reclamation tap is not put to use within one hundred eighty (180) days of issuance, the applicant shall be responsible for and liable for payment of minimum monthly water reclamation service charges as set forth in Article III of this chapter until such time as the tap is put to actual use. 
(Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 1986-44, § 1, 12-2-86; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 13, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-30. - Changes in use. 
    If a water reclamation system user applies for and obtains permission to make changes or additions to the property that would affect the demand on the water reclamation system, a new permit to use the water reclamation system shall be required. The water reclamation system tap fee for such permit shall be computed on the basis of the new service as determined by the schedule of fees set forth in this article. Credit shall be given for the current amount of the tap fee required for the use of the water reclamation system prior to the changes or additions to the property. Credit shall also be allowed for approved decreases in the amount of the water reclamation system service. Under no circumstances shall the city be required to pay cash refunds for either decreases in the amount of water reclamation system service provided or for allowable credits in excess of the new water reclamation system tap fee. Credits allowed herein shall apply only to the property served by the existing water reclamation system service and shall be applied only to the water reclamation system tap fees owed to the city and not to other utility fees or charges. 
(Ord. No. 835, § 1, 6-6-79; Ord. No. 1989-41, § 1, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Secs. 95-31-95-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SERVICE CHARGES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Power of council to fix and collect utility rates and charges, §§ 13.4, 13.5. 
State Law reference- Power of city to prescribe and collect sewer service charges, § 31-35-402, C.R.S. 1973. 

Sec. 95-46. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to generate sufficient revenue to pay all costs for the operations and maintenance (including replacement) costs of the city water reclamation system. Costs shall be allocated to all users in proportion to each user's contribution to the total loading of the treatment works. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 2, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-47. - Classification of uses. 
    There shall be two (2) classifications of users of the city water reclamation system, residential and nonresidential. Nonresidential users may be assigned residential classification by the director of public works provided that the effluent strength from such user does not exceed the effluent strength of an average residential user. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 3, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, §§ 2, 3, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-48. - Components. 
    Each user of the city's water reclamation system shall be assessed charges on a monthly basis for the use of the water reclamation system. Such charges shall consist of a basic monthly service charge, a charge based on the volume of average residential strength effluent discharged, and a surcharge for all nonresidential users discharging wastes in excess of average residential strength. Charges for out-of-the-city service shall be set by resolution of city council. For the purpose of this section, a "unit" is defined as an independent dwelling unit. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 955, § 1, 9-21-82; Ord. No. 1986-40, § 1, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 2000-44, §§ 2, 3, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 44, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 95-49. - Basic monthly charge. 
    The basic monthly residential and nonresidential charges shall defray the fixed costs of operating the city water reclamation system and be set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 618, § 2, 3-19-74; Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 1986-40, § 2, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 1989-58, § 1, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2000-51, § 1, 12-16-00; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 45, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 95-50. - Average residential effluent strength. 
    Average residential effluent strength is as follows: 
Three hundred (300) mg/l biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), or five hundred (500) mg/l chemical oxygen demand (COD) 
Three hundred (300) mg/l suspended solids (SS) 
Thirty (30) mg/l ammonia nitrogen 
(Ord. No. 842, § 4, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 3, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2001-17, § 2, 6-5-01) 
Sec. 95-51. - Quality surcharge. 
    The quality surcharge shall defray the costs of collecting and treating effluent in excess of average residential strength. When in the judgment of the director of public works, a user's discharge exceeds average residential strength, the director of public works is authorized to take such measures as may be necessary to determine the amount of excess strength and to compute a quality surcharge to be assessed as set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 3, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2001-17, § 3, 6-5-01; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 46, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 92-52. - Bills-Mailing; contents. 
    Bills for water reclamation service charges shall be mailed in conjunction with water bills, pursuant to the billing and payment provisions contained in section 120-61 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 622, § 4, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 842, § 6, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 14, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-53. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 15 of Ord. No. 2000-44, adopted Nov. 21, 2000, deleted § 95-53, which pertained to notice of delinquent bills, and derived from Ord. No. 622, adopted April 24, 1974; Ord. No. 842, adopted June 19, 1979; and Ord. No. 1984-05, adopted March 6, 1984. 
Sec. 95-54. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 16 of Ord. No. 2000-44, adopted Nov. 21, 2000, deleted § 95-53, which pertained to lien for delinquent bills, and derived from Ord. No. 622, adopted April 24, 1974; and Ord. No. 842, adopted June 19, 1979. 
Sec. 95-55. - Volume charge-Generally. 
    The volume charge under this article shall defray the marginal costs of collecting and treating the effluent discharge by each user. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 3, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-56. - Same-Users with consistent monthly flows. 
    The volume for all users with consistent monthly effluent flows shall be based on the number of thousand (1,000) gallons of water consumed during an average winter month. Water consumed during an average winter month shall be the average consumption on the November, December and January bills of the previous winter for those accounts with some consumption during each of the three (3) billing periods. For accounts with no consumption in one or more of the billing periods, an average may be established using historical use records or other available data for the type of customer. The average for billing purposes shall be redetermined in March of each year. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 1986-40, § 3, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 3, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-57. - Same-Users with inconsistent monthly flows. 
    When in the judgment of the director of public works, a user's discharge under this article is such that the volume charge based on the average number of thousand (1,000) gallons of water consumed during a winter month is not representative of the user's true volume contribution to the system, the director of public works is authorized to take such measures as may be necessary to determine the user's actual volume contribution and to compute a volume charge based on such volume contribution. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79) 
Sec. 95-58. - Same-New users; changes. 
    For any new user connecting to the city's water reclamation system, or for a user making a change in the use of his premises or making a substantial expansion of his premises, the director of public works or his duly authorized agent shall make an estimate of water consumed during an average winter month based upon a count of plumbing fixtures, consumption of similar users or such other information which under all the circumstances is relevant in making such a determination. Such estimate when made shall be used in charging for water reclamation service for that connection until the next May. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-59. - Same-Water from noncity sources. 
    The director of public works may require of any user of the water reclamation system that water used from wells or sources other than the water system of the city shall be metered, or he shall otherwise determine a reasonable method to be used to establish the water reclamation service charges to any such user. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 5, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-60. - Same-Amount. 
    The monthly volume charge per one thousand gallons (1,000) gallons of usage shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 1986-40, § 4, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 1989-58, § 2, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 2000-51, § 2, 12-16-00; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 47, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 95-61. - Review and revision. 
    The city administrator shall cause a review of the total annual cost of operation and maintenance of the water reclamation system as well as each user's estimated contribution no less than every two (2) years. Water reclamation service charges shall be revised, as necessary, to assure that the purpose set forth in this article is properly implemented. 
(Ord. No. 842, § 7, 6-19-79; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 2, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-62. - Rate regulation of city wastewater services. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a landlord to charge a tenant any amount for wastewater services which is greater than the amount charged for such class of customer by the city. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall prohibit landlords of multi-unit dwellings and multi-unit residential structures, exempt from the city's independent water metering requirements, from charging tenants a monthly amount to reimburse such landlord for the cost of supplying wastewater services for the term of the lease. 
(c)  The method of determining such amount and documentation supporting same shall be disclosed to the city upon its request and must, in the city's determination, be a reasonable estimate of the landlord's per capita or per dwelling unit cost to supply wastewater services based on previous usage rates and current water reclamation rates. 
(d)  The city has the authority to audit, upon reasonable notice, a landlord's records to ensure the landlord's wastewater charges are in compliance with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010-29, § 1, 12-7-10) 
Secs. 95-63-95-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - USE REGULATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 866, §§ 1-9, adopted Feb. 19, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as Art. IV, §§ 95-71-95-79, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 95-71. - Purpose. 
(a)  Generally. This article is enacted to protect, preserve and promote the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City of Lafayette, to provide with respect thereto for the mandatory hookup of sources of effluent within the city to the city's water reclamation system, to protect the capacity of the system by preventing the hookup of noneffluent sources and by requiring disconnection of existing noneffluent sources thereof, to ensure that new connections are properly designed by providing for a system of plan approval and on-site inspection and to protect the water reclamation facility and all related mains, laterals and equipment, the city's workers, the organisms used in treatment of effluent and the waters of the state by providing for either pretreatment and/or the nonintroduction of hazardous or deleterious substances into the city's system. 
(b)  Strict liability. The Lafayette City Council, recognizing the threats upon the frail ecology and expressing great concern for its protection, declares that merely committing any act prohibited by this Chapter 95 and/or orders of the city issued under the provisions of this chapter, or failing to perform any act required by this chapter or said orders of the city constitutes a violation of this chapter. The violator's intent is not a defense to any violation of this chapter or said order of the city, but intent may be considered as a matter in determining aggravation or mitigation. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 1, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 17, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2001-17, § 4, 6-5-01) 
Sec. 95-72. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Act or the Act shall mean the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, 33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq., as amended. 
    Applicant shall mean the owner of the premises for which any permit is applied for or a person authorized in writing by such owner to act in his behalf with regard to such permit. 
    Best professional judgment shall mean the highest quality technical opinion developed after consideration of all reasonably available and pertinent data or information. 
    BMP or best management practice shall mean any reasonable practice or procedure deemed necessary by the city to prevent, abate or remedy the consequences of the introduction of unlawful pollutants or concentration of pollutants into the POTW by an industrial or commercial user to the extent technically and economically practical. 
    BOD or biochemical oxygen demand shall mean the quality of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain shall mean that part of the lower horizontal piping of a drainage system that receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building water reclamation conduit beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building water reclamation conduit shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public water reclamation conduit or other place of disposal, also called house connection. 
    City shall mean the City of Lafayette, Colorado. 
    Clean Water Act or Federal Water Pollution Control Act shall mean 33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq., as amended. 
    COD or chemical oxygen demand shall mean the measure of the oxygen equivalent of that portion of organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidant under laboratory procedures. 
    Combined conduit shall mean a water reclamation conduit intended to receive both effluent and storm or surface water. 
    Deleterious wastes shall mean any wastes contained in effluent that would be harmful or damaging to the city's water reclamation system or to the water reclamation process used by the city. 
    Domestic effluent shall mean the effluent derived principally from dwellings, business buildings and institutions. It is equivalent to normal effluent. 
    Easement shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others whether required by written conveyance, prescription or otherwise. 
    Effluent shall mean the combination of liquid or water-carried waste conducted away from residences, business buildings and institutions that is known as domestic effluent, together with the liquid or water-carried waste resulting from manufacturing process employed in industrial establishments, including the washing, cleaning or drain water form such process, that is known as industrial waste. 
    Floatable oil is oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from effluent by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. Effluent shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated, and the effluent does not interfere with the collection system. 
    FOG or fats, oil and grease shall mean any hydrocarbons, fatty acids, soaps, fats, waxes, oils and any other material that is extracted in accordance with EPA approved methodology. 
    Garbage shall mean the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
    Hazardous or toxic materials shall mean all materials identifiable as hazardous waste or a toxic substance under the terms of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, 42 U.S.C. sections 6901-6987, Pub. L. 94-580, specifically any substance which qualifies under the regulations issued pursuant to the terms of the act, as found at 40 C.F.R. section 250. 
    Holding tank wastes shall mean any waste from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers and vacuum pump tank trucks. 
    Industrial wastes shall mean the effluent from industrial processes, trade, or business as distinct from domestic wastes. 
    May is permissive. 
    National categorical pretreatment standards shall mean any regulation developed under the authority of section 307(b) of the Act and 40 CFR section 403.6. 
    National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) shall mean the program for issuing, conditioning and denying permits for the discharge of pollutants from point sources into the navigable waters of the contiguous zone and the oceans pursuant to section 402 of the Act. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet, including storm drains and combined conduit overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    Permit shall mean any written authorization required pursuant to the provisions of this Code or by any other rule, regulation or ordinance of the city for the installation, operation or use of any water reclamation facilities. 
    Person shall mean any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of seven (7) and a hydrogen-ion concentration of 10 -7 . 
    Properly shredded garbage shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public water reclamation conduits with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public water reclamation conduit shall mean a common water reclamation conduit controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
    Publicly-owned treatment works (POTW) shall mean that portion of the water reclamation treatment system owned by the city. This definition includes any water reclamation line that conveys effluent to the water reclamation plant, except private lines. For the purposes of this chapter, the term POTW shall also include any water reclamation line that conveys effluent to the POTW from persons outside the POTW boundaries who are by contract or agreement with the city, users of the POTW. The POTW is located at 750 East County Line Road, Lafayette, Colorado. 
    Septage shall mean wastes removed from a septic tank. 
    Shall is mandatory. 
    Slug shall mean any discharge of water or effluent that in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the water reclamation plant. 
    Storm drain shall mean a conduit or drain for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water or unpolluted water from any source. 
    Superintendent shall mean the director of public works of the City of Lafayette or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Suspended solids shall mean total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of or is in suspension in water, effluent or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
    Unpolluted water is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the water reclamation facilities provided. 
    User shall mean any person that discharges, causes or permits the discharge of effluent into a public water reclamation conduit. 
    Waste shall include effluent and any and all waste substances, liquid, solid, gaseous or radioactive, associated with human habitation, or of human or animal origin, or from any producing, manufacturing or processing operation of whatever nature, including such waste placed within containers of whatever nature prior to, and for the purpose of, disposal. 
    Watercourse shall mean a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
    Water reclamation conduit shall mean a pipe or channel that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
    Water reclamation facilities shall mean the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away and treat effluent, domestic and industrial wastes and sludge. 
    Water reclamation plant shall mean an arrangement of devices and structures for treating effluent, industrial wastes and sludge. 
    Waters of the state shall mean any water, surface or underground, within the boundaries of the State of Colorado. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 2, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 18, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2001-17, § 5, 6-5-01) 
Sec. 95-73. - Improper disposal of waste; mandatory connection. 
(a)  Improper disposal prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under its jurisdiction any effluent or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge to any stream or water course any domestic or industrial waste water or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Private disposal systems unlawful, certain circumstances. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of effluent. Where a public water reclamation conduit or combined conduit is not available under the terms of this section, construction of any private effluent disposal system shall be governed by the provisions in section 95-76. The owner(s) of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public water reclamation conduit or combined conduit of the city is hereby required at the expense of the owner(s) to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public water reclamation conduit in accordance with the provisions of this article within sixty (60) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public water reclamation conduit is within four hundred (400) feet of the property line. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 3, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 2000-44, §§ 3, 19, 11-21-00) 
Sec. 95-74. - Certain discharges into water reclamation conduits prohibited. 
    The following discharges to water reclamation conduits shall be prohibited: 
(1)  Unpolluted waters, discharge prohibited. Water which is the discharge from sump pumps or which has been used for cooling, heating transfer purposes, condensation, air conditioning, refrigeration or similar use; any storm water drainage from the ground surface, roof leaders, catch basins or any other source, or subsurface drainage or ground water, except in areas of existing combined conduits; it shall be unlawful to discharge through a direct or indirect connection to a public water reclamation conduit without a permit issued by the city unpolluted water of any type not specifically mentioned in this section. 
(2)  Hazardous or toxic materials, discharge prohibited. It shall be unlawful to discharge into the city's water reclamation conduits any "hazardous or toxic materials" as defined at section 95-72. 
(3)  Deleterious materials, discharge prohibited. No person(s) shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described water or wastes to any public water reclamation conduits: 
a.  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. At no time shall two (2) successive readings on any explosion hazard meter, at the point of discharge into the system (or at any point in the system), be more than five (5) percent nor any single reading over ten (10) percent of the Lower Explosive Limit (LEL) of the meter. Fire or explosion hazard may also be determined using flash point concentration, by closed cup method as specified in 40 CFR 261.21. The flashpoint shall not be less than sixty (60) degrees centigrade or one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit; 
b.  Any waters containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any water reclamation process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, exceed the limitation set forth in a National Categorical Pretreatment Standard or create any hazard in or have an adverse effect on the waters receiving any discharge from the water reclamation plant. Toxic pollutants shall include but not be limited to, any pollutant identified pursuant to section 307(a) of the Act. These general discharge prohibitions apply to all such users of a POTW, whether or not the user is subject to National Categorical Pretreatment Standards or any other national, state or local pretreatment standards or requirements; 
c.  Any substance that may cause the POTW's effluent or any other product of the POTW, such as residues, sludges or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with the reclamation process when the POTW is pursuing a reuse and reclamation program. In no case shall a substance discharged to the POTW cause the POTW to be in noncompliance with the sludge use or disposal criteria, guidelines or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal; 
d.  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five point five (5.5) or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the POTW; 
e.  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in water reclamation conduits, or other interference with the proper operation of the waste water facilities such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders; 
f.  Any holding tank waste or septage without a permit issued by the city. Unless otherwise allowed by the city under the terms and conditions of the permit, a separate permit must be secured for each separate discharge. The permit shall state the specific location of discharge, the time of day the discharge is to occur, the volume of the discharge and the waste water constituents and characteristics. If a permit is granted for discharge of such waste into the public water reclamation system, the permittee shall pay the applicable charges and fees and shall meet such other conditions as required and set forth by the city; 
g.  Any substance that will cause the POTW to violate its NPDES permit or any receiving water quality standards; 
h.  Any effluent with objectionable color not removable in the treatment process such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions; 
i.  Any water or waste containing free or floating oil and grease; 
j.  Pollutants that result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems; or 
k.  Any material or substance not specifically mentioned in this section that in itself is corrosive, irritating, or noxious to human beings or animals, or that by interaction with other water or waste in the public sewer system could produce undesirable effects or create any other condition deleterious to structures, treatment processes or quantity of the receiving stream. 
(4)  Limited discharge materials. The following-described substances, materials, waters or waste shall be limited in discharges to municipal systems to concentrations or quantities which will not harm either the water reclamation conduits, water reclamation process or equipment, will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or will not otherwise endanger lives, limb, public property or constitute a nuisance. The superintendent may set limitations lower than the limitations established in the regulations below if, in his opinion, such more severe limitations are necessary to meet the above objectives. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of the discharge, the superintendent will give consideration to such factors as the quantity of subject waste in relation to flows and velocities in the water reclamation conduits, materials of construction of the water reclamation conduits, the water reclamation process employed, capacity of the water reclamation plant, degree or treatability of the waste in the water reclamation plant and other pertinent factors. The limitations or restrictions on materials or characteristics of waste or effluent discharged to the water reclamation system which shall not be violated without approval of the superintendent are as follows: 
a.  Effluent having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit or sixty-five (65) degrees Celsius; 
b.  Effluent containing petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oils or products of mineral oil origin in amounts that will either interfere with or pass through the POTW; 
c.  Any water or waste that contains grease or oil or any other substances that will solidify or become discernibly viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit (0 degrees Celsius) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (65.5 degrees Celsius); 
d.  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded as defined in section 95-72, "properly shredded garbage". Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary water reclamation conduits from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering establishments or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers; 
e.  Any waters or wastes containing concentrations of any toxic or objectionable substance which exceed standards which have been established by the city, whether or not a hazardous or toxic material under section 95-74(b); 
f.  Any waters or wastes containing odor-producing substances exceeding limits which may be established by the superintendent; 
g.  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
h.  Quantities of flow, concentrations or both which constitute a "slug" as defined herein; 
i.  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the waste water treatment processes employed or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the waste water treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters; 
j.  Any water or wastes which by interaction with other water or wastes in the public water reclamation system release obnoxious gases, form suspended solids which interfere with the collection system or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. 
k.  Any effluent containing BOD, COD, total solids, suspended solids, ammonia nitrogen (or substances readily converted thereto), or FOG of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the water reclamation plant; provided, however, that a user may be permitted by specific, written agreement with the city to discharge such BOD, COD, TSS, ammonia nitrogen, or oil and grease, which agreement may provide for special charges, surcharges, payments or provisions for treating and testing equipment. 
(5)  Federal categorical pretreatment standards. Upon the promulgation of the Federal Categorical Pretreatment Standards for a particular industrial subcategory, the federal standard, if more stringent than limitations imposed herein for sources in that subcategory, shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed herein. The city shall notify all affected users of the applicable reporting requirements. 
(6)  Specific pollutant limitations. It is unlawful for any person to discharge effluent containing pollutants in excess of the limitations on discharge, as set forth below: 
Pollutant Concentration (mg/l) Arsenic, Total (As) 0.022 Cadmium, Total (Cd) 0.023 Chromium (Cr III), trivalent 0.097 Copper, Total (Cu) 0.40 Lead, Total (Pb) 0.52 Manganese (Mn), total 1.33 Mercury, Total (Hg) 0.0002 Molybdenum (Mo) 0.14 Nickel, Total (Ni) 0.31 Selenium, Total (Se) 0.032 Zinc, Total (Zn) 2.74  
(7)  State requirements. State requirements and limitations on discharges shall apply in any case where they are more stringent than federal requirements and limitations or those contained therein. 
(8)  POTW's right of revision. The city may establish by ordinance more stringent limitations or requirements on discharges to the POTW, if it is deemed necessary to comply with the purpose presented in section 95-71. 
(9)  Excessive discharge. It is unlawful for any user to increase the use of process water or to attempt in any way to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with any applicable limitations. 
(10)  Accidental discharges. 
a.  Each user shall provide protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other substances regulated herein. Facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the user's own cost and expense. In the case of an accidental discharge, it is the responsibility of the user immediately to notify the city and the POTW of the incident. Notification shall include the location of discharge, type of waste, concentration, volume and any corrective actions. Within five (5) days following an accidental discharge, the user shall submit to the city a detailed written report describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall neither relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage, or other liability that may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, fish kills, or any other damage to persons or property, which such user shall be liable therefor, nor shall such notification relieve the user of any fines, civil penalties, or other liability that may be imposed by this chapter or other applicable law. If the POTW is fined by the state or federal government for violation of the POTW's NPDES permit or violation of water quality standards as the result of a spill or intentional slug discharge of a toxic pollutant, then such fine, including all POTW legal, sampling, analytical testing costs and any other costs shall be charged to the responsible user. 
b.  A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees whom to call in the event of an accidental discharge. Employers shall ensure that all employees who may observe, cause or suffer such an accidental discharge to occur are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
(11)  Notification of discharge required. All nonresidential dischargers shall notify the superintendent of the nature of their business or activity, so that an assessment may be made as to any potential impacts on the water reclamation system. The user shall provide any additional information as deemed necessary by the superintendent. 
(12)  Alternatives available to superintendent. If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public water reclamation conduits which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in this article and which in the judgment of the superintendent may have a deleterious effect upon the water reclamation facilities, processes, equipment or receiving waters or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may: 
a.  Reject the wastes; 
b.  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public water reclamation conduits; 
c.  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
d.  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or water reclamation charges as provided for by city ordinance. 
When considering the above alternative, the superintendent shall give consideration to the economic impact of each alternative on the discharger. 
(13)  Pretreatment or other facilities, cost to owner. Where pretreatment or flow-equalizing facilities are required for any waters or wastes, such facilities shall be provided or installed by the owner(s) at his expense, and they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner(s) at his expense. 
a.  Amalgam separator required. 
1.  Definitions. For the purpose of this section the following words and phrases shall mean as follows: 
"Amalgam" means any mixture or blending of mercury with another metal or with an alloy used in dental applications. 
"Amalgam separator" means a type of wastewater treatment equipment that is designed to remove amalgam particles and dissolved mercury from the wastewater discharged by dental practices. 
"Amalgam waste" means any waste containing mercury or residues from the preparation of amalgam. This includes any waste generated or collected by chair-side traps, screens, filters, vacuum system filters, amalgam separators, elemental mercury, or amalgam capsules. 
(i)  "Noncontact amalgam" includes scrap or excess amalgam after a procedure is completed, as well as the remaining amalgam capsule. 
(ii)  "Contact amalgam" means scrap that has come into contact with a patient or body fluids. Examples include: extracted teeth and scrap collected in chair-side traps and vacuum pump filters. 
"Best management practices" (BMPs) means a set of operational standards designed to minimize the environmental impact and human exposure to mercury. 
"Dental practice" means any dental facility that discharges wastewater from the placement or removal of amalgam. 
"Exempt dental practice" means any dental facility in which no dentist places or removes amalgams and/or teeth containing amalgams. 
2.  [Compliance; waiver.] 
A.  Any dental practice that discharges wastewater generated from the placement or removal of amalgam shall, within six (6) months from the effective date of this ordinance, implement and certify to the superintendent compliance with the BMPs set forth in this section. The dental practice shall also, within one (1) year from the effective date of this ordinance, install, operate and maintain an amalgam separator in accordance with the requirements set forth in this section. 
B.  Waivers will be granted by the superintendent to exempt dental practices. To receive a waiver a dental practice must submit a written waiver request to the superintendent within six (6) months of the effective date of this ordinance. 
3.  [Amalgam separator requirements.] Amalgam separators shall meet the following requirements: 
A.  Amalgam separator design. An amalgam separator shall be International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 11143 certified and shall be designed and approved for a flow rate capable of handling the maximum volume discharged from the dental practice it serves. 
(i)  The amalgam separator must be tested according to the most current ISO 11143 standard. Each dental practice shall select a separator with the highest efficiency level attainable for the practice's working conditions. 
(ii)  If ISO increases the acceptable standard, the dental practice must comply with the new standard within five (5) years of ISO's adoption. 
B.  Installation. The amalgam separator shall be installed so that all amalgam-contaminated wastewater will pass through the unit before being discharged into any water reclamation conduit. 
C.  Inspection and maintenance. Each dental practice shall be responsible for inspection and maintenance of the amalgam separator. 
D.  Disposal. Waste removed from the amalgam separator shall be collected and handled in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions and as described in the BMPs for this section. 
4.  Best management practices. Every dental practice shall comply with the following BMPs: 
A.  Equipment. The dental practice shall ensure that all dental chairs are equipped with chair-side traps and that all vacuum pumps are equipped with traps and filters. All equipment shall be cleaned and maintained in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. 
B.  Clean-up procedures. The dental practice shall use nonchlorine or nonoxidizing disinfectants and neutral cleaners. When cleaning filters or collecting scrap amalgam, the dental practice shall not rinse filters or traps over sinks or drains. Each dental practice shall maintain a mercury spill kit and train all staff on clean-up procedures. Spilled amalgam must be cleaned up immediately in accordance with the most current Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) procedures as set forth in: http://www.epa.gov/epaoswer/hazwaste/mercury/faq/spills.htm 
C.  Salvaging. All contact and noncontact scrap amalgam shall be salvaged and stored in structurally sound, tightly closed and appropriately labeled containers. 
D.  Disposal. The dental practice shall not dispose of any amalgam waste. All amalgam waste shall be removed from the dental practice only by an authorized amalgam waste recycler. 
5.  Record keeping and reporting. 
A.  Record keeping. The dental practice shall maintain records of the disposition of all amalgam waste. The records shall include the name, address and telephone number of the amalgam waste recycler including the dates and amounts of amalgam waste delivered to the amalgam waste recycler. The dental practice shall also maintain records of all service and maintenance of the amalgam separator. All records shall be kept on site for a minimum of three (3) years and shall be made available to the superintendent upon request. 
B.  Reporting. Each year, no later than February 15, the dental practice shall submit to the superintendent a certification of compliance. The certification shall include: 
(i)  Amalgam separator compliance. The dental practice shall include the following information: the manufacturer and model name of the amalgam separator, the date of installation, the name, address and telephone number of the company which installed the unit or performed any service or maintenance and the name, address and telephone number of the amalgam recycler used by the dental practice. 
(ii)  BMPs compliance certification. To ensure compliance with the BMPs the dental practice shall sign a self-certification of the BMPs implemented at the dental practice. The certification shall be signed by all practicing dentists. The dental practice shall also report any change in its operations regarding BMPs or the use and maintenance of the amalgam separator. All certifications shall be sent to: 
Water Reclamation Division 
City of Lafayette 
1290 S. Public Road 
Lafayette, CO 80026 
(14)  Oil and grease interceptor installation. 
a.  Grease interceptor installation. Grease interceptors are required for all facilities used and operated regularly for the sale of prepared food, including but not limited to restaurants, cafes, fast food outlets, pizza outlets, delicatessens, sandwich shops and any and all other kinds and types of food vending establishments in which any food preparation (including heating or defrosting in or by means of any kind of oven or heating device) takes place on the premises, whether or not such facilities are located in a separate building or structure or occupy space in a building or structure that is occupied by other businesses, and including schools, churches, boardinghouses with communal kitchen facilities, nursing homes, and day care centers that have kitchens and engage in the preparation of food. In addition, meat cutting facilities and other facilities capable of discharging significant amounts of grease into the POTW shall be required to install grease interceptors. The exception shall be those facilities granted a variance by the city. Grease interceptors shall not be required for any private residence or dwelling unless a commercial use exists within the residence or dwelling that generates amounts of grease beyond that generated by a residential dwelling. 
b.  Grease interceptor sizing criteria. The city shall promulgate rules, regulations and criteria for grease interceptor sizing. 
c.  Inspection of grease interceptors. The city shall establish an inspection program for grease interceptors. The city shall develop rules and regulations to inventory all grease interceptors and document the inspections of these interceptors. 
d.  Grease interceptor pumping schedules. All users connected to grease interceptors will be required to pump out their interceptors at intervals determined in rules, regulations and criteria promulgated by the city. 
e.  Biological treatment. Biological treatment shall not be a substitute for the pumping of the grease interceptor. Biological treatment may be permitted in cases in which the superintendent has specifically approved such treatment. Standards for such approval shall be set by the superintendent. 
f.  Existing sources not connected to grease interceptors. Sources existing prior to June 15, 2001, not connected to grease interceptors and that may potentially contribute significant amounts shall be identified through such means as site inspections, discharge sampling and inspection of the collection system. Once these sources are identified, they will be required to implement best management practices (BMPs) to keep oil and grease out of the water reclamation system. The city shall promulgate rules, regulations and criteria for BMPs. 
g.  Failure to pass inspection. If the BMPs are not successful at the facility and the facility continues to contribute significant amounts of oil and grease to the sanitary sewer, as documented by field inspections, then the facility will be required to install an adequately sized grease collection device. 
h.  Right of entry. Whenever it is necessary to make an inspection to enforce any provision of this section 95-74(14), or whenever the city believes that there exists on any premises subject to this section any condition or violation with regard to the use and maintenance of oil and grease interceptors, city personnel may enter such premises to inspect the same provided that such personnel present proper credentials or otherwise have grounds for a search warrant exception as may be authorized by law. If requested entry be refused, the city shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry, including an issuance of an administrative warrant from the municipal court or from the District Court of the State of Colorado having jurisdiction. 
(15)  Information may be required. The superintendent may require a user of water reclamation services to provide information needed to determine compliance with this article. The superintendent may also require that such information be submitted to the city in the form of a periodic or regularly scheduled report. These requirements may include: 
a.  Effluent discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period; 
b.  Chemical analyses of effluent; 
c.  Information on raw materials, processes and products affecting effluent volume and quality; 
d.  Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent or other materials important to water reclamation conduit use control; 
e.  A plot plan of water reclamation conduits of the user's property showing water reclamation and pretreatment facility location; 
f.  Details of effluent pretreatment facilities; 
g.  Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the municipal water reclamation system. 
(16)  Special agreements not prohibited. No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment. 
(17)  Discharge permits may be required. Nonresidential dischargers may be required to obtain a discharge permit, wherein may be specified conditions and other agreements relating to specific use of the water reclamation system by said discharger. A permit fee sufficient to pay for any costs of administering the discharge permit shall be specified by the superintendent, and paid by the discharger. Standards for such permits shall be set by the superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 4, 2-19-80; Ord. No. 2000-44, §§ 2, 5-7, 20, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2001-17, §§ 6, 7, 6-5-01; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 1, 7-15-03; Ord. No. 2007-11, § 1, 3-20-07; Ord. No. 2014-12, § 1, 4-15-14) 
Sec. 95-75. - Connections to water reclamation system, permits, plans, inspections. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall uncover, make any connection with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public water reclamation conduit or appurtenances, or perform work on, or construct, a building water reclamation conduit or lateral without first applying for and obtaining a written permit from the city and paying all fees and connection charges as required therefor. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. The applicant's signature on the application for any permit shall constitute an agreement to comply with all of the provisions, terms and requirements of this article and other ordinances, rules and regulations of the city and with the plans and specifications filed with the application, if any, together with such corrections or modifications as may be made or permitted by the city, if any. Such agreement shall be binding upon the applicant and may be altered only by the city in writing. 
(b)  Costs, protection, maintenance, repair, and replacement. 
(1)  All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building water reclamation conduit shall be borne by the owner(s). The owner(s) shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of a building water reclamation conduit. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the owner of any property using the Lafayette water reclamation system and the lessee of any such property to protect, maintain, repair, and replace the water reclamation service pipe as may be necessary in order to allow said water reclamation service pipe to function in an acceptable manner. For the purpose of this section "water reclamation service pipe" is defined as that pipe commencing at the water reclamation main and extending to the building or other appurtenance. It shall further be the duty of said persons to pay all costs of protection, maintenance, repair, and replacement of the water reclamation service pipe and the city shall have, for the security of the collection of such charges, a lien upon the real property served by such water reclamation service pipe which lien may be collected pursuant to section 95-54 of this chapter. 
(c)  Separate building water reclamation conduits required. A separate and independent building water reclamation conduit shall be provided for every building; except where one (1) building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private water reclamation conduit is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building water reclamation conduit from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building water reclamation conduit, but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. Old building water reclamation conduits may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this article. 
(d)  Use of proper materials and construction techniques. The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of all water reclamation conduits, including building water reclamation conduits, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of suitable code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M. and W.P.C.F. Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. Whenever possible, the building water reclamation conduit shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public water reclamation conduit, effluent carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building water reclamation conduit. No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public water reclamation conduit unless such connection is approved by the superintendent for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. The connection of the building water reclamation conduit into the public water reclamation conduit shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M. and the W.P.C.F. Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the superintendent before installation. 
(e)  Inspection. The applicant for the building water reclamation conduit permit shall notify the superintendent when the building water reclamation conduit is ready for inspection and connection to the public water reclamation system. The connection and testing shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent or his representative. 
(f)  Safety precautions. All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
