Chapter 120 - WATER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Municipal utilities, Ch. XIII; authority of city to acquire water, water rights and water storage rights, § 16.8. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 30; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 45; nuisances, Ch. 70; sewers, Ch. 95; connection to utilities, § 90-32. 
State Law reference- Municipal water utility, C. R. S. § 31-15-707, 708; C. R. S. Title 31, Art. 35. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 120-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Accessory dwelling unit: A detached dwelling unit located on the same lot as the principal dwelling unit, and regulated by Chapter 26 of this Code. 
    Apartment: A multiunit dwelling under a common ownership consisting of one (1) or more rental units. 
    Building: "Building" as used herein for purposes of applying the schedule of charges means an independent structure standing alone, excluding fences. To qualify as one (1) building, all portions, additions or extensions shall be connected by an attachment that is an enclosed part of the building and which is usable by the occupants thereof. 
    Combined uses: Developments with combined residential and other than residential uses in the same structure or building. 
    Commercial: Any nonresidential use of water. 
    Condominium: Any multiunit dwelling consisting of separate estates in individual air space units, each of which has an undivided interest in the common elements, if any. 
    Consumer: Any person, firm or corporation receiving water from the city waterworks. 
    Irrigation service: A metered water service within the city limits that supplies potable water and which water is used solely for irrigation purposes and consequently does not contribute effluent into the city's water reclamation system by supplying such water to a structure capable of or currently housing water reclamation facilities. 
    Mains: The main pipes; and connections forming a part of the city waterworks. 
    Multiunit dwelling: A building used by two (2) or more families living independently of each other in separate dwelling units. This definition does not include motels or hotels but does include trailer courts with each trailer space considered as one (1) dwelling unit. 
    Multiunit residential structures: This term includes multiunit dwellings, townhouses, apartments and condominiums. 
    Other than residential: All utility customers not included under the classifications in this section as single-family or multiunit dwellings shall be categorized as "other than residential," which includes but is not limited to business, commercial and industrial connections, and recreational facilities appurtenant to residential developments. 
    Service pipe: A branch pipe with its fittings and connections through which water is taken. 
    Single-family dwelling: A detached principal building other than a mobile home, designed for or used as a dwelling exclusively by one (1) family. 
    Street: Any street, avenue, alley, land or other thoroughfare. 
    Townhouse: A multiunit dwelling in which the ownership of each dwelling unit consists of a separate fee simple estate on an individually platted lot, together with an undivided fee simple interest in the common elements, if any. 
    Water district: A duly formed and existing water district which is formed and existing pursuant to applicable statutes of the State of Colorado. 
    Water service: A connection to the city waterworks and the ability to be served by the city waterworks. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 1(a-f), 4-24-74; Ord. No. 1997-6, § 1, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 1999-50, § 1, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 1, 7-15-03) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to water system, C. R. S. § 31-35-401. 
Sec. 120-2. - Policies and procedures. 
    The director of public works and/or the director of finance may establish policies and procedures for any matters not addressed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1999-50, § 2, 1-4-2000) 
Sec. 120-3. - Extensions-Subdivisions. 
(a)  The developer of any subdivision desiring water service from the city shall pay the entire cost of extending the city water service to his subdivision and shall deed to the city all mains and service connections required to serve his subdivision. The city shall pay for any oversizing of pipe which is required as a result of any master plan adopted by the city for service of water to any area either within or outside of the existing city limits. All extensions shall conform to city specifications. 
(b)  For subdivisions inside or outside the city limits, the city's main extension policy shall be as follows: 
(1)  The city will extend or require the subdivider to extend the required water main to the subdivision to be served. If the subdivider is required to extend the main, then the city will negotiate a repayment agreement with the subdivider which will allow said subdivider to recoup as much of the cost of the extension between the boundary of his subdivision and the nearest properly sized city water main as can be agreed upon. It shall be the city's policy that the subdivider shall pay for the extensions of any water line for his subdivision. 
(2)  In the event no agreement can be made between the city and the subdivider, then the city shall not be responsible to extend the main. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 7, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 1997-6, § 3, 5-20-97) 
State Law reference- Construction of water mains, C. R. S. § 31-35-301 et seq. 
Sec. 120-4. - Same-Individuals. 
    Any individual desiring an extension of the city water system to serve his private property shall pay the entire cost of extending the city water service to his property and shall deed to the city all water lines and improvements necessary to extend the service to his property. The city shall pay the cost of any oversizing of pipe which the city requires to serve any individual property as a result of any master plan which is adopted by the city for water service within or outside of the existing city limits. All extensions shall be approved by the city and conform to city specifications. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 8, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 1997-6, § 4, 5-20-97) 
State Law reference- Construction of water mains, C. R. S. § 31-35-301. 
Sec. 120-5. - Oversize line. 
    If the size line required to serve a subdivision or individual is smaller than the size line the city wishes installed for sound future planning, then the city will participate in the oversizing of the pipe from a minimum of six (6) inches to the size the city desires to be installed. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 17, 4-24-74) 
Sec. 120-6. - Water line modifications. 
(a)  The city recognizes its responsibilities as relates to water service to existing, developed, platted property within the city which is already served by water mains and fire hydrants which may be inadequate for conformance with sound engineering and public safety standards. When necessity arises for enlarging or replacing or otherwise upgrading the water distribution system in an existing, platted, developed area already served by city water, the improvements will be made by the city. If such improvements are made necessary by the development of a new subdivision which is to be served by a water main passing through an area described above, then the city may require the developer to negotiate a participation agreement with the city for the cost of the improvements. 
(b)  For an individual property owner desiring water service on an undeveloped, unplatted area of the city, where city water mains do not exist, the city's policy will be the same for the individual as for a subdivision in the same circumstance. 
(Ord. No. 621, §§ 15, 16, 4-24-74) 
Sec. 120-7. - Meters generally. 
    All water meters shall be set in place and kept in repair by the city, and shall be and remain the property of the city and under its control. The size and type of meter will be determined by calculations and criteria set by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 9, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 1997-6, § 5, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 1999-50, § 3, 1-4-2000) 
Sec. 120-7.1. - Independent metering. 
(a)  As of the effective date of this ordinance [October 10, 2001], all new consumers of city water services shall be independently metered, with the following consumers exempted: 
(1)  Water service customers who, prior to the effective date of this ordinance [October 10, 2001], live in multiunit dwellings and multiunit residential structures on a single master meter where an agent acts for the payment of water bills and water maintenance charges for the consumer owners are exempt from independent water metering, as long as the agent carries out all responsibilities of the owners in a timely manner; and 
(2)  Water service consumers in "other than residential" uses, as that term is defined in section 120-36 of this Code. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to require that consumers exempted in subsection (a) of this section be independently metered should those consumers or their agents not fill their responsibilities under this chapter in a timely or effective manner. 
(Ord. No. 1996-16, § 1, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2001-37, § 1, 10-2-01) 
Sec. 120-7.2. - Requirement for conversion. 
(a)  Except where water service consumers are exempted from the requirement of independent metering pursuant to sections 120-7.1 or 120-7.3 of this Code, the city shall convert all shared water meters to independent water meters, on such schedule as the city administrator shall determine to be in the best interests of the city. 
(b)  All consumers of city water services who are not independently metered as of the date of enactment of this ordinance, and who are not exempted from the requirement of an independent meter pursuant to section 120-7.1(a) of this Code, shall reimburse the city for the cost of installation of an independent meter, including materials, labor and any other expense necessary to the installation. 
(c)  The city's cost of converting a shared meter into two (2) or more independently metered systems shall be either divided equally between or among those consumers who share the meter, or divided between or among them based on actual individual consumers' conversion costs. The director of public works, based on the particular situation, will determine the appropriate method of cost allocation. 
(d)  An exempted consumer, as described in section 120-7.1 of this Code, who the city determines must be independently metered pursuant to section 120-7.1(b) of this Code, shall reimburse the city for the cost of installation of an independent meter, including materials, labor and any other expense necessary to the installation. 
(Ord. No. 1996-16, § 1, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 1999-50, § 4, 1-4-2000) 
Sec. 120-7.3. - Requirement for conversion; separation of properties. 
(a)  Where two (2) or more dwelling units are owned by one (1) party, either separated by a common wall or as separate buildings, and are served through one (1) service pipe or water meter, upon severing of ownership of the dwelling units, each dwelling unit severed shall thereafter be served by an independent meter. 
(b)  All costs for the service measured by the new meter will be the responsibility of the new owner. 
(c)  The city's cost of converting a shared meter into two (2) or more independently metered systems shall be divided equally between or among the owners of the dwelling units that shared the common meter; said owners shall reimburse the city for the cost of installation of the independent meters, including materials, labor and any other expense necessary to the installation. 
(d)  This section does not apply to the following types of properties existing prior to the effective date of this ordinance [October 10, 2001]: 
(1)  Water service customers in multiunit dwellings and multiunit residential structures on a single master meter where an agent acts for the payment of water bills and water maintenance charges for the consumer owners, as long as the agent carries out all responsibilities of the owners in a timely manner. 
(e)  The city reserves the right to require that the consumers exempted in subsection (d) of this section be independently metered should those consumers or their agents not fulfill their responsibilities under this chapter in a timely or effective manner. 
(Ord. No. 1996-16, § 1, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 2001-37, § 2, 10-2-01) 
Sec. 120-7.4. - Payment of costs of conversion. 
    The city administrator may, in his discretion, authorize that the costs of conversion to an independent meter be paid by the water service consumer in installments, without interest, over such period of time as the city administrator may deem appropriate or necessary. The city administrator may, in his discretion, authorize that a discount of the costs of conversion be given to any water service consumer who pays the costs of conversion in a lump sum at the time of conversion. The costs of conversion to an independent meter shall constitute a water service charge which shall be paid and shall be subject to collection pursuant to Code section 120-61. 
(Ord. No. 1996-16, § 1, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 120-8. - Protection, maintenance, repair, and replacement of water meter and service pipe. 
(a)  Meters. It shall be the duty of the water consumer, the fee owner of the property being served with the city water, and the lessee of any such property to use all necessary precaution to keep the water meter from freezing and to protect the water meter from any damage from freezing or any damage caused by the negligence of any person, and if the meter shall be injured or damaged by freezing or by the negligence of any person, then such persons, above named, shall pay all necessary costs of repair or replacement and the failure to pay such costs of repair or replacement shall warrant and authorize the city in turning off the water to the property. 
(b)  Service pipes. It shall be the duty of the water consumer, the fee owner of the property being served with city water, and the lessee of any such property to maintain and to use all necessary precaution to keep the water service pipe which service pipe is defined as that pipe commencing at the water main and extending to the building or other appurtenance being served by water through which water is taken from freezing, and from damage caused by any injury to said service pipe. 
(c)  The maintenance and protection of privately-owned piping, including service pipe and fittings, pressure reducing valves, meter pits, fixtures and water-using appliances, except meters whether located in or upon public or private property, are the sole responsibility of the user, except as otherwise set forth below. The city is not responsible or liable for damage from any cause whatsoever to such piping, fixtures, appurtenances and water-using appliances, and no user is entitled to reimbursement for damages or payment of refunds by reason of pressure changes or stoppage of the flow of water through the system. The protection of water-using devices and systems which requires limited or sustained water pressure or a continual water supply is the responsibility of the user who will provide suitable protective devices, including pressure reducing valves for such apparatus at the owner's expense. The city will make available the following service to permitted premises: 
(1)  Repair of leaks on user service pipes which have curb stops will be performed by the city on that segment of the user's service pipe which lies between the water main and the outlet side of the curb stop. The user will repair all leaks that emanate from the threads on the outlet side of the curb stop and all other service pipe appurtenances on the outlet side of the curb stop. 
(2)  Repair of leaks on user service pipes that have outdoor meters and no curb stop will be performed by the city on that segment of the service pipe which lies between the water main through and including the valve at the inlet side of the meter and the meter-attaching coupling. The user will repair all leaks emanating from the service pipe or any of its appurtenances located on the outlet side of the meter yoke. The user will maintain the meter pit. 
(3)  Repair of leaks in service pipes that do not have curb stops or outdoor meters will be performed by the city only on that portion of the service pipe that is outside the user's property boundary or within a recorded easement for the service pipe. The user will repair all leaks emanating from the service pipe or any of its appurtenances located inside his property line. 
(4)  Repair of leaks on user service pipes which are connected to privately owned fire lines will be performed by the city as set forth above, as applicable, except that any repair will include repairs on that segment of the fire line between the main and the inlet side of the property line valve on the fire line but will exclude said property line valve. The city assumes no responsibility for maintenance or repair of fire lines which are free of domestic service pipes. However, if a user does not promptly repair a leak, the city may make any necessary repairs at the expense of the user or the owner. The city may recover the actual cost of the work or expense. 
(5)  The user is responsible for all damage to persons or property resulting from leaks from the service pipes or appurtenances thereto. 
(6)  Where a single connection but a common service pipe (irrespective of diameter) serves more than one (1) user independently metered and further where the common service may branch and cross from one (1) property to another, excluding: 
a.  any service pipe serving a multiunit dwelling, apartment or condominium as those terms are defined in section 120-36 of the Lafayette Code; and 
b.  any service pipe owned and maintained by the city and serving as a public main, such service pipe is hereby deemed a private water main. 
Where any private water main develops a leak between the meters and the city water main, whether the private water main is in an easement or private property, all of the users served through the private water main are jointly and severally responsible for all costs to repair the leaking service pipe. The city has the right to repair the leak after notification to the users and then to bill the repair costs and cost of unmetered water lost equally to all users and the failure to pay such costs shall warrant and authorize the city in turning off the water to the property or properties being served. 
(7)  Any maintenance provided by the city under this section will not include any responsibility for either the thawing of frozen service pipes or appurtenances, repairs to stub-in connections, or repairs of leaks caused by frozen service pipes if within any time in the previous seven (7) months the city has thawed or performed freeze-related repairs on the same service pipes. 
(8)  The repair service as hereinabove described will be provided without cost to the user only for those leaks that are attributed to normal wear and aging of the service pipe; except that such repair service will not be provided if the city determines that the service pipe is substandard, or that the service pipe is buried at too shallow a depth. Leaks caused by actions such as excavation, demolition, or landscaping upon the customer's property will not be repaired by the city and repair of such leaks is the responsibility of the user. Leaks caused by a customer or any third party through actions such as excavation, demolition or landscaping upon city-owned easement or right-of-way shall be repaired by the city; the city shall bill the person for whose benefit such action was conducted. The unmetered water lost due to the broken service pipe will be billed to the user at the appropriate rate as set forth in section 120-58 of this Code. The volume of lost water will be estimated based on service pipe size, break size, water pressure, and flow time. The failure to pay all costs billed by the city under this section shall warrant and authorize the city in turning off the water to the property or properties being served. 
(9)  Should the city perform any work or incur any expenses for the installation, removal, replacement, servicing, relocation, or maintenance of a water service pipe or appurtenances thereto, and any such work or expense is the responsibility of either the user or the owner, the city is authorized to recover the actual cost of such work or expense. The failure to pay such costs shall warrant and authorize the city in turning off the water to the property or properties being served. 
(10)  Nothing herein shall prevent any property owner from improving or replacing, at the property owner's sole expense, any service pipes owned by said property owner. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 10, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 1985-23, § 1, 7-16-85; Ord. No. 1993-11, § 1, 5-4-93) 
Sec. 120-8.1. - Access to property. 
    For the purpose of inspection, construction, or the performance of such maintenance as is available under this Code, authorized employees of the city will be allowed free access at reasonable hours to any building or premises where water is used. The city has the right of ingress and egress to utility easements at any time for the purpose of maintenance, construction, and repair of utilities. All such employees carry an identification card containing a picture of the employee. Unless such employee possesses such an identification card, the employee need not be admitted to the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1993-11, § 2, 5-4-93; Ord. No. 1996-16, § 2, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 1997-6, § 6, 5-20-97) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1993-11, adopted May 4, 1993, added a new section to Ch. 120, but did not provide for specific designation of such section; such section has been designated as § 120-8.1 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 120-9. - Tampering with meters, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with any meter, or to install or use any by-pass or other device whereby water may be drawn from a service pipe without being registered by the meter. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 9, 4-24-74) 
State Law reference- Criminal tampering, C. R. S. §§ 18-4-505, 18-4-506. 
Sec. 120-10. - Pollution of water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or cast any substance into any reservoir, well, trench, pipe or drain used in and necessary for the construction, maintenance or operation of the city waterworks system which may tend to fill up such reservoir or well or to obstruct the flow of water in such trench, pipe or drain or to pollute the water therein. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 13, 4-24-74) 
State Law reference- Criminal pollution of state waters, C. R. S. § 25-8-609. 
Sec. 120-11. - Using water from another connection. 
    Except to the extent that another consumer may be exempted from the independent meter requirement pursuant to section 120-7.1 or 120-7.3, it shall be unlawful for any consumer to permit water to be taken through his service pipe for the use of any person whose premises are not connected for the use of water through the city's mains. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 12, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 1996-16, § 2, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 120-12. - Hydrants. 
(a)  No water shall be used from the fire hydrants except for the extinguishment of fire, other municipal use or unless city approval has been obtained. Consumer use of hydrants shall require use of meters to measure water taken unless prior approval from the city is obtained. 
(b)  No person shall hitch any animal to or pile goods around or in any other way or manner obstruct the use of any of the public water hydrants. 
(c)  Any person violating subsection (a) or (b) of this section 120-12, upon first conviction shall be punished by a minimum fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00), which fine shall be imposed by the municipal court and shall not be suspended; upon second conviction shall be punished by a minimum fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), which fine shall be imposed by the municipal court and shall not be suspended; upon third conviction shall be punished by a minimum fine of not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), which fine shall be imposed by the municipal court and shall not be suspended; and upon all subsequent convictions shall be punished by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00); which fines shall be imposed by the municipal court and shall not be suspended. This offense is not punishable by imprisonment. 
(Code 1963, § 15-20; Ord. No. 621, § 14, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 1997, § 7, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 2001-4, § 1, 2-6-01) 
Sec. 120-13. - Irrigation-Restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any consumer or other person, or for the owner of any property to cause, permit, suffer, or allow any person to irrigate, sprinkle, or otherwise apply water from the municipal water utility system to any outdoor vegetation, including, but not limited to, lawns and gardens, between the hours of 10:00 a.m., and 6:00 p.m. 
(1)  The foregoing restriction shall not apply to: 
a.  Irrigation of land used for commercial agriculture; or 
b.  Watering by hand of any outdoor vegetation using a manually operated hose equipped with an automatic shut-off valve; or 
c.  Watering by hand of any community gardens using a manually operated hose equipped with an automatic shut-off valve; or 
d.  Irrigation of, short grass on city-owned or operated golf courses and city owned athletic fields. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any consumer or other person, or for the owner of any property to cause, permit, suffer or allow any person to irrigate, sprinkle, or otherwise apply water from the municipal water utility system to any lawn, garden, or other area of land in a manner that allows water to be cast upon a paved area or onto any other area not covered by vegetation. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any consumer or other person, or for the owner of any property to cause, permit, suffer, or allow any person to wash any paved area with a hose using water from the municipal water utility system. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall apply to all real property within the city, whether publicly or privately owned, and all land outside of the city that is served by the municipal water utility system. The provisions of this section may be enforced with respect to land located outside of the city by a suit for injunctive relief in a court of competent jurisdiction. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the testing of fire hydrants or fire sprinkler systems shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(e)  In addition to the restrictions set forth herein, city council may by resolution impose time restrictions on the use of municipal water for irrigation purposes. 
(f)  Water conservation enforcement personnel, as designated by the city's public works director, shall be authorized to enforce the provisions of this section, including the issuance of municipal court summons and complaints. 
(g)  Prior to the issuance of a summons and complaint any consumer or person alleged to have violated any provision of this section shall first have received two (2) written warnings from water conservation, code or law enforcement personnel. Thereafter any consumer or other person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this section, shall upon first conviction be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), which fine shall not be suspended by the court; upon a second conviction of such consumer or other person there shall be imposed a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), which fine shall not be suspended by the court; upon a third and each subsequent conviction of such consumer or other person, there shall be imposed a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), which fine shall not be suspended by the court. 
(Ord. No. 775, § 2, 4-18-78; Ord. No. 1997, § 8, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 2013-27, § 1, 11-6-13) 
State Law reference- Water and irrigation, C. R. S. Title 37. 
Sec. 120-14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 9 of Ord. No. 1997-6, adopted May 20, 1997, deleted in its entirety and reserved for future use § 120-14. Former § 120-14 pertained to special permits for irrigation and derived from Ord. No. 775, § 5, adopted April 18, 1978. 
Sec. 120-15. - Irrigation-Finding of noncompliance. 
    A finding by a duly authorized representative of the city of improper irrigation as provided in section 120-13 shall constitute presumptive evidence of a violation of sections 120-13-120-16 by the head of the household and/or any person occupying or owning the premises where such violation is found to occur. 
(Ord. No. 775, § 3, 4-18-78) 
Sec. 120-16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sec. 1 of Ord. No. 2017-22, adopted June 19, 2017, deleted § 120-16, which pertained to penalties for violation of irrigation provisions, and derived from Ord. No. 775, adopted Apr. 18, 1978; and Ord. No. 1994-6, adopted Apr. 19, 1994. 
Secs. 120-17-120-19. - Reserved. 
Sec. 120-20. - Connection of well to water system. 
    No person shall, under any circumstances or conditions, connect any water well whether registered with the state engineer or not, to any portion of the water transmission or distribution system of the city. 
(Ord. No. 639, § 1, 11-19-74) 
Sec. 120-21. - Shutting off water. 
    The council reserves the right to cause the water to be shut off in the mains when it deems necessary. The director of public works for the purpose of repairing or making connections for extensions to the waterworks or for the purpose of cleaning the same, may shut off the water at any time; provided that before the water shall be turned off from any school or public building, the director of public works shall notify the occupant or person in charge of such building. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 14, 4-24-74) 
Sec. 120-22. - Resale of water prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful, except as authorized by resolution of council, for any person to resell water furnished or provided to such person by the city's water service system. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall prohibit landlords of multi-unit dwellings and multi-unit residential structures, exempt from the city's independent metering requirements, from charging tenants a monthly amount to reimburse such landlord the cost of supplying water for the term of the lease. 
(c)  The method of determining such amount and documentation supporting same shall be disclosed to the city upon its request and must, in the city's determination, be a reasonable estimate of the landlord's per capita or per dwelling unit cost to supply water based on previous usage rates and current water rates. 
(d)  The city has the authority to audit, upon reasonable notice, a landlord's records to ensure the landlord's water charges are in compliance with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010-29, § 2, 12-7-10) 
Secs. 120-23-120-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE 

Sec. 120-36. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 10 of Ord. No. 1997-6, adopted May 20, 1997, deleted in its entirety and reserved for future use § 120-36. Former § 120-36 pertained to definitions and derived from Ord. No. 841, § 3, adopted June 15, 1979. The user is directed to the definitions in § 120-1. 
Sec. 120-37. - Permit. 
    No water service approval shall be granted, no water meter shall be installed and no water service shall be made on any water main or other portion of the waterworks of the city without first securing a permit or permits therefor. The application for a water meter or water service permit shall be made in writing upon a form furnished by the director of public works, and shall state clearly the water service and meter size, address and name of the person applying for the water service and any other information that the director of public works may reasonably require. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 2, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-38. - Fee required. 
    Any applicant desiring to take and use water from the water utility of the city shall pay to the city a water service fee pursuant to the schedule of water service fees prescribed in section 120-39.1. Applicants desiring to take and use water for a proposed structure within the city limits shall pay such fee at the time of issuance of a building permit or at a time pursuant to Article XIV of Chapter 30 of this Code. Applicants desiring to take and use water from the water utility of the city for an existing structure within the city limits, or any structure outside the city limits, whether existing or proposed, shall pay such fee prior to the issuance of a water utility connection permit. This fee shall be in addition to any other charges relating to water service elsewhere described in the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 2, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 1990-17, § 2, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Charter reference- Power of council to fix charges for public utility services, § 13.4. 
Sec. 120-39. - Responsibility for payment of fee. 
    The city shall look only to the owner and the owner's successors in interest of each property or building desiring water service for payment of the water service fee. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-39.1. - Residential fee. 
    Residential tap fees shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 860, § 1, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 895, § 1, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 917, § 1, 7-21-81; Ord. No. 992, § 1, 9-20-83; Ord. No. 1985-28, § 1, 8-20-85; Ord. No. 1985-37, § 1, 10-7-86; Ord. No. 1993-12, § 1, 4-20-93; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 24, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 50, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 120-40. - Other than residential fee schedule. 
(a)  All utility customers, other than residential, shall pay a water tap fee set by resolution of city council. The size of the water meter, and therefore the amount of the water tap fee, shall be based on the total maximum demand of the proposed use exclusive of the demand for fire protection purposes. Maximum demand shall be determined on a fixture-unit basis as described in the International Plumbing Code, as adopted by the City in section 30-176 of the Code. The actual physical connection size and the location of the water main shall be determined by the public works department. 
(b)  Applicants shall provide all pertinent information necessary for determination of the water service fee as required by the director of public works. The applicant shall be required to provide the maximum design demand in gallons per minute for any landscape irrigation system. The fees shall be paid upon application for a building permit, or at any time prior to the purchase of the same, or at a time pursuant to Article XIV of Chapter 30 of this Code. No building permit or water utility connection permit shall be released until all public utility requirements have been satisfied, unless deferred as above stated. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 860, § 2, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 895, § 2, 11-4-80; Ord. No. 1986-37, § 2, 10-7-86; Ord. No. 1990-17, § 4, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 1993-12, § 2, 4-20-93; Ord. No. 2000-44, § 25, 11-21-00; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 51, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 120-40.1. - Combined uses-fees. 
    Developments with combined uses shall be assessed a water service fee based on the individual uses within the structure. The "other than residential" portion shall be assessed in accordance with the "other than residential" fee schedule, and the residential portion shall be assessed in accordance with the residential fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1997-6, § 11, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-40.2. - Business and commercial condominiums. 
    Business, commercial and industrial developments designated to be sold and occupied in a manner similar to residential condominiums shall be assessed a water service fee pursuant to the "other than residential" schedule of fees. The industrial water service fee shall be based on the total demand of the building or structure. Any increase in total demand resulting from the installation of additional fixtures shall require an additional water service fee. 
(Ord. No. 1997-6, § 12, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-40.3. - Irrigation service. 
    The director of public works shall establish policies and procedures pursuant to section 120-2 to determine those utility customers who shall be required to obtain an irrigation service for landscape irrigation. All utility customers who are required to obtain an irrigation service pursuant to such policies and procedures, and all utility customers who desire to install an irrigation service or utilize a water service for irrigation purposes shall meet the requirements as specified by the director of public works pursuant to section 120-2, based on the schedule of fees for other than residential users. 
(Ord. No. 1997-6, § 13, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 1999-50, § 5, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-40.4. - Accessory buildings and dwelling units. 
    Separate water service, water meters and water rights fees are not required for secondary or accessory buildings on private lots or for accessory dwelling units on private lots zoned OTR (old town residential), on properties having a main or principal building or use, provided that ownership of such separate secondary, accessory buildings or accessory dwelling units and main or principal buildings is by a single person or entity. If ownership of a secondary, accessory building or accessory dwelling unit and a main or principal building is severed or is otherwise held by separate persons or entities, both of the buildings shall be required to obtain a separate water service and water meter, and to pay separate water rights fees. All costs for water service, water meters and water rights fees shall be the responsibility of the new owner. 
(Ord. No. 1997-6, § 14, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03; Ord. No. 2015-23, § 1, 7-21-15) 
Sec. 120-41. - Out of city fees. 
    Tap fees for connections outside the city limits shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 52, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 120-42. - Installation costs. 
    Upon approval of the water service permit, the city shall install a water meter in a meter pit provided by the applicant. The applicant shall bear the cost of the meter and installation, yoke, corporation valve, pit and cap, and all costs of excavation and plumbing from the water service to the buildings or uses served. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 1997-6, § 15, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 1999-50, § 6, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-43. - Changes in use. 
    If a water utility system user applies for and obtains permission to make changes or additions to the property that would affect the demand on the water utility system, a new water utility system permit shall be required. The water utility service fee for such permit shall be computed on the basis of the new service as determined by the schedule of fees set forth in this article. Credit shall be given for the current amount of the water service fee required for the use of the water utility system prior to the changes or additions to the property. Credit shall also be allowed for approved decreases in the amount of the water utility system service. Under no circumstances shall the city be required to pay cash refunds for either decreases in the amount of water utility system service provided or for allowable credits in excess of the new water utility system service fee. Credits allowed herein shall apply to the property served by the existing water utility system service and shall be applied only to the water utility system service fees owed to the city and not to other utility fees or charges. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 1989-42, § 1, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-44. - Monthly charges. 
(a)  In the event that a water service is issued by the city but such water service is not put to use within one hundred eighty (180) days of issuance, the applicant shall be responsible for and liable for payment of minimum monthly water utility service charges as set forth in Article III of this chapter until such time as the water service is put to actual use. 
(b)  The city administrator shall have the authority to waive the requirements of paragraph (a) for up to one hundred eighty (180) additional days in the event that the water utility customer is able to show sufficient good cause for the waiver to be granted. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 3, 6-15-79; Ord. No. 1986-45, § 1, 12-2-86; Ord. No. 1999-1, § 1, 1-19-99; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 2, 7-15-03) 
Secs. 120-45-120-55. - Reserved.

Sec. 120-57. - Service charge components. 
(a)  Each user of the city's water utility system shall be assessed charges on a monthly basis for the use of the water utility system. Such charges shall be set by resolution of city council and consist of a basic monthly rate, a high volume surcharge and a monthly service charge per unit. 
(b)  Charges for service outside the city limits shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, a "unit" is defined as an independent dwelling unit. 
(Ord. No. 911, § 2, 4-21-81; Ord. No. 954, § 1, 9-21-82; Ord. No. 1989-57, § 1, 12-19-89; Ord. No. 2002-39, § 1, 1-7-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 53, 3-1-05)

Sec. 120-58.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 2003-10, adopted April 7, 2003, repealed § 120-58.1, which pertained to basic monthly charge during drought conditions, and derived from Ord. No. 2002-12, adopted May 21, 2002. 
Sec. 120-59. - Computation of rate. 
(a)  The schedule of water rates in this article shall be applied to water used or consumed as determined by the water meter readings which are made by the city. 
(b)  Water meters are to be read to the nearest one thousand (1,000) gallons; thus any meter containing a portion of one thousand (1,000) gallons shall be rounded off to the nearest one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 5, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 911, § 2, 4-21-81) 
Sec. 120-60. - Building occupied by more than one (1) tenant. 
    Owners or agents in charge of business blocks or other buildings occupied by more than one (1) tenant using water from the same service pipe shall be required to pay the water rate for the whole of such buildings, unless a separate meter is installed for each tenant. 
(Ord. No. 621, § 11, 4-24-74; Ord. No. 911, § 2, 4-21-81) 
Sec. 120-61. - Billing and payment. 
(a)  Bills for water and water reclamation service charges shall be mailed regularly as provided by policies and procedures established pursuant to section 120-2 of this chapter. Such bills shall state the amount of utility service charges attributable to the customer's use of the utility system. Except as otherwise provided in section 120-7.1, where the utility customer is not the owner of the property served, the bill shall state the owner or property management company name after the tenant name. All final utility bills shall be issued to the owner or property management company of any rental property. The city may seek payment from any responsible party, but the owner of the property is ultimately responsible for the payment of all charges. 
(b)  In the event that a utility bill is not paid by the fourteenth day following the date of mailing, the city treasurer may give the utility user a delinquent notice in writing that the bill must be paid within seven (7) days of the date of the notice. There shall be added to all utility bills that are thirty (30) or more days delinquent, an interest charge of one and one-half (1.5) percent per month on the delinquent portion of the bill, not to exceed a total of twenty-five (25) percent of the amount due. The owner or property management company of any rental property will be notified by a duplicate delinquent notice. This action shall constitute proper notification by the city to all parties responsible for payment of the utility bill applicable to the property. 
(c)  In case any person shall fail or refuse to pay all charges as prescribed herein, or fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of the water and water reclamation utility ordinances of the City of Lafayette, the director of public works may shut off the water to said premises, building, house, lot or dwelling unit, and water shall not be turned on again until all charges are paid, together with a shut-off and turn-on fee as set by resolution of city council, interest accrued, and the cost of collecting said charges, or until compliance with the provisions of the water or water reclamation utility ordinances of the City of Lafayette have been obtained. The cost for out-of-city customers shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(d)  In cases where more than one (1) premises, lot, house, building or dwelling unit is lawfully served by a common meter, pursuant to the exemptions listed in sections 120-7.1 and 120-7.3, only one (1) statement or bill comprising all charges for water and water reclamation services furnished shall be issued. If that bill is not paid when due, or if anyone served through said common meter fails to comply with any of the water or water reclamation ordinances of the City of Lafayette, the city may discontinue all water service through said meter and to the premises receiving water through said meter, until such charges, together with costs and interest, if any, are paid or the ordinances have been complied with. No claim for damages because of such turnoff or discontinuance of water service may be made against the water utility of the city by anyone receiving water through a common meter, who has complied with the water or water reclamation utility ordinances, or who has paid a proportionate or other share of the charges outstanding and remaining unpaid. As a condition precedent to the furnishing of water through a common meter, any act or omission requiring the city to discontinue water service through said common meter and to be premises receiving water thereby shall be deemed to be a joint act of persons who are served through said meter. 
(e)  The city will transfer the unpaid balance of a final utility bill to the active water account on a given property after all other collection procedures have been attempted. The owner of any given property shall be ultimately responsible for all water and water reclamation services and charges applicable to their property. The city shall have for security of the collection of such utility rates, penalties and charges, a lien upon the real property served, which lien shall become effective immediately upon the supplying of water and water reclamation service and shall not be discharged until the payment is made of all the utility service bills, penalties and charges herein provided. 
(f)  If the lien as provided in this section is not discharged by payment, the city administrator shall report the delinquency to the council not less than three (3) months from the date thereof; and the council shall be authorized to collect the delinquent bill by causing such delinquent charges to be certified to the treasurer of Boulder County to be collected and paid over to the treasurer of the city in the same manner as taxes. 
(g)  Alternately, upon the election of council, such proceedings may be instituted for the enforcement and foreclosure of such lien in accordance with the provisions of the statutes of the State of Colorado relating to mechanic's and material liens in accordance with the authority contained in Sections 38-20-101 and 38-21-101 Colorado Revised Statutes, 2007. 
(h)  In the event of such suit, the city shall also be entitled to judgment against the owner or occupant of the premises served for the costs and expenses of such suit, including attorneys' fees in addition to the amount delinquent and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 911, § 2, 4-21-81; Ord. No. 1984-04, § 1, 3-6-84; Ord. No. 1996-16, § 3, 9-3-96; Ord. No. 1999-50, § 7, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 55, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 120-62. - Additional service charges. 
(a)  Turn on and restore service. There shall be charged and added to bills for water service a fee set by resolution of city council each time a municipal water user or his agent requests that the city turn on and restore municipal water service that has been turned off at the request of or by the water user or his agent. Said fee shall be charged at the time the water service is turned on and shall be added to the user's water bill as provided in section 120-61. During the period that a municipal water user's service is turned off, said municipal water user shall be responsible for the payment of the minimum basic monthly charge for water service pursuant to section 120-58 and the minimum basic monthly charge for sewer service pursuant to section 95-94 with the exception of water service provide by an irrigation service. 
(b)  Meter reset fee. There shall be charged a fee set by resolution of city council when any person requests an initial water meter setting for a new water connection, and the property is not prepared for such connection at the time the city attempts to set the meter. The fee shall be assessed to the person's utility bill. 
(c)  Shutoff notice. There shall be charged and added to bills for water service a fee set by resolution of city council for the physical placement of a final shutoff notice on the property for which water service is to be disconnected. 
(d)  Stretcher bars/meter jumpers. For the purposes of this section a "stretcher bar" or "meter jumper" is defined as an apparatus that allows a municipal water user to bypass the meter requirement and utilize water free of charge. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code for any person to install, permit the installation of, use, or otherwise benefit from the use of a stretcher bar or meter jumper. In addition to any penalties that may be assessed by the municipal court for violation hereof, any person violating this section shall also pay to the city a civil penalty in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each day that the stretcher bar or meter jumper remains in place. 
(Ord. No. 1988-21, § 1, 11-15-88; Ord. No. 1989-12, § 1, 3-21-89; Ord. No. 1989-39, § 1, 8-1-89; Ord. No. 1996-13, § 1, 8-6-96; Ord. No. 1997-6, § 18, 5-20-97; Ord. No. 1999-50, § 8, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 4, 7-15-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 56, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 2010-11, § 1, 4-20-10) 
Sec. 120-63. - Adjustment to utility bills. 
    Any adjustments to utility bills, including water, water reclamation, water service, service charges, fees, etc., shall only be permitted as provided by policies and procedures established pursuant to section 120-1.1 of this chapter. Adjustments may be made only for good cause shown. Only the director of finance or designee may make adjustments. The director of finance may consult with the director of public works in making an adjustment determination. No adjustment may reduce interest charges to less than one-half (1/2) percent per month. 
(Ord. No. 1999-50, § 9, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 4, 7-15-03) 
Secs. 120-64-120-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXTENSION OF SERVICE RE: ANNEXATION, SUBDIVISION OF LAND, ETC.[3]
