DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 120-81. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Lafayette Water Rights Dedication Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-82. - Intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent and purpose of this article to further the goals of sound water management by requiring the dedication of reliable water rights prior to any commitment by the city to extend or supply treated water service to new customers, and thereby to assure an adequate and stable supply of water for the City of Lafayette service area; to prevent the abandonment of water rights to the detriment of the city; to ensure the financial stability of the city water utility; and to promote the general welfare of the public. 
    This article, in part, provides a supplemental requirement for annexation pursuant to the Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, C.R.S. 1973, Section 31-12-101 et seq., and is not to be construed as altering, modifying, eliminating or replacing any requirements set forth in that act or any requirements set forth in other city ordinances or the City Charter. 
    It is not the intent of this article to extend water service outside the boundaries of the city when such extension would be inconsistent with the Lafayette Comprehensive Plan or the City Charter, or when the extension of such service would render the city incapable of meeting any of its present or future obligations within the city boundaries. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-83. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    Annexation means the act of attaching, adding, joining or uniting a parcel of land to the legal entity known as the City of Lafayette. 
    Applicant means any person who submits an application to the city requesting annexation, replatting, subdivision or water service extension approval. 
    Appurtenant means belonging to, accessory or incident to, adjunct, appended, or annexed to. 
    Average net annual stream depletion yield means the net stream depletion yield that has occurred historically, over a representative time period, divided by the number of years within that time period. 
    CBT water means an allotment contract entitling the holder to a share of the water supply from the Colorado Big Thompson Project administered by the NCWCD. 
    City staff means any employee of the city, as well as any person or entity that the city council or employees of the city elect to consult. 
    Conveyance of legal title to water rights means the legal process by which legal title to the water rights to be dedicated is transferred to the city by appropriate deed and assignment of any applicable corporate stock, or, in the case of CBT water, approval of a transfer of one (1) or more units of CBT water by the Board of Directors of the NCWCD. 
    Dedication means the total divestiture of property, without consideration, for use by the public, and acceptance for such use by the city council. 
    Lease means any grant for permissive use that results in the creation of a landlord-tenant relationship on a contractual basis. 
    NCWCD means the Northern Colorado Water Conservancy District. 
    Net annual stream depletion yield means that quantity of water, associated with a decreed right other than CBT water offered for dedication, that is totally lost to the stream system in a given year, as a result of the application of the water involved to a beneficial use. The net annual stream depletion yield for a water right that has been decreed as being from a nontributary source, shall be one hundred (100) percent of the water available for diversion and beneficial use. 
    Nonresidential development means those areas of the city that are not or will not be zoned for residential occupancy, and shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, developments containing commercial, industrial, office and similar uses. 
    Plat is an accurately surveyed map or chart of a piece of land subdivided into one (1) or more lots with streets, alleys, roads and other such avenues of transportation delineated thereon and drawn to scale. 
    Relative standard deviation (also referred to as the coefficient of variation) means the standard deviation of yield divided by the average (mean) yield of a water right. 
    Replat means to make a change in the original plat, or, where there is no original plat, the act of creating a plat for previously unplatted property. 
    Residential multifamily development means those areas of the city where people reside or are intended to reside on a permanent basis in a building used by two (2) or more families living independently of each other in separate dwelling units. This definition does not include motels or hotels but does include townhouses, condominiums, apartments and mobile home courts. Each mobile home space shall be considered as one (1) dwelling unit. 
    Residential single-family development means those areas of the city where people reside or are intended to reside on a permanent basis in a detached principal building other than a mobile home and which principal building is designed for or used as a dwelling exclusively by one (1) family. 
    Safe net annual stream depletion yield means the minimum net annual stream depletion that is expected to occur. 
    Standard deviation means the square root of the quantity: The sum of the squares of the deviation of each year's yield from the average yield, divided by the number of years of the study period used in the determination less one (1). In equation form, the definition appears as follows: 
  
Formula 
  
Where: 
X;sub \sub; = the yield of the individual year 
X = the average yield for the period of study 
n = the number of years of a representative study period 
i = the number one, two, three, ..., n for each year of the study period. 
    Subdivide or subdivision shall have the same meaning as defined in Chapter 26 of this code. 
    Sufficient legal priority means that the water right(s) proposed for dedication shall have a sufficient probability of being physically and legally available for diversion from the stream system, in order to provide a dependable supply of water to the city. CBT water is hereby deemed to have sufficient legal priority. A direct flow water right shall qualify only if its priority is such that some water will be physically and legally available for diversion from the stream system into the city's municipal water system each and every year. Further, the water right shall have a relative standard deviation of net annual stream depletion yield of no more than forty (40) percent; or have a ratio of safe net annual stream depletion yield to average net annual stream depletion yield of at least fifty-hundredths (0.50). A storage right shall qualify only if there is a seventy (70) percent probability of the reservoir right yielding, each year, the amount of water for which credit is given. In making these determinations, factors to be considered shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, the adjudication date and appropriation date of the water right, the decreed use(s), the historic usage of the water proposed for dedication, the physical flow available in the stream, and the administrative practices of the Office of the State Engineer. 
    Transferable net stream depletion yield means that amount of average net annual stream depletion yield that is capable of being transferred to the city's municipal water system in an appropriate water court proceeding. 
    Unit of CBT water means 1/310,000 of the water supply from the Colorado Big Thompson Project declared available, from year to year, to the NCWCD by its Board of Directors. 
    Water right means a decreed right to use, in accordance with its priority, a certain portion of the waters of the state by reason of the appropriation and beneficial use of the same, or one (1) or more units of CBT water. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-84. - Cash-in-lieu of water rights value for an acre foot of water and CBT unit yield. 
(a)  The cash-in-lieu of water rights value shall be set by resolution of city council, and shall be based upon defraying the city's actual or estimated expenses to locate and acquire new water rights, or to increase the effective yield of currently held water rights, all as may be needed to adequately serve the demands of the city's customers. 
(b)  The yield of CBT water for the purpose of calculating the water rights dedication to the city, as described in division 2 of this article, shall be set by resolution of city council. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 57, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 2014-18, § 1, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 120-84.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sec. 2 of Ord. No. 2014-18, adopted Nov. 3, 2014, repealed § 120-84.1, which pertained to the CBT unit yield and derived from Ord. No. 2005-10, adopted Mar. 1, 2005. 
Sec. 120-85. - Existing supply and distribution systems from entities other than the City of Lafayette. 
(a)  Because the city understands that some annexations may include areas with existing water supply service (including membership in water supply organizations or inclusion in water districts), the city may make a downward adjustment in the dedication requirement when the city council determines, in its sole and absolute discretion, that it is appropriate to do so to account for such existing water systems. 
(b)  In such cases, the city council, with assistance from the city staff, shall make a full analysis of the potential future water supply burden that may be placed upon the city by such annexation. The city council shall consider all factors affecting the water supply situation, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The probability that the applicant will continue to rely on the other system and not seek or demand water service from the city at some time in the future; 
(2)  The legal obligation of the city to supply water to the annexed area regardless of any existing system in the area; 
(3)  Evidence of water service commitments secured by the applicant from a water district or water supply organization with the capability of reliably meeting the demands represented by those commitments; 
(4)  The extent to which the district or other water supply organization has extended distribution lines into the area that are capable of providing reliable service to that area, or the extent to which the extension of such lines is assured; 
(5)  The age and condition of the existing water supply system. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 5, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-86. - Lease back provision. 
    If the water dedicated is not needed immediately for transfer and use in the city's system, the applicant shall have the first right to lease back the dedicated water rights at a lease rate per acre foot to be determined by the council at the first city council meeting in February of each year. The lessee shall be required to pay any applicable ditch assessments or related costs associated with the water rights leased. The duration of any lease shall be for one (1) year only, and any renewal shall be solely at the discretion of the city council. The city assumes no liability for nondelivery of leased water. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-87. - Exceptions. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to the subdivision or replatting of any annexed lands where the applicant can demonstrate that the requirements set forth in previous city water rights dedication ordinances or in this ordinance have already been met. Also, this ordinance shall not apply to subdivision agreements into which the city has entered prior to May 1, 2003, unless the terms and conditions of said agreements are altered or amended, or the agreements have expired prior to the fulfillment of any water rights dedication, or cash-in-lieu of water rights obligations contained therein. 
(b)  Whenever an application pertains to the annexation, replatting, subdivision or water service extension to a parcel of property already serviced by city water, the applicant will not have to comply with the dedication requirements for the land area encompassed by the lot or lots containing those existing dwellings or structures that are presently so served; provided, however, that no additional construction takes place on the lot or lots so exempted. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-88. - Future obligations. 
    This article is intended to increase the water supply of the city in order to meet the increased water requirements attributable to annexations, subdivisions, replatting and extensions of water service. Under no circumstances should this article be interpreted to relieve the applicant, his successors, assigns, or future residents of the subject land, of any obligation to install water mains or other facilities, to pay water service fees or plant investment fees that may be imposed by the city for the expansion or improvement of its water treatment and water reclamation facilities, or to pay reasonable fees or charges to the city for the performance of services. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 6, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-89. - Safety clause. 
    If any provision of this article or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of the article that can be given effect without the invalid provisions or applications, and to this end the provisions or applications of this article are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DEDICATION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 120-91. - Approval of subdivision, etc., conditioned upon dedication of water rights. 
    The dedication and conveyance of CBT water, direct flow and/or storage water rights to the city shall be required as a condition precedent to the approval of the subdivision or replatting of any land zoned and/or used as residential property. The dedication and conveyance of CBT water, direct flow and/or storage water rights to the city for all property other than residential shall be required as a condition precedent to the approval of a water service application. Also, subject to section 120-87, said requirement shall apply to all extensions of municipal treated water service. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2003-20, § 7, 7-15-03) 
Sec. 120-92. - Amounts of water to be dedicated. 
    For any land to be annexed, subdivided, replatted, or served by an extension of water service, (1) the party seeking approval for the annexation, subdivision, replatting, or water service extension within the city limits, or (2) any water district whose service area lies entirely within unincorporated Boulder County, shall dedicate to the city the following amounts of water: 
(a)  Residential developments. For each dwelling unit of each annexation, subdivision or replat, or for each dwelling to be served by an extension of water service, the party seeking approval for the subdivision, replatting or water extension shall dedicate to the city the following amounts of water: 
(1)  For residential single-family development five-tenths (0.5) of an acre foot, consisting of: 
a.  Direct-flow water rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide for each dwelling unit an annual average of five-tenths (0.5) of an acre foot of transferable net stream depletion yield, after having been properly discounted to take into account the appropriation date of the rights; 
b.  Storage water rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide an annual average of five-tenths (0.5) of an acre foot of water per dwelling unit; or 
c.  A combination thereof. 
(2)  For residential multifamily development thirty-five one hundredths (0.35) of an acre foot, consisting of: 
a.  Direct-flow water rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide for each dwelling unit an annual average of thirty-five one hundredths (0.35) of an acre foot of transferable net stream depletion yield, after having been properly discounted to take into account the appropriation date of the rights; 
b.  Storage water rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide an annual average of thirty-five one hundredths (0.35) of an acre foot of water per dwelling unit; or 
c.  A combination thereof. 
(3)  For each acre of nonresidential uses within residential developments (recreation centers, parks, greenbelts, etc.) two (2) acre feet, consisting of: 
a.  Direct-flow rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide for an annual average of two-acre feet of transferable net stream depletion yield after having been properly discounted to take into account the appropriation date of the rights; 
b.  Storage water rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide an average of two-acre foot of water; or 
c.  A combination thereof. 
(4)  For each residential multifamily development with no dwelling unit outdoor irrigation one-quarter (.25) acre foot, consisting of: 
a.  Direct-flow rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide for an annual average of one-quarter (0.25) acre foot of transferable net stream depletion yield after having been properly discounted to take into account the appropriation date of the rights; 
b.  Storage water rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide an average of one-quarter (0.25) acre foot of water; or 
c.  A combination thereof. 
(b)  Nonresidential developments. Subject to modification by the provisions contained in sections 120-95 and 120-96, below, for each acre of nonresidential development two (2) acre feet, consisting of: 
(1)  Direct-flow rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide an annual average of two (2) acre feet of transferable net stream depletion yield after having been properly discounted to take into account the appropriation date of the rights; 
(2)  Storage water rights of a "sufficient legal priority" to provide an annual average of two (2) acre feet of water; or 
(3)  A combination thereof. 
(c)  Out-of-city water service. Any party or entity seeking an out-of-city water service shall dedicate to the city double the amount of water otherwise required by this section. 
(d)  The quantity of water required for fractional acres shall be determined proportionately. Where the quantity of water required is expressed in fractional CBT units, the quantity shall be rounded up to the nearest full unit. 
(e)  CBT dedication calculation. All parties who dedicate units of CBT water to the city to meet the water dedication requirements of this article shall calculate the number of CBT units to dedicate to the city by the following formula: 
Total acre foot dedication divided by the CBT unit yield = Number of CBT units. 
The yield of CBT is set forth in section 120-84 and paragraph (d) of this section applies to the calculation. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, §§ 59, 60, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 2005-23, § 1, 8-2-05; Ord. No. 2014-18, § 3, 11-3-14; Ord. No. 2016-17, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 120-92.1. - Expansion of use. 
    If a water utility system user expands the demand on the water utility system as provided in section 120-43, additional water rights shall be dedicated. The dedication requirement shall be determined by calculating the requirement as outlined in section 120-92 and crediting the previously dedicated amount of water rights. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-93. - Acceptance of water rights by city; determination of yield. 
(a)  Only those water rights that the city, in its sole and absolute discretion, deems capable of being transferred into the city's municipal water system will be accepted. The specific yield allocated to each water right proposed to be dedicated, shall be determined solely and exclusively by the city. 
(b)  At the sole and absolute discretion of the city, water rights not meeting the criteria for "sufficient legal priority," as defined above, may be accepted, if said water rights contain attractive transfer or other characteristics, and further, that the water rights have an eighty (80) percent probability of yielding, each year, the amount of transferable net stream depletion for which credit is given. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-94. - Cash (etc.)-in-lieu of water rights. 
(a)  In the event that a person seeking annexation, subdivision, replatting, or water service extension approval within the city limits, or any water district whose service area lies entirely within unincorporated Boulder County: 
(1)  Is required to dedicate less than ten (10) acre feet, at the sole and absolute discretion of the public works director, cash-in-lieu of water rights may be substituted; 
(2)  Is unable to dedicate sufficient water rights to meet the requirements described herein, at the sole and absolute discretion of the city council, cash (or other consideration)-in-lieu of water rights may be substituted. 
In order to defray the expense the city must incur in locating and purchasing water rights to totally or partially satisfy developments for which sufficient water rights are not dedicated, the cash equivalent price shall be determined by section 120-84. 
(b)  In the event that any person seeking an out-of-city water service is permitted to satisfy his water rights dedication obligation by cash (or other consideration)-in-lieu of water rights, any such person shall pay twice the cash-in-lieu of water rights value set forth in section 120-84. 
(c)  If the city council makes a specific determination that the health, safety and welfare of the users of the municipal water utility would be benefited by the receipt of cash payments instead of water rights dedications, the city council may decide that applicants subject to water rights dedication obligations should be encouraged to pay cash. Such a preference shall be established by passage of a resolution by the city council setting forth the specific reasons therefore and establishing a date certain, after which the cash preference will expire. The preference may be extended by subsequent resolutions of the city council. Total or partial compliance with the city's preference for cash-in-lieu of water rights shall be optional with each applicant. For those applicants who elect to provide cash during the period when the preference is in effect, the cash equivalent price shall be determined by the city council resolution, in which the preference determination was established. All the money received by the city shall be used solely for the purchase of water rights, for the purchase of raw water storage space, or for financing the construction of capital improvement projects designed to enhance the city's raw water storage capabilities. 
(d)  Any consideration other than cash shall be evaluated by the city council on a case-by-case basis. The amount of credit given, if any, shall be determined by the city council after considering the advice of the city staff. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2005-10, § 61, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 2016-17, § 2, 4-19-16) 
Sec. 120-95. - Requirements adjusted for high use developments. 
    For nonresidential uses within residential developments and nonresidential developments that contain high water users, the city council, with assistance from the city staff, shall make a determination of the amount of water projected to be required to serve the area described within any application for annexation, replatting, subdivision or water service extension approval. If the results of the study indicate that the nonresidential uses within residential developments and nonresidential development will require more water than the two-acre feet per acre minimum set forth in subsections 120-92(a)(3) and 120-92(b) above, then the dedication requirement shall be adjusted accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2014-18, § 3, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 120-96. - Downward adjustment; owner's responsibility in event of projection shortfall. 
    The city recognizes that certain nonresidential uses within residential developments and nonresidential developments may, when built, require less than two-acre feet of water per acre each year. Therefore, should an applicant seeking subdivision, replatting or water service extension approval for a nonresidential subdivision believe that the two-acre feet of water per acre requirement exceeds the amount of water needed to serve each acre of the proposed development when completed, the applicant shall have the option of presenting data to the director of public works documenting the development's projected annual water needs. 
    The director of public works shall review the data so provided and may review any other pertinent data including, but not limited to, the actual water usage of other developments comparable to the proposed development. After reviewing the data, the director of public works shall determine whether the two-acre feet of water per acre requirement exceeds the amount of water that will be needed to serve each acre of the proposed development when completed. If the director of public works determines that the amount of water required to serve each acre of the nonresidential uses within residential developments, or the nonresidential development, is less than two-acre feet per year, an appropriate downward adjustment in the dedication requirement shall be made by the director of public works. 
    All charges incurred by the city in conjunction with the review process shall be assessed to the applicant. Payment of said charges shall be required as a condition precedent to application approval. A decision of whether the data provided by an applicant is sufficient for purposes of conducting a meaningful review shall be determined solely by the city. Adequate assurance that the lands described in the application will not develop in a manner such that the ultimate water usage exceeds the projected estimates (in the form of platting restrictions, covenants running with the land or similar legal mechanisms that will bind not only the applicant, but subsequent owners and lessees of both the land and all structures contained thereon), must be provided by the applicant. If, in the future, the annual water needs of the developed area exceed the projected level of usage, the then current owner shall be responsible for providing the city with the additional water rights to make up for any shortfall. Said water rights shall meet the criteria of the water rights dedication ordinance then in effect. Failure to comply with this requirement shall result in the automatic imposition of a moratorium on the issuance of new water taps for the development and/or the discontinuation of water service to the affected area. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2014-18, § 5, 11-3-14) 
Secs. 120-97-120-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROCEDURE 

Sec. 120-101. - Application-Submission; contents. 
    All applications for annexation, subdivision, replatting or extension of municipal water service shall be submitted to the city planning department. Any such application shall comply with the requirements of the planning department then in effect. The application shall be accompanied with a summary of the water rights appurtenant to the property to be served by city services. At a minimum, the water rights summary must contain the information requested in division 5. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 2011-33, § 13, 9-20-11; Ord. No. 2019-06, § 2, 2-19-2019) 
Sec. 120-102. - Same-Number of acres; acre feet of water. 
    The city staff shall determine the number of gross acres that are described in the application and the number of acre feet of water required to be dedicated by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-103. - Same-Preliminary determination re water rights. 
    The city staff shall also make a preliminary determination concerning whether the water rights proposed for dedication can be transferred into the city's municipal water system, and are of a sufficient legal priority, have a satisfactory historic usage and yield enough water each year to satisfy the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-104. - Same-Submission to council. 
    The application, along with the city staff's determinations and recommendations, shall then be submitted to the city council for consideration. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-105. - Council action. 
    After evaluating the application and considering the determinations and recommendations provided by the city staff, the city council shall either, accept, accept in part, or reject the water rights offered for dedication. The council shall also have the option of requesting additional information from the applicant prior to a formal resolution of the matter. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-106. - Acceptance of water rights; required. 
    It is the intent of this article, that subject to the provisions set forth in division 4 herein, no annexation, subdivision, replatting or request for water service extension shall be approved until the city council has formally accepted water rights, or cash (or other consideration)-in-lieu of water rights, that fully comply with the water right dedication requirements set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-107. - Dedication to be complete; fees and costs. 
(a)  The dedication and conveyance of all water rights shall be complete, without any conditions or contractual clauses, outstanding assessments, liens or encumbrances whatsoever, unless the express approval of the city council is obtained. In the case of direct-flow or storage water rights, the dedication and conveyance shall be considered complete upon transfer of title to the water rights to the city. In the case of CBT water, the dedication and conveyance shall be considered complete upon approval of the application for transfer by the NCWCD board of directors. 
(b)  The applicant shall be responsible for reimbursing the city for all costs and fees, including transfer fees, associated with transferring into the city's municipal water system, any water rights either dedicated by the applicant or purchased by the city with cash-in-lieu of water rights provided by the applicant. In the case of direct-flow or storage water rights, such costs and fees shall include, but not be limited to, those associated with any necessary water court proceedings to change the water rights to municipal use. In the case of CBT water, such costs and fees shall include, but not be limited to, the cost of obtaining approval of the transfer to the city by the NCWCD board of directors. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-108. - Dedication of carriage rights. 
    The applicant shall dedicate any carriage rights that are associated with the dedicated water rights or that the city determines to be necessary to transport the water into the city's municipal system. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-109. - Transfer of consideration; time of valuation. 
    Whenever the city council permits the applicant to satisfy the dedication requirements by substituting cash (or other consideration) in lieu of water rights, instead of, or in combination with, water rights, city council approval of the application for annexation, subdivision, replatting or request for water service extension shall be contingent upon tender of the cash payment or conveyance of the substitute consideration. The cash in lieu of water rights valuation shall be made as of the date payment in full is tendered to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-110. - Dry-up covenant. 
    Whenever the city council determines that the transfer of an irrigation water right to municipal purposes will be contingent upon documenting, to the water court, that lands historically irrigated with the water right have been taken out of irrigation, approval of the application shall be contingent upon the current owner of the historically irrigated property entering into a binding dry-up covenant with the city, that encompasses and runs with the affected lands. The need for such a covenant, as well as the specific lands to be so covered, shall be determined solely by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-111. - Expenses; payment by applicant. 
    Applicants shall be responsible for all expenses incurred by the city in evaluating the contents of each application, specifically including the acceptability and yield of the water rights offered for dedication. This responsibility shall include fees charged by outside water consultants the city may employ in the legal and engineering fields. Payment of said expenses shall be a condition precedent to application approval. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-112. - Escrow of transfer charges. 
    The city council, after receiving input from the city staff, shall make a determination of the anticipated charges associated with each water rights transfer, and the applicant shall be required to escrow the amount so determined. As the city incurs charges attributable to the water transfer process, monies in an equivalent amount shall be withdrawn from the escrow account for the benefit of the city. Any unused funds shall be returned to the applicant. However, in the event that the charges incurred by the city exceed the amount placed in escrow, then the applicant shall be responsible for making up the difference. Failure to comply fully with this requirement shall result in the institution of a moratorium on the extension of city utility services to the property for which the water rights or cash (or other consideration) in lieu of water rights were earmarked. At such time as the city is fully reimbursed for the expenses incurred in the transfer process, the moratorium shall be lifted. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-113. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sec. 7 of Ord. No. 2014-18, adopted Nov. 3, 2014, repealed § 120-113 which pertained to interim acquisition of CBT water, and derived from Ord. No. 2003-7, adopted Apr. 1, 2003. 
Secs. 120-114, 120-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DEFERMENT OF WATER RIGHT DEDICATION OBLIGATION 

Sec. 120-116. - Request for deferment. 
(a)  Subject to the following constraints, an applicant may request that a portion of the total water right dedication requirement be deferred. 
(b)  Such deferral shall apply only to those applicants that request annexation, replatting or subdivision approval. 
(c)  Only those applications that encompass more than fifteen (15) acres of land shall qualify. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-117. - Amount of deferment. 
    The specific amount of the total water rights dedication obligation that can be deferred shall be dependent upon the gross acreage described within the application. However, formal approval by the city council of any annexation, replatting or subdivision request shall be contingent upon receipt by the city of at least some water rights or cash (or other consideration) in lieu of water rights. The minimum percentage of the total water rights dedication obligation that must be satisfied prior to city council approval of the application is as follows: 
Gross Acreage Described Within the Application Minimum Percentage of the Total Water Rights Obligation That Must be Dedicated Prior to 
Application Approval 15-30 acres 50 30-60 acres 33 60-100 acres 25 Greater than 100 acres Determined on a case-by-case basis  
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-118. - Extension of services when deferment exercised. 
    In the event that an applicant elects to defer a portion of the water rights dedication obligation, city utility services shall be extended only to that portion of the lands described within the application for which water rights or cash (or other consideration) in lieu of water rights have been received. Further extension of such services shall not be allowed until additional water rights, or cash (or other consideration) in lieu of water rights have been received by the city. The cash-in-lieu of water rights valuation shall be made as of the date payment is tendered to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-119. - Number of allowable phases; extension of services. 
(a)  An applicant shall be limited to a finite number of phases within which the water rights dedication obligation associated with the lands described within a particular application must be met. The allowable number of phases shall be dependent upon the number of gross acres involved as follows: 
Gross Acreage Described Within the Application Number of Phases Allowed, Subsequent to Satisfaction of the Initial Minimum Dedication 
Requirement 15-30 acres 1 30-60 2 60-100 3 Greater than 100 acres To be determined on a case-by-case basis  
(b)  Where more than one (1) subsequent phase is allowed, the specific percentage of the outstanding water dedication obligation that must be completed for each phase shall be discretionary with the applicant; provided, however, that sufficient water dedication applicable to each such phase occur; and further provided that in no event shall city services be extended to any lands described within the application for which water rights or cash (or other consideration) in lieu of water rights have not been received. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Secs. 120-120-120-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - OPTION TO PURCHASE AND RIGHT OF FIRST REFUSAL 

Sec. 120-126. - Option to purchase. 
(a)  Time. Any person required to comply with the basic dedication requirement shall also grant to the city the option to purchase any and all water rights that are appurtenant to the land involved, but that are in excess of the basic dedication requirement or that are deemed not to be satisfactory. Said option may be exercised by the city at any time for a period of two (2) years following approval of the application for annexation, subdivision, replatting or water service extension. 
(b)  Price. The option price shall be that price agreed upon by the parties. If the parties do not agree upon an option price within thirty (30) days after notice of the city's intent to exercise its option is received by the owner, appraisal at the city's expense will establish the price that reflects the fair market value of the water right(s). 
(1)  The appraisal shall be conducted by one (1) appraiser appointed by the city, one (1) appraiser appointed by the owner of the water rights, and a third appraiser to be appointed by both parties' appraisers. The average of the three (3) appraisals shall be the option price. 
(2)  The terms and conditions of the payment and conveyance of said water rights shall be those that are mutually agreeable to both parties. Nonetheless, it is expected that payment and conveyance will be completed within one hundred eighty (180) days of the establishment of the option price. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-127. - Right of first refusal. 
(a)  Grant of right. In addition to the grant of said option to purchase by the applicant, there shall be a grant to the city by the applicant of a right of first refusal regarding the water rights subject to said option to purchase. If the city, for any reason, should choose not to exercise its option to purchase, the city shall retain said right of first refusal, in the event the water rights are sold independently of the land, for a period of ten (10) years following final approval of annexation, subdivision, replatting, or extension of water service. 
(b)  Notice of period. If the owner of the water rights subject to said right of first refusal wishes to sell said water rights to a third party, he shall give to the city at least ninety (90) days' notice of his intention to effect a sale of said water rights by delivering to the city a bona fide written offer to purchase made by a third party. 
(c)  Exercise of right. During the ninety-day notice period provided for above, the city shall enjoy its right of first refusal entitling it to purchase the water rights subject to its right and proposed for sale. If within ninety (90) days following notice by the owner of his intention to sell his water rights, the city chooses to exercise its right of purchase, then the city shall pay to the owner the amount tendered to the owner in the bona fide offer by the third party. In the event that the city determines not to exercise its right to purchase the water rights offered for sale, the owner shall be free to sell the water rights to the third party; provided, however, that any such sale to a third party shall be pursuant to the terms and conditions that were the same as those tendered to and refused by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-128. - Recording of option to purchase and right of first refusal. 
    The grant of any option to purchase and right of first refusal shall be by means of an agreement prepared by the city and signed by the applicant, and shall be structured so that all subsequent purchasers of the water rights are placed on notice of the city's prior claim. Such document shall be filed of record with the applicable county clerk and recorder's office and shall be presented to the secretary of any applicable ditch or reservoir company. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Secs. 120-129, 20-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - REQUIRED INFORMATION 

Sec. 120-131. - Water rights-Generally. 
    The following information shall be provided for all water rights that are proposed to be dedicated to the city: 
(1)  The name of the water right involved, the number of shares in a mutual ditch or reservoir company evidencing the right, if applicable, and/or the percentage of undivided interest of the water right proposed to be dedicated. 
(2)  The name and address of the owner(s) of the water right proposed for dedication. 
(3)  A copy of the documents through which the owner(s) received title to the water right proposed for dedication, including deeds, stock certificates, etc., and a copy of any decree or judgment that may affect the title of the water right since the owner(s) received title. 
(4)  If the water right is decreed for irrigation use, the legal description of the lands historically irrigated, the name and address of the present owner(s) of the lands so irrigated, the total number of years the subject water right was used on the irrigated acreage, the types and approximate acreages of crops historically raised on the irrigated acreage, and the names and addresses of all known previous owners or lessees of the land historically irrigated. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 120-132. - Same-Appurtenant to the subject land. 
    The following information shall be provided for all water rights that are appurtenant to the land that is the subject of the application: 
(1)  The name of the water right involved, the number of shares in a mutual ditch or reservoir company evidencing the right, if applicable, and/or the percentage of undivided interest of the water right(s) proposed to be dedicated. 
(2)  A copy of the documents by which the owner received title to the water right and a copy of any legal decree or judgment that affects the title of those water rights since the owner received title. 
(3)  The legal description and total number of acres of land historically irrigated with the appurtenant water right, the total number of years the subject water right was used on the irrigated acreage, the types and approximate acreages of crops historically raised on the irrigated acreage, the names and addresses of all known previous owners or lessees of the land historically irrigated. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
DIVISION 7. - CERTAIN FEES AND ACTIVITIES DEFERRED 

Sec. 120-133. - Additional deferral. 
    In addition to the deferral of the payment of any costs and fees permitted by this chapter, the payment of fees and/or costs imposed by this chapter may be deferred pursuant to Article XIV of Chapter 30 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 2003-7, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Secs. 120-134-120-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MUNICIPAL WATERSHED PRESERVATION 

Sec. 120-150. - Intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent and purpose of this article to obtain and maintain safe drinking water supplies for the citizens of Lafayette. 
(Ord. No. 1986-19, § 1, 5-6-86) 
Sec. 120-151. - Establishment of extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
    Pursuant to section 31-15-707(1)(b), Colorado Revised Statutes 1973, as amended, the jurisdiction of the City of Lafayette is hereby extended beyond the municipal boundaries to include the following stream segments: 
    South Boulder Creek from a point 6,800 feet south and 2,200 feet east of the southwest corner of Section 15, Township 1 South, Range 71 West, 6th P.M., to the point where South Boulder Creek intersects South Boulder Road in Section 3, Township 1 South, Range 70 West, 6th P.M. 
    Dry Creek a/k/a the New Dry Creek Carrier, from a point 1,500 feet north and 700 feet east of the southwest corner of Section 36, Township 1 North, Range 70 West, 6th P.M. to its confluence with Boulder Creek at a point 2,600 feet north and 2,100 feet east of the southwest corner of Section 17, Township 1 North, Range 69 West, 6th P.M. 
    Boulder Creek from a point 2,100 feet south and 1,000 feet east of the northwest corner of Section 23, Township 1 North, Range 70 West, 6th P.M., to the headgate of the Lower Boulder Ditch in the SW 1/4 SW 1/4, Section 16, Township 1 North, Range 69 West, 6th P.M. 
(Ord. No. 1986-19, § 1, 5-6-86) 
Sec. 120-152. - Regulation of stream segments. 
(a)  The city staff is directed to conduct a survey of all natural and man related activities within the stream segments above defined which are now or may in the future adversely affect the quality of the Lafayette municipal water supply. 
(b)  A summary of the adverse effects of each activity noted during the survey shall be prepared. 
(c)  To the extent that a natural activity having an adverse effect on water quality can be corrected without adverse effects to the property of others (such as the removal of beavers to eliminate giardia), the city staff is directed to control, remove or eliminate the natural activity. 
(d)  All other activities shall be evaluated on a case by case basis, once the specific effect on Lafayette's water supplies is noted. The city staff and city attorney are directed to coordinate with other local and state agencies having concurrent jurisdiction over the affected stream segments to promote the implementation of rules and regulations which will protect the municipal water supplies to the City of Lafayette and to enforce all rules and regulations once enacted. To the extent that any person or entity is conducting an activity that results in a deterioration of the quality of water flowing in the above defined stream segments below the minimum drinking water standards set by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, the city attorney, at the direction of the city council, shall pursue whatever administrative and judicial remedies are available to the city to eliminate such activities. 
(Ord. No. 1986-19, § 1, 5-6-86) 
Secs. 120-153-120-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - WATER FUND ENTERPRISE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1993-53, adopted Jan. 4, 1994, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of §§ 1-4 of said ordinance as §§ 120-161-120-164 herein was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 120-161. - Created. 
    Pursuant to the authority of section 16.13 of the Charter of the city, there is hereby created and established the water fund enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 1993-53, § 1, 1-4-94) 
Sec. 120-162. - Appointment of board. 
    The city council is hereby appointed as the board of the water fund enterprise. There shall not be appointed any persons other than the city council to serve on the board of the water fund enterprise nor shall city council delegate to any other person or entity the powers reserved to the board of the water fund enterprise hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1993-53, § 2, 1-4-94) 
Sec. 120-163. - Authority to issue revenue bonds. 
    The water fund enterprise, acting by and through the city council sitting as the board of the water fund enterprise, may issue its own revenue bonds or other obligations (including refunding securities) on behalf of the city, which revenue bonds or other obligations shall be payable solely from the net revenue (including special assessments) derived from the operation of the water fund enterprise. Such revenue bonds or other obligations may be additionally secured by mortgages on or security interests in any real or personal property of the city used in the operation of the water fund enterprise. Such revenue bonds or other obligations shall be issued by ordinance of the board of the water fund enterprise, adopted in the same manner and subject to referendum to the same extent as ordinances of the council. 
(Ord. No. 1993-53, § 3, 1-4-94) 
Sec. 120-164. - Restrictions on board's authority. 
    The city council shall not authorize the board of the water fund enterprise to acquire, construct or install or hold title to or dispose of any city-owned property used in the operation of the water fund enterprise, to impose or adjust rates, fees, tolls or charges for the use of any such property or for any service or commodity furnished by the water fund enterprise, to levy special assessments or to exercise any power reserved to the council or other city officials by the City Charter or otherwise (other than the power to issue revenue bonds and other obligations). 
(Ord. No. 1993-53, § 4, 1-4-94)
